APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

September 5th, 1950.

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Carcross Indian Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: RHEXPELLY
English name: Ruth Pelly
Age: Born March 10th, 1944
Name of Band: Carcross
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid:
Father's full name and No.: Fred Pelly
Mother's full name and No.: Dorothy (Good)
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: Church of England
Does applicant speak English?: Yes
Previously attended: school for years

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian, and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

Note—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

FORM No. 1-A 406
R. 3524

Note—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Whitehorse, Y. T.,
June 25th, 1951.

Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Re: Carcross Residential School and
Discharge of Rachael Silverfox,
birthdate Sept. 10, 1934, and Lizzie
Silverfox, birthdate June 18, 1935.

I have been informed by Rev. C. Stanger, Principal of the Carcross Indian Residential School, that the above-named children have reached the age of sixteen years and are recommended for discharge from the school.

May authorization be granted for the discharge of these children and authority granted to issue transportation to Mayo from Carcross. Transportation will be via train from Carcross to Whitehorse and bus from Whitehorse to Mayo.

HJM

cc Indian Commissioner for B.C.

September 11, 1951.

Mr. R. J. Meek,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Whitehorse, Y. T.

Re: Carcross Residential School

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, the Department approves having Jane Smarch remain in the above school until June 30, 1952.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I am in receipt of the following application from the Rev. C.T. Stanger, principal of the Carcross Indian Residential School, Carcross, Y.T.:

"I herewith request permission for Jane Smarch who has reached the age of 16 years to remain at this school for two more years. She would be entering Grade VI this term, with the possibility of attaining Grade VII completed by her eighteenth year."

I have been advised by the Rev. Stanger that he has the approval of the parents, Mr. and Mrs. Tommy Smarch O.L.I., Carcross Band.

c.c. Indian Commissioner for B.C.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent
Indian Agency.

CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

I attach hereto Applications for Admission on behalf of the following children:

Robert Hager          Laura Hager
Neil Hager            John Lucas
Florence Alice Silverfox (Baum)

In the case of Robert and Neil Hager, the mother Mary Hager, 009, Mayo Band, is at present at the Charles Camsell Hospital, the father wrote to me that he could not efficiently maintain his home with the children at school and himself working all day.

Florence Baum or Silverfox has no opportunity to attend day school as there is none at Fort Selkirk. Although her parents are living she is maintained by her grandfather Peter McGinty, 030, Selkirk Band.

May approval be obtained for the admission of the above to the Carcross Residential School.

c.c. Indian Commissioner for B.C.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent
Indian Agency.

I attach hereto Application for Admission for Christina Silas, Selkirk Band, to the Whitehorse Indian School. She formerly attended Carcross Residential School, but was transferred to Whitehorse as her father was working here.

However, the mother, Martha Silas was admitted to the Charles Cassell Hospital in January 1951 with far advanced pulmonary tuberculosis, Dr. Falconer has recently reported "she has far advanced disease and the outcome is still in doubt". In the meantime Davis Silas, who has the reputation of being a steady and reliable worker, has obtained permanent employment at the Carcross Residential School.

I attach a written request signed by David Silas asking that Christina and Pearl Silas be transferred to the Carcross School. Both Rev. Lee and Rev. Stanger are agreeable to the move though neither like transferring children in mid-term. I have interviewed David Silas who is very sincere in his desire to have his children with him at Carcross Residential School. I hesitate to recommend the transfer from an educational point of view, but from the purely humane angle I would suggest the two children be allowed to be with their father - particularly in view of the mother's condition.

Further to your letter of November 2nd 1951 regarding the admission of Paddy, Jimmy & Albert James of the Atlin-Tealin Band to the Carcross Indian Residential School, the following is reported.

In order to definitely establish that the father George James expressed his sincere wishes that his children be enrolled at the Carcross School the reply to your letter was held in abeyance until the writer completed a winter inspection of the Carcross area during the month of December last.

It was learned that Mr. Matthew Watson who witnessed the signing of this parent's signature was a Commissioner for Oaths in and for the Yukon Territory and that he did fully explain the meaning of the affidavit to the parent before taking the oath that it was his wish to have the children enrolled at the Carcross School.

It is understood, that before the Lower Post Residential School was completed, James intended to send his children to this school when it was completed. However in recent months he had a dispute with Father Engel, O.M.I., of the Atlin Mission and as a result decided emphatically to send his children to the Carcross School rather than Lower Post. There is no doubt in the opinion of this office that James' declaration was understood by him and that it is now his wish to send the children to the Carcross School.

In view of the foregoing, may their admission to this school be approved?

With reference to your letter of February 12th regarding admissions to the Carcross Indian Residential School, in view of the contents of your letter the Department is prepared to approve the admission of Bernard Johnson to the Carcross Residential School, provided the Principal is prepared to accept him.

With reference to the applications for Alto Washpan, Effie Washpan and Garry Jimmy Sam, it is noted that in both cases the parents are living and all three children have attended the Carmacks Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA,
Ontario.

Reference your letter of 19th instant, file 940-10 (E6).
Rev. C.T. Stanger, principal of Carcross Indian Residential School has been advised of approval of Bernard Johnson to his school.

Concerning Alta and Effie Washpan, children of David Washpan, 039, Carmacks Band. David's trapline is located some 25 miles up the Little Salmon River, and 45 miles from Carmacks. Whenever the family is in Carmacks - possibly between two and four months during the summer time - the children attend the Carmacks Day School.

Garry Jimmy Sam, son of Jack Sam, 032, Selkirk Band, who has a trapline some 40 miles up from Selkirk on the Pelly River, and approximately 80 miles from Carmacks. This family usually spends the summer in and about Carmacks and during this time the children attend Carmacks Indian Day School.

The maximum yearly schooling the above children receive would be about four months, the average would be somewhat less, possibly about three months. It is felt that more adequate schooling can be given at a residential school and I would recommend their admittance to Carcross Residential School.

Mr. R.J. Meek,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Whitehorse, Y.T.,

With reference to your letter of March 22nd regarding the admission of Kenneth Johnson to the Carcross Indian Residential School, we have carefully reviewed the correspondence on this case and the Department's ruling is that in view of the fact that his religious denomination is Roman Catholic his admission to the Carcross Indian Residential School is denied.

This case is similar to the James children, whose admission to the Carcross school has been denied for the next academic year by our official letter of February 29th signed by the Director. The Department is paying the grant for them for this year because they were already at the school when a decision on their admission was made. However, in the case of Kenneth Johnson he must not be placed in the Carcross school or any other school without securing the necessary authority.

If the parents are interested in placing Kenneth Johnson in a residential school, the Department will consider an application for his admission to the Lower Post school, but under no circumstances must he be placed in the Carcross school.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Reference letter February 23, 1952, File 940-10 (E6), the parents of Kenneth Johnson live at Bennett, B.C. The closest school is Carcross, about twenty-five miles from them.

Kenneth attended Whitehorse Indian Day School on a day school basis for a short time in 1951 as he was staying with relatives in Whitehorse at that time. I understand these facilities are not now available to him.

As his parents live at a considerable distance from a school institutional care for Kenneth is necessary.

Superintendent

May 11th 1946.

The Indian Agent,
DAWSON, Yukon.

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to inform you that Register No. 138 - Douglas Hall - Age 13 years - was accidentally drowned on Sunday, April 28th 1946 at 4.00 P.M.

This boy was given permission to be absent from the school that week-end in order to visit a relative in Carcross a visit that was approved by his father. On Sunday afternoon this boy rode a bicycle out on a wharf, lost control of same and fell into the river. According to eye witnesses to this tragedy he was only in the water for about 15 minutes but artificial respiration administered by the Section Foreman for over 45 minutes brought no results.

The parents of this boy were notified immediately and an enquiry into the accident was conducted by the R.C.M.P.

Yours truly,

H. C. M. Grant (Sgd.)

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM NO. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? April 28th 1946.

2. At what time of day? About 4.00 P.M.

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? School Engineer was over in the village of Carcross shortly after accident happened and was informed of same by Section Foreman.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Artificial respiration.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? No medicines were used.

6. When was the doctor called? R.C.M.P. were notified immediately.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? Pupil was not removed to hospital.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school? Section Foreman, trained in First Aid, administered artificial respiration for approximately 45 minutes.

9. Add any other useful information here.

At the time this boy was drowned he had leave of absence from the school for the week-end to visit a relative. Such visits were approved of by the father.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

Re Carcross Indian Residential School (Anglican) - Yukon

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a report of an examination made of the books and records of the above school at the office of the Secretary of Anglican Schools in Canada, situated at The Bible House in Winnipeg. The examination covers a period of one year dating from October 1st, 1935, to September 30th, 1936.

This school is situated in the Yukon territory and, on account of its isolated position, has always been very expensive to operate.

The total Per Capita Grant earned for the year amounted to $9,280.00 and refunds of $329.39 were received from the Department.

The expenditures amounted to $14,671.85, which is $600.00 above last year. Like all small schools, the salaries are nearly 50% of the grant and it is very hard to make a reduction in staff and still maintain the required standard of efficiency.

An examination of the vouchers shows that, although all supplies are purchased by the Commission in Winnipeg at the same price as other schools, the freight amounts to the cost of the product.

Vouchers were examined and compared to synoptic entries and postings of monthly totals were checked to ledger.

The farming operations show only three acres under cultivation, which is used as a garden. The livestock consist of seven head of cattle and 3 horses. Practically all feed must be shipped in, out of an expense of $2,094.69 for the farm. $1,255.84 was paid in freight. As the cattle are maintained for a supply of milk, I suggested that canned or powdered milk might be more economical and the Secretary is considering making a change.

The cost of operation shows the cost per child as $351.79 with $231.25 being allowed by the grant. The cost of clothing at $15.15 per child per year is very normal, but the food cost is $94.37, which includes all freight charges.

Re Carcross Indian Residential School (Anglican) - Yukon

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith a report of an examination made of the books and records of the above school at the office of the Secretary of Anglican Schools in Canada, situated at The Bible House in Winnipeg. The examination covers a period of one year dating from October 1st, 1935, to September 30th, 1936.

This school is situated in the Yukon territory and, on account of its isolated position, has always been very expensive to operate.

The total Per Capita Grant earned for the year amounted to $9,280.00 and refunds of $329.39 were received from the Department.

The expenditures amounted to $14,671.85, which is $600.00 above last year. Like all small schools, the salaries are nearly 50% of the grant and it is very hard to make a reduction in staff and still maintain the required standard of efficiency.

An examination of the vouchers shows that, although all supplies are purchased by the Commission in Winnipeg at the same price as other schools, the freight amounts to the cost of the product.

Vouchers were examined and compared to synoptic entries and postings of monthly totals were checked to ledger.

The farming operations show only three acres under cultivation, which is used as a garden. The livestock consist of seven head of cattle and 3 horses. Practically all feed must be shipped in and, out of an expense of $2,094.69 for the farm, $1,352.31 was paid in freight. As the cattle are maintained for a supply of milk, I suggested that canned or powdered milk might be more economical and the Secretary is considering making a change.

The cost of operation shows the cost per child as $351.79 with $231.25 being allowed by the grant. The cost of clothing at $15.15 per child per year is very normal, but the food cost is $94.37, which includes all freight charges.

I beg to submit the report of an audit made of the books and records pertaining to the above school. The examination was conducted at the office of the Anglican Residential School Commission, Winnipeg, and covered the year 1943.

Revenue and Expenditure

The attached statements were prepared from the synoptic cash book and other Commission records, and include the payments and collections made on account of 1942. The statements are self-explanatory.

There was an operating deficit of $8,245.96 for 1943, which was an increase of $2,319.37 over 1942. This school was in operation during only six months of 1942, and received the per capita grant for that period only. I have prepared Statement #A to show the revenue and expenditure for the term of operation. In the six-month period there was an operating deficit of $4,297.90.

The food raised and consumed at the school was estimated at $825.00, while the clothing supplied by the Dorcas Society was valued at $1,646.78.

The cost of operation per pupil per year (based on the six-month period) works out at $721.307, which is an increase of $275.097. The cost of operation has always been high, due to the low pupilage and the location of the school. In this period the average attendance dropped from 30.51 to 19.51, and accounts for a large part of the increase in operating costs.

The principal's report for 1942 shows the acreage belonging to the school as 160 acres, of which 3 acres are being cultivated for garden purposes. The livestock consisted of 2 horses, 4 cows, 5 pigs, and 40 poultry.

W.R. Butchart,
Auditor.

March 26, 1931.

Mr. W.W.Cory,
Deputy Minister of the Interior, Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Cory,

Following up our conversation of last week, and at your suggestion, I wish to bring before your Department, the needs of a class of children living in isolated parts of Yukon Territory.

In different places throughout the country, children are growing up without any educational facilities. They are mostly of mixed parentage— their fathers being and mothers natives.

Last Summer we opened up a small hostel in Dawson for four or five children at the parents' request, under Miss E.J.Hartel, a lady of much experience in educational work. Two of these children are from Rupert House, one from the Pelly River, and one from the district.

These children attend the Public School in Dawson and are given home training under good surroundings in the hostel. There are at least twenty or thirty children of this kind, who ought to be attending school even now and others will attend next year.

These children will remain for the most part residents of the country, and will have a great influence on the Indians. They will also, under the present regulations, have all the rights and liberties of the white men. If educated and given a fair opportunity, they are the most valuable citizens the country has. In their hands more than in the hands of others, rests the future of this great Frontier Land. They are, in most cases, Pioneers, and have settled in outlying districts.

Some of the parents will be able to do a great deal for the education of the children, but others will need assistance.

ST PAUL'S HOSTEL.

Dawson.

St. Paul's Hostel, Dawson, has recently been opened and will be in charge of Miss E. J. Naftel. The object of this institution is to provide a home for children other than Indians and Eskimos, who live in isolated places or where circumstances prevent them from getting an education. The children will be under the direct supervision of the Superintendent and will attend the public school, besides receiving domestic and other training in the Home. Before admission each must be medically examined and pronounced as healthy. The rates will be as follows: $25. per month for each child, $22.50 per month for each of two or more children from one family. A small reduction will be made for the round year. Parents or guardians will pay travelling expenses and provide clothing. Children will require a small amount of pocket money and also for school books. In case of illness children will be taken care of as far as possible in the Home. If medical attention or hospital treatment are found necessary, the parents will be expected to pay the cost of such. All children are accepted on an equal footing and the rates are placed at a low figure to be within the reach of parents of moderate means. The cost of upkeep will amount to much more than the charges made and parents and other friends are invited to do what they can to help, and thus ensure the continuation of the institution.

Dear Mr. Cory,-

I enclose herewith a statement regarding the question of the education of half breed children in Yukon, and am forwarding Sir James Loughheed a copy of this.

11th April, 1921.

Dear Mr. Scott,-

I am sending you herewith copies of two communications from Bishop Stringer relative to the establishment of St. Paul's Hostel at Dawson to provide a home for half breed children who live in isolated parts of the Territory, or where circumstances prevent them from obtaining an education.

It is explained that the children are to reside in the Hostel and attend the public schools; that a charge of $25.00 a month is to be made for each child; that the cost will be about $40.00 a month per child; that with twenty or thirty occupants it will cost about $8,000.00 per annum to maintain the hostel; that the parents will contribute about $2,500.00; and that it will be necessary to make up the balance of $5,500.00 in some other way. Bishop Stringer asks, therefore:

(1) That the Department defray the cost of building, amounting to about $10,000.00 and give a per capita grant;

(2) that the institution be placed in charge of the Department of Indian Affairs, or some other Department of the Government;

(3) that the building known as the Commissioner's residence be utilized for this purpose.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to acknowledge yours of May 4th and also yours of June 23rd in which you ask for further information regarding the question of the education of half-breed children.

I have recently had a meeting of the Committee of men and women in Dawson to discuss the problem.

There are two questions confronting us at present, which are depending on each other, namely, the number of children who are likely to apply, and the providing of suitable accommodation for them.

It is very difficult to learn in advance, the number of children who would be available. The parents of the children who should attend school, seem to find it inconvenient to decide in advance, so that any estimate, must be a very rough and uncertain one. About a dozen children that I know of, will in all probability, present themselves for admission, when school opens about the middle of August. At the same time, it is quite possible that several more may put in an appearance at the last moment this Autumn. Some children live in very remote places, where communication is very uncertain.

The other practical side of the question is the providing of accommodation in such a way that the need will be met without unnecessary expense, no matter how few or how many children may apply.

We are now in possession of a log building which will accommodate one half dozen children and perhaps two of a staff.

Three members of the committee and I looked over a building belonging to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, formerly known as the Canteen and Sergeants Mess and Recreation Room, standing on the River Front on the North side of the Police grounds, and we came to the conclusion that this is the most suitable building in Dawson, if it could be put into shape.
In order to see if it would be available, I am writing to the Commissioner of Police, asking for the use of this building. The walls, floor and roof seem to be in good condition, but the heating plant was unsatisfactory, as I understand the police gave it up because it was so cold. It is about 62 x 35 feet, two story, and is divided into two parts by a partition upstairs and down.

One thing that commended itself to me is the possibility of arranging it, so that a part can be used, if the number of children do not justify the use of the whole building. I imagine the heating could be arranged to allow this alternative.

It is difficult to get an estimate of the cost of putting the building into shape, but this should not be prohibitive; the chief cost would be a suitable heating plant, arranging of the plumbing and sewerage system. The main sewer drain is close to the building.

If the Police Department would give the use of this building, it would have to be put into shape and furnished. I would suggest that this should be done at the expense of the Government, and also that a per capita grant should be given, much the same as in the case of the Carcross Indian Boarding School.

The proposal is to give the children a home where they can get proper home training, and that they should attend the Public School in Dawson. This has been the arrangement with the five children kept in the Home this last year, and it seemed to work very satisfactorily.

The average per capita grant would probably be higher than in the case of the Carcross Indian Boarding School, because of the smaller number of children to begin with.

In addition I think I should mention that the per capita grant given to the Carcross Indian Boarding School, is sufficient to cover only about one half of the cost.

Some of the parents would be able to pay a certain amount towards the expenses, and we are asking them to give Twenty Five Dollars per month when possible. At the same time, it seems wise not to refuse any suitable child, and we must count on many bad debts. A careful calculation shows that with twenty children, it would cost about Forty Dollars per month for each child, to pay expenses.

I have tried to give frankly as much information as possible. I know the Minister of the Interior does not want to enter into any undertaking without knowing something of the cost. You will realize that I have also to meet the same difficulty. But here is a task to be met, and I am willing to do all in my power to meet it. After the financial part is guaranteed, it will require constant care and attention, which I am prepared to give. Dealing with the parents is not an easy task—then the procuring of
suitable workers to run the Institution is always an anxiety and worry, and this I shall endeavor to undertake.

The whole project is not an easy matter at the best, but I would urge the Government to give the necessary financial and moral support in order that the class of children referred to, living in isolation, may get a chance in life, and receive a reasonable amount of education, under healthy surroundings, in order that they may have an opportunity of becoming useful and intelligent citizens.

If thought desirable, perhaps the Interior Department might appoint some one, living in Dawson, such as the Commissioner, or the Head of the Police, or Mr. John Black, to confer with me, regarding ways and means, and make a report to the Department.

If the time should appear to be too short, to put the building referred to above, into shape before Winter, a suggestion has been made that we should, for the coming Winter, use the present building for the girls, and procure another building for the boys, or vice versa. This would be more inconvenient and more costly perhaps, but if necessary it could be arranged, and the time is passing rapidly.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Isaac O. Yukon.

Dear Dr. Scott,

The letter from your Department dated Aug. 19th last regarding the education of Half-breed and other isolated children in Yukon, did not reach me till after I came to Eastern Canada.

In the meantime, it was necessary to make further arrangements to meet the pressing need for the winter. On further consultation with Supt. Tucker of the R.C.M.P., I found that the use of the Barracks Building or Sergeant's Mess, for which we had applied, could be granted by the R.C.M.P. Police only on condition that we should be prepared to evacuate at once if the building were required any time by the police or other Government Department.

There seemed to be other difficulties in the way, and we had to decide at once as the children were arriving in Dawson and winter was coming on.

The committee were called together and after full consideration we decided to use the building we had occupied the previous year and to build an addition to it. Some nineteen children arrived before the close of navigation, and as it was necessary to make preparations without any delay we erected a log addition about equal to the size of the original building. This is being used at the present time.

I now wish to reply to your suggestion that I should give definite figures with regard to the cost in order that a specific amount may be asked for at the estimates at the next session of Parliament. We have to put additional work on the building next Summer in order to make it complete.

I am willing to defray the cost of the building if the Government will give a suitable annual grant towards the running expenses of the Institution.

We have calculated for this current year, it will cost in addition to what the parents are able to pay, about Four Thousand Dollars. This is calculated partly on last year's experience and partly upon our experience of running the Carcross Indian Boarding School.

I wish therefore, to ask Parliament for the sum of $4,000, for the annual upkeep for the year 1921-22 and $1,000, towards the expense of the year 1920-1921 or a total of $5,000, for these two years.
The Institution has now been in existence for one and a half years, and I have had to face all the costs single-handed.

It has filled a long felt need. The money, if given, will be well spent, and would be looked on as creditable to the Government. If you think it advisable I could come to Ottawa any time and explain the project to the Minister of the Interior, to whom the proposal would be new, and to further discuss the question with you and with others.

I am anxious to have a definite decision on the matter as soon as possible. The Institution is going ahead and doing good work, but the financial upkeep is giving me considerable anxiety, and it would be a shame to have to close up the work now.

For many years, this question of the education of children living in isolated places mostly half-breeds, has been considered, and this plan seemed the only solution. By means of this Institution many children will be given a chance to become good and useful citizens instead of a menace to the country.

Trusting that this request may be granted,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr. Scott,

I wish to acknowledge your communication of Feb. 10th in which you kindly state that you propose to place in the estimates for St. Paul's Hostel, Dawson, the sum of $1000. for the year 1920-21 and $4000. for the year 1921-22.

Since I wrote you last I have received from my financial Secretary Mr. A. Coldrick, Dawson, a statement of expenditure up to Dec. 31st, 1921 which shows that the cost of running the Institution is greater than I had anticipated. The average cost for the four months Sept. 1st to Dec. 31st 1921 including salaries, provisions, fuel, light etc., was about $980, a month. This is the first estimate we have been able to make with the increased number of children, namely nineteen.

The average for ten months of the year probably will be a little higher than this. For two months in the Summer, some of the children will be able to go to their homes, but the majority come from a distance, and will have to be kept in Dawson throughout the Summer; also some unforeseen expenses generally crop up. The cost for the whole year may be estimated at $11,000, with the present number of nineteen children. Of this amount we hope to collect from the parents about $1,800, which will leave a balance of $9,200, to be made up. I find also that we shall require $1,500, instead of $1,000, to clear off the deficit of 1920-21.

I wish therefore, to ask you to add $800, for the year 1920-21 and $2,500, for the year 1921-22 respectively or a total of $8,000, for the two fiscal years instead of $5,000, which I requested in my letter of Jan. 31st.

I am sorry my former estimate was so much out, but it was more or less guess work till I received the statement for the four last months for 1921 as shown above, and this reached me only a few days ago. I had hoped to get this information from Dawson before writing my last letter to you, but felt that I should delay no longer lest it should be too late.
Will you please let me know if you think it would help any for me to go to Ottawa, and present the matter to the new Minister of the Interior, or to any of the other officials. I am most anxious that the above increased grants should be made as soon as I shall have to procure a considerable amount, to make ends meet.

I am undertaking, without any cost to the Department, to provide a building, and have already erected an addition at considerable cost.

The Institution is filling a great need. All reports indicate that the children already show a wonderful improvement, and the work is considered by the people of Yukon generally, as most helpful and praiseworthy.

With reference to the name of the school to which you refer, the title 'St. Paul's Hostel, Dawson' has been used now for a year and a half, and has become identified in Yukon with the Institution. It seems quite satisfactory, and would be difficult to change locally. Of course if you think it necessary to change the name officially, it would not make much difference I suppose even if locally the old name continued to be used. Dear Dr. Scott,

I wish to thank you most heartily for your kind interest in the work of St. Paul's Hostel, Dawson, and for the substantial help you were able to procure through your Department. The results of your active interest will make it possible to continue on with the work.

At present there are twenty-two children in the Hostel, all of whom seem to be doing very well. They attend the Dawson Public School, and take their stand beside the other children with considerable credit. These boys and girls are now given a chance in life, and there is no reason why they should not prove to be good citizens instead of a menace to society, which they were likely to become if left to themselves. It is a work that seems well worth while. The children are happy and healthy and there is a wonderful difference in their demeanor since coming into the Hostel.

Mr. Moffat:

In April, 1921, the then Honourable Superintendent General requested the Department of the Interior to refer to us certain correspondence from the Rt. Rev. Bishop Stringer, relative to the St. Paul's Hostel at Dawson, Yukon. His Lordship requested government assistance for a hostel for the education of half-breed children and, as the Department of Indian Affairs had the necessary machinery for making a per capita grant to such an institution, it was decided that the St. Paul's Hostel should come under this Department, if any.

Constitute and orphan half-breeds are admitted to the St. Paul's Hostel. As this Department has considered itself responsible only for the education of non-treaty half-breeds who live the Indian mode of life on reserves, it is thought advisable to secure an Order in Council permitting us to make an initial grant of $5000 to Bishop Stringer.

The Bishop established the boarding school and in the Supplementary Estimates for 1921-22 for Indian Education, an item of $5000 was allowed to defray initial expenses. In the Main Estimates for this fiscal year $6600 was provided as per capita grant.

If we secure an Order in Council giving permission to pay a grant of $5000 to this institution, the future payments of per capita grant will be unquestioned. Accounts certified by the Bishop have been presented showing that the expenditure from September 1920 to March 31, 1922 has been $6112.73. $2327.64 has been collected from parents and guardians of the children in residence, leaving a total net expenditure of $5785.09.

Mr. and Mrs. Johnson are an ideal couple to have in charge of the institution. Everything runs smoothly and the discipline is good. The children consequently receive good home training, and it is quite a common thing to hear people say how well behaved they are both in and out of school.

We are now considering the question of an addition to the building, as the accommodation is inadequate, and we also expect some additional pupils next Fall.

Again thanking you for your practical interest in this work, I remain,

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir,

The Rev. C.F. Johnson, Principal of St. Paul's Hostel, at Dawson, since 1922, died in the Hospital here on May 14th last. He had undergone an operation a week previously and while at first we had thought he would recover our hopes were not realised.

It has not been easy to find a successor to the late Mr. Johnson. I have however appointed to that position for one year the Rev. L.G. Chappell, who for the last year has been in charge of our Mission at Moosehide and has done very good work there. If the work at the Hostel progresses favorably I hope to make Mr. Chappell's appointment a permanent one. I trust that this appointment will meet with your approval.

To fill the vacancy thus created at Moosehide I have appointed the Rev. Alex. Anderson, B.A., L.Th.. Mr Anderson has been in the Diocese of Yukon for a year, having been temporarily in charge of the Church in Dawson during the absence of the Rector on furlough. DAWSON, Jan. 12th, 1942.

Dear Clarence:

Referring to your letter of October 17th perhaps the following information will be of use to you. No doubt it is all available from your own files but you may not have it in summarized form.

I have not had an opportunity of inspecting the residential school at Carcross, nor do I know much of the results which are being achieved by it. My general observation of the work done in such institutions in the north, however, is that they do little to equip the Indians for the type of life which he must of necessity live in this country. Whether they make the Indians dissatisfied with the way of life to which he must almost inevitably return. However I realize that this is a controversial question and the schools appear to be conducted in accordance with departmental policy.

The Hostel which is maintained by the Anglican Church at Dawson is for half-breed children. I do not think there are any full blood Indian inmates. The children in residence attend the local school. I note that it has been suggested that the school at Carcross might be closed and a consolidation effected with the Hostel at Dawson, making use of the old residence of the Commissioner, for accommodation.

Bishop Geddes has not been in the Territory since my arrival so I have had no opportunity of discussing this suggestion with him. However it appears to me that the idea is open to many objections, perhaps the chief being that the cost of maintenance of an institution at Dawson would be much higher than at Carcross because of higher freight rates on supplies, the increase in cost of fuel, etc. There is not sufficient adjoining ground available to grow potatoes or other root crops to assist in maintenance or to train the native children in agricultural pursuits. Moreover the building itself is most unsuitable and the remodelling, which would be necessary before it could be so used, would be very expensive.

It may be that a lengthier experience will result in qualification of some of the views herein expressed, but in the meantime you have my present reactions to your letter. You will appreciate that I have written quite frankly in this connection and also as regards the more personal matters which are the subject of separate correspondence.

J. E. Gibben,

I know it will be argued that these children are half-breeds and not Indians, but surely the fact that they are part Indian does give the Indian Department the right to be interested in their welfare. Then too by decreeing that a half-breed should have the status of a white man does not absolve the Government from all responsibility of aiding him to fit himself to take his place in the community as a white man.

I believe that there is no other institution in Canada exactly similar to St. Paul's Hostel. It had its origin in an effort to meet a somewhat unique situation that was created as a result of the impact of a large white population, predominantly male, upon a comparatively small Indian population, at the time of the Klondike Gold Rush and in the years immediately succeeding.

Your branch has since the inception of St Paul's Hostel provided us with a per capita grant and each year a supply of medicines. All the other expenses of the Institution; the building, its equipment and maintenance, the clothing and food for the children, have been provided by the Church. We are grateful for the interest your Branch has shewn in these children who come from the remote and isolated parts of the Yukon, and for what you have done to assist them to become worthwhile citizens of Canada. And I beg of you to continue the good work that you have been doing and not deprive us of your grant for without we shall have to close our doors.

Dear Sir,

Some time ago I received a communication from the Director of the Lands, Parks, & Forests Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources in which he stated that you had informed him that you would not be paying the customary per capita grant to St. Paul's Hostel after the end of March 1943. I have as yet received no intimation from your Branch that you were contemplating such a course and I am wondering if it is true that at the end of March next our life line is to be cut and we are to be forced to close the doors of St. Paul's Hostel. For without Government assistance we could not hope to continue operations.

For more than twenty years now your Branch has been rendering financial assistance each year to this institution and we have been carrying on a work that I feel confident is of real benefit to the whole of the Yukon. The work has now just reached the stage where we are beginning to see real results in our efforts to fit the children who come to us to take their full share in the development of the life of our country. In June last one of our girls completed the requirements for University Matriculation, and is now at the Royal Columbian Hospital in New Westminster, B.C., training to be a nurse. Another girl who finished her schooling a few years ago and who, since then, has held a subordinate position on our staff here, is at the present time filling, very acceptably, a position on the staff of the Indian Residential School at Alert Bay. One of our boys who reached the age of 16 in June last, has since leaving school been filling the position of Messenger and junior operator at the local Radiotelegraph Station operated by the Royal Canadian Corps of Signals. The Officer in Charge of the Station speaks in the highest terms of his work. I think it is quite safe to say that not one of these three would be making the contribution to the welfare of our country that they are making today, had it not been for St. Paul's Hostel. I had hoped that as the years went by, an increasing number of our children would be finding useful vocations in the life of the country, and thereby rewarding the Government and the Church for the expense incurred in giving them this opportunity. Must all our hopes be in vain and all the efforts of the past years go for nought just as they appeared to be reaching the stage where they are beginning to bear fruit.
Ottawa, February 3, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Grant to St. Paul's Hostel, Yukon.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received from the Right Reverend W. A. Geddes, D.D., Bishop of the Yukon. I am enclosing also copy of a circular letter dated December 10, 1937, addressed to inspectors, Indian agents and principals of residential schools.

You are doubtless aware that this Branch has been paying per capita grant for the maintenance of the St. Paul's Hostel, Yukon, during the last 20 years. This grant has been paid at the rate of $250.00 per pupil on an enrolment of 30 pupils.

In view of the fact that no provision is made in the estimates of this Branch for the education of pupils other than Indian pupils, our legal right to make this grant to the St. Paul's Hostel has been questioned from time to time. The grant was first made in the year 1925, at a time when a limited number of half-breed children were admitted to Indian residential schools. These half-breed children were admitted by the authority of a ruling made by the Minister of the Interior and dated October 18, 1899. The Minister's justification for the ruling at that time was expressed in a statement to the effect "that the North West Government cannot provide for the education of non-annuitants upon reserves; and if we exclude them from our schools they will practically be debarred from all means of education". There is nothing on file to indicate that the legality of this particular regulation was ever reviewed by the Law Officers of the Crown, nor is there anything to suggest that its legality was disputed at any time throughout the years. It is difficult, however, for the officials of this Branch to
convince themselves that we can legally make a grant from year to year for the maintenance of the St. Paul's Hostel and for the education of half-breed children enrolled at that institution, while at the same time refusing the enrolment of equally deserving half-breed pupils at our residential schools throughout the Dominion.

No provision has been made in the 1943-44 estimates for the payment of per capita grant to the St. Paul's Hostel and the Director of the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch was so notified in a letter dated July 6, 1942. It was my understanding at that time that the responsibility for the payment of this annual grant would be assumed by the Territorial Government of the Yukon.

Ottawa, February 15, 1940.

Dear Father Plourde:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 10, in which you submit, for departmental consideration, the claims for the establishment of an Indian residential school in the Teslin Lake district, received by you from the Right Reverend J. L. Coudert.

You are probably aware that the construction of certain Indian day and residential schools was carefully reviewed and considered at the time the 1940-41 estimates were prepared. It was decided, however, in view of war conditions, that our building program for this year, with the exception of one or two day schools, should be abandoned. It does not appear at all likely, therefore, that we shall be able to secure the funds necessary for the rebuilding of either the Albany R. C. or the Carcross C. E. schools.

The Department was informed a week or two ago of the destruction of the Ahousaht residential school, by fire. This is only one of a number of schools that have been destroyed by fire in recent years. In view of this serious loss and inconvenience to the Department and to the Churches concerned, I am convinced that all residential schools built in the future should be of fireproof construction throughout. I am equally convinced that it will be almost impossible to secure the funds necessary to construct such buildings. The number of residential schools that should be built and the type of construction is, of course, a matter of government policy. However, it does seem to me economically unsound to insist upon

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
General Superintendent,
Catholic Oblate Missions,
612 McDermot Avenue,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.
the multiplication of residential schools while we have not at our disposal now, nor have we had at any time in recent years, the funds necessary to keep the buildings already in operation in a reasonable state of repair. For example, there are a number of Indian residential schools at this date that are hauling the water required to meet the needs of the institution a considerable distance. Further, there are a great many schools that are still urgently in need of paint, additional buildings for vocational instruction, etc.

I have been wondering, therefore, if it would not be advisable for the Churches to make a careful survey of Indian educational needs as these are likely to arise in the future and to work out a program that might be considered practicable by the Government, in view of the prevailing economic conditions.

It is scarcely necessary to add that I should be glad to discuss this matter with you personally, during one of your visits to the Department.

Yours very truly,

March 2nd, 1941

To Mr. Harper Reed, Indian Agent
Telegraph Creek, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Referring to our conversation of a few days ago in Atlin regarding the Orphan, Destitute and T.B. Indian Children belonging to the R.C. Church in the Stikin Agency as well as in the Yukon, I would suggest that the Department of Indian Affairs build a combination Boarding School and Preventorium capable of accommodating some 50 or 60 children and located at a convenient point on the frontier of the Yukon and British Columbia.

Our Church would welcome such a move and would be willing to assist the Department by providing an adequate staff of nursing and teaching sisters for the work; I understand that a suitable piece of land belonging to the Government could be found at Tagish where the barracks of the Mounted Police used to be located in the days of the Klondike rush; there is, at such a point, an abundance of game and fish, and some natural meadows where fodder could be easily obtained for a few heads of cattle. The altitude is ideal for the treatment of Tuberculosis, and the climate dry and salubrious; Tagish being only some 12 miles from Carcross can easily be reached either overland or by boat.

I firmly count on your cooperation to get the Department interested in an enterprise which would mean so much for the welfare of many Indian Children of the Stikin Agency and the Yukon.

Yours sincerely,

J.L. Coudert O.M.I.
Coadj.of the Yukon & P.R.
Tagish Lake, Y.T. (site old N.W.M.P. Detachment) North end.

Transportation:- On (a little off however) the main Summer Boat Service to the Atlin Lake District. Winters - frozen lake travel to Atlin - but Spring and Fall periods of no travel. Freight rates rather high. Transport of children from the Cassiar District would be by Air. Very accessible from all Yukon points, only. This site will be on the proposed new roadway from Carcross to Atlin. Is now on the Dom. Govt Wires Line.

Living:- Fish supply in Lake very good. Little or no meat locally but cattle could be stocked; also honeses etc. Wood fuel would have to be cut on Lake and hauled in. Oil burning plant could be installed, but costs more. Climate ideal - high and dry, suitable for Nomadic Indians. Water supply - Lake frozen over in winters. Good vegetation possible.

Medicals- Doctors are stationed at both Whitehorse, and Atlin, at which places there are Indian Wards attached to the Hospitals. Phone connections each way.

Construction:- In the long run, lumber from the outside would be more beneficial - costs however would be heavy. Filling that, house logs etc could be hauled in from the Lake - but large trees are scattered. Outside material would come up over the White Pass Route-from Skagway, and then floated down the Lake from Carcross.-railhead.

His Lordship was promised that a report on this matter would be submitted to the Department, but that it must be borne in mind; a serious War was in progress, and that all expenses were curtailed.

However, were such an enterprise entertained, there is little doubt that some control of our vexed T.B. situation could be maintained; and as it is utterly impossible to segregate known cases within the Nomadic Cassiar, under present wild conditions, it is evident that some time in the future some sort of a Preventorium will have to be considered. Also it is mentioned that such an establishment, if ever considered would be able to bring our nomadic children up-to-date, in the least possible time; with correct education- to withstand the on-coming civilisation of the Western North Country. In this case, of course, the present Seasonal Day Schools could be discarded.

All of which, Sir, is respectfully submitted as promised His Lordship -Bishop Coudert. O.M.I.

I am,

Sir,

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept. Mines & Resources.
OTTAWA.

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.
Sir,

Re:- Suggested R.C. Boarding School & Preventorium. TAGISH LAKE. Y.T.

Bishop Coudert, O.M.I., at an interview in Atlin, B.C., on February 18th last, brought up the above subject for consideration. He stated that it was high time that some serious effort should be made to stop the ravages of T.B. infection amongst the R.C. Nomadic Children, and the R.C. Missions within the Stikine Agency, and also some parts of the Yukon. Enclosed is submitted a letter received from His Lordship. This suggestion was given polite attention; but it had to be admitted that such an institution was very necessary, as we were utterly unable to carry out prevention methods in the wild Interior, at present.

A discussion took place on the matter of Location, and three places were considered:- Firstly Watson Lake, near Liard Po at the back end of the Cassiar. It was mentioned that as a New Air Port was being constructed there, such a school might be served "by air" from most points, and by River from the Westward. However the remoteness of the location, taken with the cost of freight, etc, proved such a point useless.

A site on the Stikine River, 16 miles below the town of Telegraph was next taken up, favoured by the Indian Agent, but not so much by His Lordship. The following data is submitted on this site:-

Transportation:- Summer River Boat from Wrangell S.E. Alaska. Winter -Old car trail to Telegraph Creek-useable, but Dog-teams can be used. Freight rates to here very reasonable. Easy access to any from Cassiar Interior.

Living :- Unending supply of Salmon-fair supply Moose & Goat meat etc. Fuel Wood unlimited. Good side stream possible for Hydro Electric use. Ample grounds-river benches with Bull Pine. Fairly dry belt, but with occasional cold river winds. Wintering of horses possible.

Medical :- A Doctor is resident at Telegraph Creek, and Phon connection can be established. As there is no Hospital operating in Telegraph Creek, and the Townsite being crowded, it might be possible to establish a White Ward on this site also.

Construction :- Freight on imported lumber would not be excessive - Failing that house logs etc can be obtained on the site. Very fine tested sand and clay, for Brick making, is also on the benches, near by. Sun all winter long, and very good gardens possible.

The site favoured by His Lordship, was that of the Old N.W. M. Police Barracks at the north end of Tagish Lake Y.T. He considered that as it was in the Yukon, it would be more under Ottawa control, and at the same time serve both the Yukon and British Columbia. It was mentioned that the Church of England had an Industrial School at Carcross, just 25 miles, by lake, distant. The following data is submitted on the Tagish Lake site.

I am taking occasion of this communication to urge again the officials of the Indian Department to take into serious consideration our oft repeated request that something be done early in Northern British Columbia and the Yukon about the erection of a Catholic Boarding School and Preventorium for the destitute and orphan Indian children of that area whose number is daily increasing owing to the high mortality rate of the parents.

You may admire our patience and perseverance over these twenty years of begging and knocking at the door of the Government for the sake of its most derelict wards; but, for our part, I must admit that we feel rather scandalized at the attitude of indifference, not to say of utter callousness, assumed by the responsible officials of the Government in regard to the treatment of those entrusted to their care.

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Residential School at Teslin

I beg to call your attention to the fact that for the past few years I have time and again, directly and through Father O. Plourde, pointed out to the various Officials of the Branch the necessity of having a Catholic Residential School at Teslin, Y.T., for the children of Catholic Indians of the Yukon and Northern B.C. whose life is essentially nomadic, and especially for the benefit of orphan and underprivileged Indian children.

Allow me to insist again on the urgency of a solution to be given to this request on the part of the Branch in view of the following data:

A. My Diocese or Vicariate Apostolic, covering the whole of the Yukon, and the Northern portion of B.C. located along the Alaska Highway and known as the Telegraph Creek, and Fort Nelson and the Atlin Districts, has a Catholic Indian population of well over 900 Indians, viz:

- In the Yukon Agency ............... approx. 300
- In the Ft. Simpson Agency .......... 135
- Ft. Nelson Slaves ................. 90
- Ft. Nelson Sekanals ............... 45
- In the Stikine Agency .............. 470
- Total: 905

B. We have in the diocese Five Seasonal Day Schools in which approximately 75 children attend school, viz:
- In the Yukon: Teslin and Burwash Landing
- In the Stikine Agency: Klappan, Dease Lake and Lower Post
- In the Fort Simpson Agency (Fort Nelson district): none

C. - The two nearest Boarding Schools are:
- In Lejac, Central B.C., located at least 1000 miles from the nearest Indian Band of my diocese.
- In Fort Providence, N.W.T., located at least 500 miles from the nearest Indian Band, viz: that of Fort Nelson.

N.B.-Those two Boarding Schools are 2100 miles apart from each other by the nearest means of communication.

We have no children in the Boarding School of Fort Providence on account of the difficulties of communication.

We have 27 Orphan or Destitute children in the Lejac School, sent for an indefinite period of time by the authority of Agent Sampson, following the epidemics which have worked havoc among the Indians of the Stikine Agency these past few years. Therefore, altogether, hardly 102 Catholic Indian Children of my diocese have an opportunity of attending any school.
D. I must, moreover, call your attention to a strange situation arising in Carcross, where, owing to the presence of an Anglican Boarding School in the vicinity, five of our Catholic Indian Children have been induced to attend the Anglican School, because there were no school facilities of any kind for them within hundreds of miles. The enclosed letter from the parents of some of those children shows to the evidence how reluctant the parents were to have their children admitted to such a school, against their own conscience. I hope that said children have been duly registered as Catholics on the school roll, and I would request the Branch to make a thorough investigation into the matter.

The other Catholic families of Carcross have begged me time and again to petition the Government for a boarding school of their own faith in the Yukon, being reluctant to have their children sent over 1000 miles away from them to Lejac for their education. Meanwhile, they prefer to see their children deprived of schooling rather than have them enrolled in the local Anglican Boarding School.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have been asked by His Excellency Bishop J. Coderre, O.M.I. of White Horse Y.T., to formally present to your Department his request for a Residential School to be located to Teslin. In support to his plea, I beg to submit the following facts:

a) His Diocese or Vicariate covers the whole of the Yukon and the Northern portion of B.C. located along the Alaska Highway and known as the Telegraph Creek, fort Nelson and the Atlin Districts, has a Catholic population of well over 900 Indians as follows:

In the Yukon Agency........305
In the Ft. Simpson Agency..135
In the Stikine Agency......470
Total:.....................910

b) There are, at the present time, in the above territory five seasonal Day Schools in which approximately 75 children receive instruction, viz:

In the Yukon: Teslin and Burwash Landing
In the Stikine Agency: Klappan, Dease Lake and Lower Post.

c) The two nearest Residential Schools are at Lejac, Central B.C., which is at least one thousand miles from the nearest Indian Band of his Diocese, and at Grouard, Alta, located, at least, five hundred miles also from the nearest Indian Band,

2...
viz: that of Fort Nelson. I would add that these two Residential Schools are 1000 miles apart from each other by the nearest means of communication.

There are at the present time in this Vicariate, 43 children attending the two Residential Schools mentioned above; 27 are registered in the Lejac school and 16 at that of Grouard. I understand that all these children are orphans or belong to families who cannot take care of them. They were derelicts in the vast Yukon and Northern B.C. Areas and something had to be done to prevent them from dying of starvation or of being a social worry to the white population of his diocese. But their presence in those two schools is not a desirable thing for these children as they are too far away from the surroundings in which they expect to spend their lives after leaving school. Besides, transportation costs are so high that they cannot come back to the Reserve for vacation where they would at least have the chance to spend a couple of months with relatives or friends.

Furthermore, these orphans and derelict children attending those two schools are not the only children in this Diocese which need to be looked after and placed in a residential school. There are still others who should be placed in such institutions and which it is a duty of the Bishop to so place them.

I have given Teslin as the proper place for the erection of this school because it is conveniently located on the Alaska Highway, easy of access at any time of the year; it has a modern airport, Post Office and several local stores. It is also the most central place of the Diocese for such an institution. The most distant points where Catholic Indians are to be found are less than 500 miles from Teslin, such for instance as Fort Nelson in the extreme East, Telegraph Creek in the extreme South, Snag in the extreme West, and Mayo in the extreme North.

Moreover, we have in Teslin a well established mission, with two residing missionaries, a large residence for our staff, a modern building for class rooms and a spacious church. It is located on the lake shore where there is an abundant supply of water. The country abounds in fish and meat. We have plenty of room for the erection of the Boarding School on the mission property which comprises more than four acres of land already cleared for the purpose. My present purpose would be to erect a building large enough to house about 50 pupils and the staff of sisters in charge of the school. The mission Church or Chapel would serve as a school Chapel, the priests' residence would house the staff and the school building would provide the class rooms. I think that in this way we can accommodate the number of children asked for and who are so worthy of a home on account of their poverty and deriliction.

3.....
In granting this request of Bishop Coudert, I might point out that the Department would not be put to any special expenditure in the payment of grants as 43 of the children who would be received into this school are already attending such institutions. With costs of material as high, it stands to reason that the Bishop is right in expecting some contribution from your Department for the erection of this building.

Hoping that you will give this matter your serious consideration and thanking you for the support which you will give it, I remain,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

MEMORANDUM:

- THE DEPUTY MINISTER -

Re: Establishment of an Indian Residential School - Teslin, Y.T.

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter relating to the above noted subject received by me from the Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

The desirability of establishing a Residential School in the Teslin district has been reviewed on more than one occasion during the last three or four-year period, and Bishop Coudert, who visited Ottawa a few weeks ago, discussed the matter with me rather fully at that time. It would appear that the claims of Bishop Coudert for Residential School accommodation in his diocese will have to be very carefully and sympathetically reviewed at an early date. The cost of sending orphans and neglected Indian children to Lejac or Grouard is likely to prove almost prohibitive. This, in my judgment, is a district in which we should have a thorough educational survey at the earliest possible date. You may remember that Inspector Coleman, who visited this district about three years ago, was very critical in his report of the instruction provided at Indian Day Schools, particularly schools operating on a seasonal basis.

The figures submitted by Bishop Coudert appear to be very conservative. The census report now in course of preparation shows a Catholic Indian population in the Yukon Agency of 307; at Fort Simpson, of 803; and in the Stikine Agency, 457, making a total of 1567. In view of all the circumstances,

....may I recommend
may I recommend that the Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia be asked immediately following his appointment to undertake an educational survey of this district. In this survey, the Inspector might be accompanied by a man such as Mr. Anfield, who has had years of experience in the operation of a Residential School and a man who should have a thorough knowledge of the educational needs of Indians. If Indian Agent Anfield is not available, we might be able to secure the assistance and cooperation of the School Inspector about to be appointed by the N.W.T. Council. It is my understanding that this official will be appointed at an early date.

The location of the school is very important. If constructed, it should be, in my judgment, either fully fireproof or at least semi-fireproof. The cost of establishing such a school should be borne by the Government. The school should be equipped to meet not only the present needs of the Indians insofar as orphans and neglected children are concerned, but should as well be sufficiently large to meet such needs for a period of twenty or twenty-five years.
Ottawa, November 8, 1945.

Dear Mr.Hoey;

Re: Indian Residential School at Teslin Lake,Y.T.

I have a communication from Father O.Plourde O.M.I., our General Superintendent, advising me that through your kind intervention, the long pending question of an Indian Boarding School at Teslin Lake has been brought to the attention of the Minister.

I highly appreciate your great interest in this matter, which I consider as vital for the welfare of many of our Orphan and Destitute Indian Children of Northern British Columbia and the Yukon.

I understand from Father Plourde's communication that the Officials of the Department would be disposed not only to help us financing the project I had planned to be carried out on the actual Mission grounds located in the Teslin Village proper, but might even be willing to build the whole Institution entirely under their own responsibility, as has been done elsewhere.

It this was the case, may I suggest to the Department a still better location than the necessary restricted area we have presently in the Teslin village; I know that, as a rule, the Branch is anxious to have plenty of room around such an institution for farming developments or other experiments.

Seven miles from the Teslin Village, right along the Alaska Highway, there is an ideal location for an Indian Boarding School and plenty of arable land at Morley Bay, at the very mouth of Morley River. A good and abundant water supply could be obtained from the nearby river; large natural meadows could provide good fodder for several heads of cattle; easy fishing could be carried on at the mouth of Morley River, close to the Institution; and the soil would be more apt to be used for gardening farming than at Teslin Village proper.

Therefore, before giving a final approbation to the project, think it would be wise for the Department to investigate thoroughly this matter of the best location. I understand that Father Plourde intends to pay a visit shortly; no doubt you will be aware of his departure from Ottawa; may I suggest that you leave all the necessary instructions with him to obtain about Morley Bay all the added informations you may wish to have.

Yours sincerely in Christ

J.L.Coudert O.M.I., Bishop of Rhodiapolis
Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse

Dear Sir;

Referring to our conversation of last May and to my letter of June 22nd to the Director of the Branch regarding the urgent need of a Catholic Residential School in the Yukon or close to the Yukon border, I beg to call your attention to the fact that recently more and more catholic children are being admitted to the Anglican School of Carcross.

As I remarked to you recently such an abnormal situation will not be able to be remedied unless the Government grants to our Catholic Indians the Residential School they are entitled to in the Yukon.

I already sent you a written statement from Mrs. Billy Johnson (Martha Sam) protesting against the fact that she is obliged to send her children to the Anglican School of Carcross, but she had no alternative and under the present circumstances I had to allow her to do so against all church regulations; this is the case also for the children of Bill Hall, those of Dick Bean Charley and several others, who have begged me times and again, for the past five years, to open up a Boarding School for Catholic Indian Children in the Yukon and Northern B.C.

Hoping that the above information will prove valuable to the Officials of the Branch and convince them of the urgency of our request for an Indian Boarding School in or near Teslin,

I remain,

Memorandum for File:

Proposed Indian Residential School, (R.C.) Teslin Lake

The following points were raised by Bishop Coudert and Father Plourde with Mr. Hoey and myself at a meeting held in my office on October 25, 1946:

A. The Bishop has selected a tentative site for the school and pointed out the following factors as advantages in favour of his location:

(1) It is 1/2 mile to the north of the Airport at Teslin Lake.

(2) Abundant water should be available from nearby streams.

(3) The Alaska Highway goes right by this site.

(4) It is 1½ miles from the Indian village at Teslin.

(5) There is a bus along the highway either two or three times a week, depending upon the season of the year.

(6) It is 110 miles south of Whitehorse and 450 miles north of Fort Nelson, thus placing it in a strategic position for the admission of pupils from the entire area of his Diocese.

(7) An area estimated at 640 acres would be required and this should be readily obtainable at this site.

(8) There is plenty of wood available for fuel purposes.

B. The following decisions were reached:

(1) That a start be made towards the establishment of a residential school in this area.
(2) That a survey be made as soon as weather conditions in the Spring permit by Mr. Clark and Mr. McKinnon (It was later suggested by the Director that the Bishop nominate a Brother of the Oblate Order who had considerable building experience in the North to assist these two in the survey.)

(3) That the Crown Assets Allocation Committee and the War Assets Corporation be approached to ascertain the availability of surplus building materials and Army Camps along the Alaska Highway in the general area of this site.

(4) That a start be made on this school even on a small scale of some 30 or 40 students.

(5) That the North West Territories Bureau be approached to ascertain the availability of the required acreage in the vicinity of Teslin.

C. The Bishop had previously interviewed Mr. Jackson and it is understood that he concurs in the general proposal for the establishment of a residential school in the Bishop's Diocese and that the Welfare and Training Service is required to work out the necessary details for the fulfillment of the above proposals.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Destitute and Neglected Indian Children to be admitted in the "Pius the Tenth School" in Skagway Alaska.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I hear that in the near future you may receive a request either from Agent Samson of the Stikine Agency or from Agent Meek of the Whitehorse Agency concerning the admission of some neglected children into a Catholic Boarding School.

The two cases I am referring to are those of:
1. Lucy Ward's illegitimate and neglected children of Atlin, B.C.
2. Dick Beans' legitimate but neglected children of Whitehorse, Y.T.

In both cases the parents have proved seriously negligent in the moral upbringing of their children.

Following the recent conversation I had both with Mr. Kinleyside and with Mr. Hoey, I understand that the Department does not seem to have any objection to having said children admitted into the Pius Xth Boarding School for Native Children, located in Skagway, Alaska, under the very efficient care of Rev. Father Gallant and the Sisters of St. Ann; it is an independent Institution, conveniently located within 110 miles from Atlin or from Whitehorse with easy access through the White Pass Railways—I have already discussed this matter with Father Gallant last September, and received from him the assurance that our children would be welcome into his school for $300.00 Canadian Dollars a year.

Pending the time the proposed boarding school may be ready for operation in Teslin, I think that the above solution would prove far more satisfactory both to the Department and to the interested parties than having the children sent out either to Lejac or to Grouard, more than a thousand miles away from their country and people.

Hoping, therefore, that the Branch will see its way clear to act according to the way suggested above until the proposed school in Teslin be in operation, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Bishop J.L. Coudert O.M.I., Vic.Ap.of Whitehorse
