Reference complaint of Bishop Coudert, Whitehorse, contained in your letter of 2nd ultimo, file 166-15-1 (VT 1) concerning Lucy Ward's Children, Atlin, B.C. This settlement being in the Stikine Agency, I communicated the complaint to Indian Agent R.H.S. Sampson.

Second complaint of Bishop Coudert concerned neglected children of Dick Bean Charlie, Whitehorse, Y.T. Mr. and Mrs. Dick Bean Charlie are notorious characters here, both being alcoholics of the poorest types, though Dick has the reputation of being one of the best hunters in the area when sober.

After consultation with the N.C.O. 1/c R.C.M.P. here, it was decided that a joint charge of Failing to Provide the Necessaries of Life to Minor Children (Sec. 242, subsec. 3 (b) C.C.C.), be laid, the R.C.M.P. prosecuting. This was subsequently done and on December 17th were tried before Magistrate J.A. Simons. Witnesses for prosecution included Dr. F.B. Roth, Miss M. Hackett P.H.N., and the undersigned. Accused were found guilty as charged and entered into Recognizance for Suspended Sentence as per Sec. 1081 C.C.C.

A difficult situation arose in connection with the care of the children. Mr. and Mrs. Charlie are members of the Church of England, some of the children are baptized Roman Catholic though without the consent of the father, and the children regularly attend the Mission Day School of Rev. H.I. Lee. It was agreed amongst all interested parties including attending ministers that the father be asked his wish as to his children. He stated he wished them to continue living at the Rev. Lee's school, where they are now being well looked after. This was agreed to by the presiding magistrate.

Margaret Charlie, age 12, Jackie age 10, Nancy age 9 attend Whitehorse Indian Day School and are maintained by Rev. Lee. Rose age 3 lives with her brothers and sisters at the school but does not attend classes. Annie age 18 months is presently
a patient at the Whitehorse General Hospital and enquiries are now being made for a suitable foster home - a rather difficult task owing to the poor reputation the Charlies have with the other Indians.

Terms of Recognizance state that Mr. and Mrs. Dick Bean Charlie are on probation for the term of one year; the inference being that the children will be returned to their parents at the end of that time if in the best interests of all concerned.

In the meantime four children are being maintained by Rev. Lee. In the ordinary course of events it might have been possible to place these neglected children with foster parents at moderate expense. I would therefor suggest that Rev. Lee be compensated for actual expense of maintaining the four above mentioned Charley children. I might add that a nephew of the Charlies, Donald Miller age 6 is also being now maintained at the Whitehorse Indian School, though the Charlies draw Family Allowance in his support; he being an orphan.

May I please be advised as to what reimbursement Rev. Lee should be granted for the four children he is maintaining.

R.J. Meek

G. H. Gooderham, Esq., Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

Reference to your letter, file 143-6-3 of the 3rd instant, in connection with the possible acquisition of a number of Army buildings now being disposed of along the Alaska Highway by War Assets Corporation.

I have inspected a number of Camps between mileposts 56 and 300 and have found that the one at Milepost 147 is the only one wholly suitable to the needs of the Indians of this Agency.

It consists of one Butler Hut 48' x 20'; one large Garage and Repair Shop built of native lumber; three huts 120' x 20' with meat cooler and pantry and two National Prefabricated Huts 48' x 20'. Milepost 147, also known as Beaton River, has been the site of an Indian Camp for several generations back and Indians continue to make use of it as it is in the center of a good hunting and trapping territory. It is also a junction of the Beaton and Halfway Rivers Indian trails and several Indian families of the Hudson Hope Band are in continuous residence there. For this reason I would recommend that the following buildings of this Camp be acquired:

One Butler Metal Hut,
One Garage and Repair Shop,
Three huts 120' x 20' w/meat cooler and pantry,
All the outbuildings therefor.

The two National Prefabricated Huts have been excluded because they are unsuitable to Indians, also because the District Sales Branch of War Assets Corporation have made previous commitments towards their disposal.

I will add that the Department has already moved towards the acquisition of these buildings and wish you to refer to the latter dated March 8th last, file 21-143, written by Mr. J. E. Morris of Welfare Division, advising that an application had been made to the Chairman of the Crown Assets Committee requesting that these buildings be turned over to us when no longer required.

Besides the above, I have visited the following Camps, inspecting each building:

Milepost 143: Okes Construction Co's Camp.- Eighteen buildings, six of which are large panel type huts and two buildings, 80 feet long or more, of native lumber. The remainder are smaller buildings, most of them of the panel-type. I list this camp as an alternative to the one of Milepost 147 hereabove mentioned in the event that the latter could not be obtained.
Milepost 136: M.H. & K.C.B. - Fifteen buildings, of which four are National Prefabricated Huts, one log Recreation Hall, five large buildings of lumber. The remainder are smaller buildings of frame construction. Disadvantageous location due to absence of water in the vicinity. Purchase not recommended.

Milepost 209: Art. Bolier's Camp. - Nineteen buildings and six outbuildings, all of native lumber. Indian trail to headwaters of the Muskwa River at Mile 210.7, a campsite for roving Indians. There appears to be no object in acquiring this camp as it would not be possible to make use of it before three or four years at the earliest.

Other camps visited were at Mileposts 56, 60, 92, 97, 101, 117, 118, 176, 191, 224, 229, Vogt's Saw Mill and 271. They have been found to be so situated as to be useless for the Department's purposes in this Agency.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Acting Indian Agent.

Further to our conversation of recent date and
in answer to the reports submitted by Mr. Indian Agent Calibois,
of Fort St. John, on October 8 and October 24, I wrote to the
Crown Assets Allocation Committee requesting that we be in-
formed of any buildings which are declared surplus along the
highway. Our aim in obtaining these buildings is, as you know,
to use the materials in them for the proposed Residential
School to be constructed at Teslin Lake.

Assets Allocation Committee, which reads in part as follows:-

recorded the requirements of your Department for allocation
of all Camps along the Alaska Highway and Haines Road, in
accordance with a request from your Acting Deputy Minister,
dated August 24th, 1946. This Committee has received no
further reports of surplus covering any of these Camps since
recording your request but if, as and when further reports of
surplus are received, your request will receive due consider-
ation."

It is now my intention to approach the Royal
Canadian Engineers with a view to finding out if they are about
to declare any other buildings along the highway surplus to their requirements.

For your information I might add that the Crown Assets Allocation Committee is that part of the War Assets Corporation which deals with transfers of property from the Department of National Defence to the various other government departments. When materials are obtained from the Crown Assets Allocation Committee, there is no charge made for them as the transaction is carried out by a Crown transfer. However, if we have not declared our intention to the Crown Assets Allocation Committee, the buildings are then passed over to the War Assets Corporation, which will sell them to the various bidders. The Department is considering the erection
of a residential school near Teslin Lake, Yukon Territory.
During his recent visit to Ottawa, Bishop Coudert discussed
this matter fully with the Director and other officials of
the Department.

It is hoped to start on this project on
a small scale. Therefore we have been making enquiries as
to the availability of construction materials from the old
army and contractors' camps along the Alaska Highway. It is
our intention to use this material in the construction of a
small residential school. Then, when building materials are
more readily available, it is hoped to construct a larger
school plant.

Medland of the Head Office of the Department, and he advises
that Mr. F. H. Jackson, of the Department of Mines and Re-
sources at Whitehorse, is wholly acquainted with the avail-
ability of the army camps along the highway. Therefore it
would be appreciated if you could see him and ascertain the
availability of camps in the neighbourhood of Teslin, which
could be moved for our purpose.

Re: Building Material along the Alaska Highway for proposed School at Teslin, Y.T.

Dear Mr. Neery:

I found your letter of Nov. 21 at my headquarters here a few days ago, and contacted immediately the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. Meek. I also contacted Agent Galibois of Fort Saint John, and visited the Airport Commanding Officer, on my way through Teslin.

As a result of those various inquiries, here are some practical suggestions.

1. Location of the proposed School. - Neither Morley Bay nor Johnson Crossing appear to be a suitable location for the School, as being too far away from any settlement, badly exposed to the wind, and lacking water supply facilities.

The best location is the one I indicated to the Branch, viz., immediately west of the Airport area, on both sides of the creek, and on both sides of the Highway, from the foot of the Mountain Range to the Lake shore. That particular location will not be interfering in any way with the airport.

2. The surrounding camps located along the Highway do not have any longer a single building which could be used as such for our purpose; the best buildings have already been sold, or moved or appropriated by other concerns within sixty miles of the area.

There is, however, plenty of building material still available under the form of abandoned smaller buildings, or warehouses or repair shops. If such buildings were torn apart and dismantled, a good amount of building material could be obtained from them, and moved by trucks to the proper location.

3. The Commanding Officer at the Teslin Airport is of the opinion that their actual Electric Power at the Airport is far too big for the present demands of the Airport, and is of the opinion that the surplus electric power of the Airport would be amply sufficient to look after the needs of the school.

4. The Airport has also its own water supply directly from the
lake shore, and such a supply could be extended to the proposed school, though personally I think that we could just as easily and more securely obtain our water from the shore line lying in front of the school property. The creek running through the property freezes solid at times during severe winters, but probably water could be also obtained from it along its banks through siphon. At any rate such a creek would be most beneficial for irrigation purposes during the summer.

As a result of the above informations, I would suggest:

1.-That the Branch make definite arrangements with the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch for the setting apart of the above mentioned Land; and that a Survey of the same be arranged without delay with the Surveyor General for the earliest part of next Summer.

2.-That the Branch already make plans for the kind of buildings to be erected, so that the local Agent may know exactly the kind of building material will be required.

N.B.-Most of the frame material could still be obtained locally, if action is taken promptly.

3.-That the Branch contact the R.C.A.F. in Ottawa regarding the extension of their electric power, or even their water power, from the Teslin Airport to the proposed School.

I had a tough trip along the Highway; on the first day we broke two cars, the Indian Agency's car and the Mission Car; we found Prophet School well started and doing well. I had to travel from Watson Lake to Whitehorse in a car without heater and the windows open, with a temperature of -46°. So the Yukon is still the Yukon.

Thanking you for your marked interest in our work,

I am

Yours devotedly in Christ

J.L. Coudert O.M.I.Vic.Ap.of Whitehorse
Proposed Residential School at Teslin, Yukon Territory.

Re your letters on the subject of Nov. 8th and Nov. 20th, file 166-15-1 (W.T.). On Nov. 20th, in company with F.H.R. Jackson, Lands Parks and Forests Branch, I proceeded to Teslin, stopping off enroute at Johnson's Crossing. This camp is situated on a very high bank above the river, and no water is available. This fact, coupled with several other factors renders Johnson's Crossing as unsuitable for school purposes.

One large building was noted which would be suitable for salvaging much material. We continued along the Alaska Highway down to Watson Lake, Y.T., some 300 miles eastward. Johnson's Crossing is the closest camp to Teslin, and from our observations of the other camps, contains the best building material.

It was understood the R.C.A.F. had received the buildings at Johnson's Crossing from the Army, and Wing Commander Buchan, O.C. Whitehorse Airport was interviewed, but in recent months the Department of Transport had acquired the greater number of buildings at the Crossing.

Leslie Keith, Sr. Asst. Airway Engineer, Whitehorse was next seen, and at my request he submitted a request to his superior H.P. Keith, Dist. Airway Engineer, Edmonton, Alta., at the same time not holding much hope for our acquiring the building. I have now been verbally informed that his department looks favorably upon the idea of turning over a large Mess Hall at Johnson's Crossing for use as a school at Teslin. I am not in receipt of official word at this writing.

Today I have interviewed Bishop Goudert who has recently returned from Ottawa. It is his opinion, shared by myself and F.H.R. Jackson, that a point of land about three miles from Teslin Village, and not far from the western end of the R.C.A.F. runway of Teslin Airport, would be the best place for the proposed school. There is a fair-sized creek, open ground for the school site, and lake frontage. It has advantages over all other proposed sites.
Having seen practically every abandoned Army camp between Whitehorse and Watson Lake, it appears that many of the camps are wholly unsuited for salvage purposes. A great deal of pilfering has gone on since the abandonment of the camps, and too much faith cannot be put on the inventories of camps.

I have an inventory of an abandoned camp, mile 937, and another for abandoned camp at mile 946.6. Mr. Jackson advises that both of these camps are on the opposite side of Whitehorse from Teslin. It would mean hauling salvaged lumber some 60 or 70 miles. We did not therefore examine these camps. However in view of present conditions, I shall take up the matter further with Mr. Jackson as it may be found more economical to haul suitable lumber the greater distance than to use unsuited material.

I shall inform Bishop Goudert of any further developments in this connection.

R.J. Meek

March 8, 1947

Re: Indian Boarding School in Teslin

Dear Mr. Neary;

I have your communication of February 22 and wish to thank you for the information contained therein regarding the proposed School at Teslin.

Indian Agent Meek has kept me informed re the acquisition of a certain number of buildings along the Alaska Highway; naturally, at this stage, most of those buildings are not in very good condition, but a good quantity of building material will be available from them.

1.-Re Water Supply. On two different occasions I have sent a party to take soundings on Fox Creek flowing through the location I have suggested to the Branch as the most suitable site for the proposed School; and I have taken all available information regarding the said Creek by consulting the local Indians and White Trappers or Prospectors of the area.

All agreed that Fox Creek, being a large creek flowing from a distance of some fifteen miles and draining thro' different branches, part of a considerable Mountain Range, should normally provide plenty of water for the needs of the school.

The Indians, however, told me that on some very severe winters the creek has frozen to the very bottom for a while. As our winter has been one of the most severe, I decided to have soundings made immediately after the cold wave we had in February.

The soundings revealed that the creek was frozen, indeed, to the very bottom with four feet of ice; this finding has shown clearly that Fox Creek is not a small spring but a real creek, since it had as much as four feet of ice in the winter; and tho' the findings did not appear very encouraging for a year like this one, all those whom I consulted agreed that a well, dug deep enough along its bank, would certainly provide enough water by seepage to supply the school at any time.

As this conclusion, however, may not be entirely satisfactory to you in view of the findings, I may assure you, on the other hand, that another absolutely sure supply of water may be obtained directly from Teslin Lake. The school property is to run, indeed, along the lake, and Teslin Lake is one of the largest Lakes of the North, several hundred feet deep, with a considerable current, and draining the glacier water of a large area of the Coast Range; the water of Teslin Lake is never muddy but crystal clear and should be of the purest. Actually the R.C.A.F. detachment on the Teslin Airport pumps water from the lake shore.

Pumping water from the lake will evidently entail a greater expense than getting it by gravity from Fox Creek, but the supply could never fail.
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

In order to reduce the cost of installation and pumping with such a water system, the best thing would be to build the school as close to the lake as possible, on the most suitable location. What made the installation of the water system at the Teslin Airport so expensive was due to the various experiments they made in foraging and finally in laying the main from the lake shore on a distance of well over a mile.

As a practical conclusion, my suggestion is that the best solution for the water supply at the Teslin Boarding School would be to install an alternate system whereby the water could be obtained both by gravity from Fox Creek, and by pumping from the Lake, in case the supply from the creek would fail.

2.-Re Land and Location.-If the Land Branch objects to give you too much frontage on the Alaska Highway, it would be enough to apply for an outlet of a few hundred feet on the Highway, and then get the rest of the land from the restricted area to the Lake shore; another quarter section might be applied for on the east side of the Highway, also beyond the restricted area in a heavily timbered location.

In regard to the exact location of the land and the spot on which the school should be erected, it is quite hard at this time to determine it, on account of the heavy snow covering the ground. The month of May would seem to be the most suitable time for looking over the whole ground thoroughly.

3.-Re Mr. Clark's Visit.-I beg to say that Indian Agent Meek has not yet received the letter in which you asked him to indicate to you the earliest appropriate date when your Educational Surveys Officer (Mr. Clark) should proceed to Teslin. After discussing this matter with Mr. Meek yesterday, in view of the conditions stated above, we have both come to the conclusion that the most appropriate time for Mr. Clark's visit should be in the early part of May. I may add that at that time, I expect to be in Whitehorse and could easily accompany your Officials to Teslin.

Indian Agent Meek is eagerly looking forward to Mr. Clark's visit to determine the exact location of the school, the extent of the land, the kind of work to be carried on this summer and the plans for the building which the Branch has in mind with the amount of money available.

Hoping that the above informations will be of some help to you, and thanking you for your marked interest in the educational welfare of our northern Indians, I remain,

Yours sincerely in Christ

Bishop J.L. Coudert O.M.I.
Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse

Your letter of 20th ultimo, file 166-164 (W.T. 8), re Residential School, Teslin, with copy of letter to Right Rev. J.L. Coucrt, O.M.I., Whitehorse.

I have recently visited Bishop Coucrt in this connection, and we feel that the most appropriate time for Mr. Clark, Educational Surveys Officer, to visit this area in connection with the proposed Residential School, would be in May, and preferably during the first half of the month. By that time the snow should have melted, and the roads should be in good condition.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS & ENGINEERING BRANCH

Proposed Residential School at Teslin Lake

For many years we have realized the necessity of establishing another residential school in the Yukon. By selecting the area around Teslin, we have felt that we could also accommodate the children in northern Alberta and in northern British Columbia, who at present have no educational facilities of any kind.

We have sent Major C. A. Clark, our Educational Survey Officer, into Whitehorse to proceed with Mr. Indian Agent Meek and Bishop Couder to the proposed site of this school.

We have received from Major Clark a telegram which reads in part as follows:

"Best site for Teslin School is between highway and lake at Mile eight zero, seven three miles west from village and near enough to airport to draw electricity but not airport water -stop- First job should be demolition of acquired buildings and assembling lumber near site -stop- Competitive bids not likely obtainable -stop- Experienced man named Robert T. Forsild available in about two weeks and must know your decision soon otherwise will work elsewhere and we would have task of finding another man while buildings continue to deteriorate -stop- Forsild would require periodic advances of money to cover disbursements during demolition."

I understand that our Superintendent of Welfare and Training has already phoned Mr. Founder concerning this proposed

-- site
site. It would be appreciated if you could have Mr. McIougald, your Engineer at Whitehorse, Y. T., proceed with Mr. Indian Agent Meek to Teslin as soon as possible. Once a favourable report is received from him, we can then engage Mr. Forsild to move to Teslin those array buildings which we have acquired along the Alaska highway within the last six months. The present price of lumber is $115.00 per thousand in this area. The camps which we now have contain some 40,000 feet of lumber. You can therefore appreciate our desire to have these camps moved to Teslin, where we can hire a watchman, rather than leave them in their present positions, where they would "deteriorate rapidly".

Director.

Dear Sir;

I am quite pleased with the visit of Major Clarke in connection with the educational survey concerning the proposed Boarding School at Teslin.

Following such a visit, I am sure that you expect on my part a report summarizing my viewpoint:

1. Regarding the Location.-Major Clarke has agreed with me that, considering the general aspect of the country and the kind of soil prevailing throughout the central portion of the Territory, the proposed site is about the best which could be found, though not an ideal one for cultivation.

a. It is conveniently located near the Northwest corner of the local airfield, wherefrom electric power and fire fighting equipment can be easily obtained.-It is hardly two miles from the Teslin village where many conveniences can be found, and man power easily obtained.

b. The property has natural limits, with a gravel pit in the East; the lake shore in the South; Fox Creek in the West; and the Alaska Highway in the North.-It is very nicely exposed, facing the lake and the South, which position will provide plenty of light and sunshine to the buildings, which I consider as very important in a country where the winters are so long and so dark.-It is sheltered from the North and Northwest cold winds by rather heavy timber and a mountain range.

c. Along the bank of Fox Creek, which is running on the western limit of the property, there seems to be some fairly good soil somewhat swampy, but which could easily be drained and turned into a vegetable garden, where, in my estimation, most of the vegetables needed for the school could be grown.-Within eight or ten miles of the property, there is, between the mouth of the Misutlin River and Morley Bay, some low land with marshes and natural meadows, which at a later date may be more thoroughly explored and worked up, when the school develops so as to provide fodder for a few heads of cattle; the said low land is within easy reach of the Alaska Highway.

d. In regard to the water supply, I am of the opinion that it would be much safer to get directly from Teslin Lake, after the experience we had with Fox Creek last winter, which froze solid to the
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

very bottom until recently—we have located a very appropriate site for the proposed buildings, just above the highwater mark of the lake and within 200 feet of the low water mark; at a point south east of said location, the lake is very deep, and would provide a water of the purest type; the water is crystal clear and comes from the many creeks and glaciers of the surrounding mountain ranges; moreover the lake itself is more a river than a lake with quite a current.

My suggestion is that you should first try to dig a well right on the proposed site of the school, which work could be done with local native labor at a very small cost; so close to the lake, you may get good sippage thro' the gravel; if, by chance, clay is encountered and the water obtained unfit for general purposes, then a trench of eight feet deep can be dug right down to the lake shore, on a distance of some 200 feet, assuring to the school a permanent flow of water, which cannot possibly fail.—Of course a tank should be provided in or close to the building.

c.—For recreational purposes, a part of the property is heavily wooded and can be turned into a fine park; another part is made up of a level gravel bench very suitable for a playground; moreover, the north-western portion of the property is sloping down gently to a sand beach, near the mouth of Fox Creek, and affords an ideal summer resort for bathing and boating, with a little bay well sheltered from the prevailing winds.

f.—Finally, the mouth of Fox Creek and most of the surrounding bays are teeming with the best fish, trout and white fish at all times, and salmon in the fall of the year.—If, through a special permit, the local Indians are allowed to sell us some wild meat, I may add that the region is rich in game, especially in moose, and we should have no trouble in getting such a meat from the natives.

2.—Regarding the Building Proper.—The building to be erected should be able to accommodate not less than 30 children from the start, and if possible 50.—You may judge of the amount of children who might benefit from the boarding school by looking over the enclosed copy of our Catholic Indian children now frequenting our day schools, or boarding in Grouard and in Leflar.

I would insist on having a full size basement under each building; though, you should avoid digging more than two feet in the ground, so as to have full size windows in said basement, and so as to keep on the coarse and dry gravel bed, and away from moisture or dampness which cause the foundations to freeze and heave and crack.

The main central building could have in the basement the kitchen and accessories; the dining rooms; and the laundry and store rooms. On the main floor, two class rooms, a chapel, a little dispensary, the parlors, and the quarters for the staff.

The side buildings should not be too far apart from the central building, or even could be connected with it by corridors, which should be well insulated in case of fire.—One of said buildings would used for
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

the boys, and the other for the girls. In each building, the basement should be utilized as a recreation room with spare rooms for casual training. The main floor would have the dormitory, a large clothes room, and private quarters for the guardian, with the necessary accommodations for toilets and showers.

As a practical conclusion for the present,

1.-I kindly ask you to give to the local Indian Agent the necessary authority to start immediately with some activities, while the weather is so favorable and Mr. Forsild is available; Mr. Forsild is, indeed, a very reliable and quite a capable foreman, willing to work for the Department at a reasonable price. Under his direction much work could already be done, no matter what the plans may be for the approved structure, viz., he can have the site cleared and prepared; the buildings already acquired, or to be shortly acquired from the War Asset Corporation, can be dismantled and moved to the site; an electric line can be extended from the airport so as to use the power during the construction process; hangar or store room must be immediately erected near the building site to put the perishable material, tools etc., etc., in a safe place sheltered from the weather and from depredation; and finally a well can be dug to ascertain, as stated above, the possibility of having the water supply right under the building.

N.B.-All that work can be done by Mr. Forsild with local labor, white or Indian, before the final blue prints are approved.

2.-I would like you to send a blue print copy of your plans, as soon as available, to the Very Reverend Mother Berenice Superior General Providence Mother House 3011 St. Catherine East Montreal, P.Q.

In order to ask for her suggestions, as it is very likely that her sisters will accept to come and work in the new Institution, and I would like, as much as possible, to meet their wishes.

I would appreciate also receiving a copy of the same blue prints for my own information.

I am sure that Major Clarke will give you, with many more detailed informations, all the additional data you wish to have on the subject. After the thorough investigation he made of the whole problem, I entirely rely on his knowledge of the situation and his good judgment for whatever suggestion he may have to make over and above what I am sending you here.

Yours very sincerely in Christ

School repairs in various areas, probably all, are now being discussed. The catch is that inspectors and agents do not seem to be able to tell principals and teachers what can or cannot be done during the vacation. Too often the question is not settled until late in the vacation and holidays are extended or the school disturbed while a rush job is done. Couldn't we initiate proceedings a little earlier in the school year—preferably before Christmas—to determine what should be done, provide for it in the estimates and let the field men know in May so that they can get on with it?

I hope I don't again arrive at one of our agencies to find the agent thrown with all the keys to whatever vehicles the Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Affairs Branch, happens to possess. Maybe a circular letter should go out reminding the gentry that it is desired to use existing equipment at full potential rather than to compel the hire of taxis or quadrupeds.

Yours sincerely,

Charles Fordyce Clark

Re: Proposed Indian Industrial School.
Teslin, Y.T.

Mr. Meek Indian Agent at Whitehorse was obliged to leave on a nine day trip with the Doctor in connection with Indian Affairs, about the time I had an opportunity of going over this proposed Site for an Industrial School. Will try and arrange to visit this Site with him early next week. In the meantime would like to suggest that the Salvaging of lumber from purchased buildings could be started at any time.

This Area of approximately seven acres bordering Fox Creek to the East and facing on Teslin Lake is I think, about the best building Site in proximity to Teslin.

Timber Growth
This area was burnt over some years ago and there is some dead timber lying over the surface. The second growth Poplar is small and fairly dense, in places but very little under brush over the entire acreage and some widely spaced very attractive looking Spruce and Pine trees (which apparently came through the fire) between the 15 and 20 foot contours. Should this location be finally decided on, care should be taken in clearing property in order to preserve some of the standing timber.

Soil
Sub soil gravel to depth of some seven feet, from exposed gravel excavations. Top soil fine, sandy, with light covering sandy clay. Would appear to have possibilities for vegetable growth from present covering of timber and grass, and is very similar to soil along Lake Superior, at the Japanese Camps, where we had some success growing vegetables by using a heavy coating of fertilizer and disk ing it into the sandy topsoil.

Water
Would suggest the most important features in connection with this Site, would be to try for water, some place close to this place shown as Clearing on Sketch. Mr. Meek mentioned using water from Teslin Lake, but would draw attention to the fact that when the Lake level lowers, the water line recedes to a considerable distance out on the shallow shore line on this lake, and might prove an expensive operation, especially during the winter months. This Creek flows during some winters, but from information available it sometimes freezes and would be rather questionable as a steady water supply for a school.

Electric Power
The Airport have been applying the Village of Teslin from their plant at 5¢ a kilowatt, but the Village has now been notified that this service is to be discontinued. Understand their plant at the Airport is not in the best of condition, and supply from this source would now appear to be very questionable.
Owing to the timber growth, and using a hand level, working back from lake level, these contours as shown, will not of course be too accurate but the general picture should be fairly close. Should you think it necessary I could hire a couple of men and cut the necessary lines for a more accurate description of this area, or better still, I think it would be advisable to have clearing completed first before definitely deciding on the proper building site for a school.

Am fairly certain this is the best available site for an Industrial School - but I think the sinking of a well for water supply should be given first consideration.

(Sgd) A.R. McDougall.

T.S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering and Construction Service,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Indian Agent

Re Teslin Residential School

I beg to advise that on August 14th I proceeded to the proposed site of Indian Residential School at Teslin in company with A. MacDougall, Surveys and Engineering Branch, Whitehorse. The ground in the vicinity of the proposed site of the school was looked over very carefully by Mr. MacDougall, accompanied by myself. Several suggestions and recommendations were made by Mr. MacDougall, mainly with a view to drainage and water supply. His findings will no doubt be the subject of a report to his Branch.

All of the material from Mess Hall, Johnstons Crossing, was piled close to the proposed site. It will be accessible with ease regardless of the ultimate site chosen in that area. Mr. Forsild on his own initiative had hired a watchman who was camped on the site and was engaged in clearing brush. At the suggestion of Mr. MacDougall the watchman was instructed to dig a number of test holes at specified places.

A recent letter from Surveys and Engineering Branch to Mr. MacDougall expressed concern over the possibility of permafrost. It is generally considered that south of the Pelly River there is no permafrost; therefore no fear need be felt in this regard.

I would strongly recommend that material not be stored at Teslin, but be piled at proposed site. In this regard, estimate of $650.00 for moving material from proposed site to Teslin was excessive, as it was assumed all material was already at proposed site. Material from WAC 6 not moved as yet, and moving it three miles or 20 miles makes little difference, the cost being in loading and unloading the material. Arrangements are under way for storing electrical equipment and the two kitchen ranges with R.C.M.P. at Teslin. It will be possible to have an Indian on relief camp at proposed site at subsistence wage until the first snow.

Dear Sir:

In latter part of July before starting to move building material from Johnson Crossing to school site at Fox Creek Point, Teslin, I recommended the employment of a watchman to look after lumber etc., as it seemed almost impossible to keep road prowlers from stealing materials, even during process of wrecking buildings.

I twice caught such in act of removing materials at night at Johnsons Crossing. As you remember, you agreed to my point of view and promised to take up matter with your head office at Ottawa right away.

No word was received from you about the matter by August 3, and as my crew started hauling on Aug. 4, I, on my own initiative, employed Dick Morris of Teslin to move to Fox Point and remain at building site until further orders. As this required moving also his wife and two babies, and setting up a temporary tent & he demanded $7 per day, what I deemed reasonable, considering value of materials involved and high price of store supplies at Teslin Trading Post, (about 30% over Whitehorse prices).

As it was at that time believed construction work at Fox Creek Point would be commenced this season, the job was only to be temporary.

Later you informed me that the government had postponed construction till next spring and also considered $7.00 per day too high a pay for a watchman. As I explained to you then I only considered a watchman needed during the process of moving materials or eventually till construction started.

On August 30th the last load was hauled to site, and accordingly I told Morris that his service was not required any longer. Realizing that the man needed his pay first chance and seeing no other way, I paid him with a personal check on Canadian Bank of Commerce, Whitehorse, for $189.00.

This employment started on Aug. 4th and lasted to August 30 incl. 27 days at $7.00 per day - $189.00. During his stay at Fox Point Morris was instructed to clear away brush and windfalls around proposed building site, also Mr. McDougall, Surveys and Engineering Branch, Whitehorse, instructed him to try to dig prospect holes for water.

Yours respectfully,

(signed) Robert T. Forsild.

Re Teslin Indian Residential School. On July 26th telegram was sent by me requesting authority to obtain Indian as watchmen for material being stored on proposed site of school. On August 2nd I was asked for the cost of hiring a watchman and to which I replied on August 4th. I was not able to advise Mr. R.T. Forsild until Aug. 14th that hiring of a watchman was not authorized.

As moving material started on Aug. 4th, Forsild on his own initiative hired an Indian from Teslin at the rate of $7.00 per day. Standard rate of pay in the Yukon this summer has been $1.00 per hour, and I would not consider $7.00 per day excessive. On Aug. 14th I visited the site in company with A. MacDougall, Surveys and Engineering Branch, Whitehorse, who instructed Dick Morris to sink several holes in connection with water and sewerage problems.

Communications between this office and Mr. Forsild were none too good, and at times it was a couple of days before information could reach him. On the several occasions when I visited proposed school site I found Morris clearing brush.

I attach hereto letter from R.T. Forsild to myself concerning his actions in hiring this Indian as watchman. Forsild did not obtain a receipt from Dick Morris, but enclosed cancelled cheque which is attached hereto. Forsild contends that Morris was hired to protect government property, and considers the $189.00 in wages a proper charge to Indian Affairs Branch. I would recommend that Forsild's claim be given favorable consideration - at the least until he was advised by me on August 14th. A further point to consider is that Engineer MacDougall, as part of his recommendation re proposed school site, required certain test holes dug which would take a further three or four days.

MEMORANDUM TO MR. R.A. HOEY  
Director of Indian Affairs.

Re - Representations by Bishop Coderre of Whitehorse  
and Father Plourde

These two gentlemen called on me yesterday afternoon,  
and the points covered in our conversation can be summarized  
as follows:

(a) They are very anxious to have progress made with the  
Teslin School. They argue that if local contractors  
are not in a position to undertake this work, it should  
be given to a company from Vancouver, Calgary or Edmonton.

(b) They wish to have the Canol Road kept open as far as the  
Ross River (160 miles from Johnson's Crossing). They  
claim that this will be of great help in their missionary  
work, as well as being valuable from the standpoint of  
mining and transportation generally.

(c) They pointed out that the Indians at Watson Lake are  
in the Stikine Agency. It takes the agent from Telegraph  
Creek three or four days to go down to the coast, come  
up through Skagway and Carcross to Whitehorse and thus  
make his way to Watson Lake. They suggest that the  
Indians at Watson Lake could be much better taken care  
of if they are placed under Mr. Meek, who is stationed  
at Whitehorse.

(d) Many of the children in Whitehorse have no opportunity  
of going to a Catholic residential school except at Skagway  
(in United States territory). The Catholic school at the  
latter place will take these children at $300 each per  
annum, and the representatives of the church want to know  
whether we would approve of such an arrangement. The  
proposal is, of course, only for a temporary arrangement  
while awaiting the completion of the Teslin School. They  
pointed out that a number of Canadian half-breeds are  
already going to the Skagway school.
I said that I thought that there would be a good deal of difficulty in getting the Canadian Government to agree to pay for the education of Canadian Indians in an United States School. However, I should like to have your views on this matter.

(e) The Catholic Church wants to build a school at Yellowknife. In view of the fact that our new school there is large enough to take care of all the children in the area, it is my feeling that if the Catholic Church insists on putting up a school there, it should be prepared to defray all the costs in connection therewith. We can, of course, make arrangements for the church to give instruction after hours in the present school if they wish to do so. I do not, however, see any reason for our taking part in the construction of duplicate and unnecessary facilities.

(f) The church officials were very upset over delays that have taken place in purchasing articles for their schools in the west. They stated that after approval of the expenditure had been obtained it was often months before our Purchasing Department got around to obtaining the desired commodities. They would like to have the system re-arranged so that purchasing can be done in the areas in which the commodities are to be used. They stated that this was the case in previous years, and they would like to have it revived.

(g) They put in a word for Mr. John McIsaac, a road builder in the Yukon area who is anxious to get a contract in connection with the Atlin Road. They say that he has all the necessary equipment, is a responsible person of good character, and they would like to have him employed. I made no promise in this connection.

Will you please let me have your comments on these suggestions at your convenience.

H.L. KEENLEYSIDE
Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, October 20, 1947.

MEMORANDUM:

I have for acknowledgment your memorandum of October 15th, in which you summarize and submit for my consideration certain representations made to you by Bishop Coudert, of Whitehorse, Y.T., and Father Plourde.

I may state that somewhat similar representations were made to the officials of this branch by the Bishop and Father Plourde a few days ago. They were both assured by us that everything humanly possible would be done to expedite the construction of the school at Teslin Lake. They were also assured that the desirability of transferring the Watson Lake Indians to the care of Mr. Meek would be discussed very fully with Major MacKay in the immediate future.

I am not personally in favour of the enrolment of Indian pupils at the Skagway Residential School, Alaska, although such enrolment might have certain temporary advantages. It would be, in my judgment, a somewhat dangerous precedent and might result in demands from Indians residing temporarily in the United States for financial assistance from this department for the education of their children. I feel disposed to favour the immediate construction of the Teslin Lake school; thus making provision for the education of Indian children within the boundaries of our own country.

It is my opinion that the delays in securing the supplies to which Bishop Coudert and Father Plourde refer are due not so much to the work of our Purchasing Division, but rather to prevailing economic conditions.
conditions and the difficulty experienced by citizens generally in securing supplies promptly. This is a matter that can be given additional consideration.

The question of the construction of a school at Yellowknife is one that has already been reviewed by the Northwest Territories Council and will no doubt be reviewed again before a final decision is reached.

I am sending forward your memorandum to the Superintendent of Welfare and Training for his consideration.

Director.

Ottawa, October 28, 1947.

EX'D.

My dear Bishop Coudert:

May I refer to your interview with me on October 14th, during the course of which you submitted a number of proposals with respect to the education and general advancement of the Indian population in your diocese.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch have assured me that everything humanly possible will be done to expedite the construction of the school at Teslin Lake. We do not, however, consider that it would be satisfactory to have Indian children, residents of the Yukon Territory, enrolled at the Skagway Residential School. The officials here point out that a large number of Indians take up temporary residence in the United States from time to time and, while there, seek assistance from this department such as relief supplies, transportation costs and educational grants. It has not been our policy to grant these requests at any time, but should we sanction payment of residential school grants in Alaska, such action might lead to a renewal of requests for somewhat similar grants under circumstances which would render expenditures difficult to defend or justify. My own opinion is that in view of all the circumstances we should proceed as rapidly as possible with the construction of schools for the education and care of Indian children within the boundaries of our own country.

Your request that the Indians at Watson Lake in the Stikine Agency be placed under the care of the Indian Agent now established in the Yukon will be discussed with the Indian Commissioner for B.C. at an early date. There does not appear to be any valid reason...
reason why these Indians should not be transferred promptly to the Yukon Agency.

The officials of the Indian Affairs Branch express the opinion that the difficulty in securing the necessary supplies for Indians and particularly the supplies necessary for the operation of schools, is due to the prevailing shortage of supplies throughout the country. They point out that supplies purchased through the Purchasing Division cost substantially less than supplies of similar quality purchased locally.

Your reference to Mr. John McIsaac has been carefully noted and his name sent forward to the Director of Lands, Parks and Forests, and to the Director of Indian Affairs.

I am attempting to secure information with respect to transportation on the Canol Road during the winter months. Just as soon as this information is obtained, I shall be glad to communicate with you again.

It is unnecessary to add that your interest in the Indian population, their care and general advancement, is very much appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Minister.

The Most Reverend J. L. Coudert, O.M.I., D.D.
Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse,
P.O. Box 95,
Whitehorse,
Y.T.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS AND ENGINEERING BRANCH.

Teslin Residential School.

It is our intention to include in our 1948-49 Main Estimates a sum for the erection of a residential school at Teslin, Y.T. We have already been in contact with you concerning the site for this school. You are requested to prepare the plans and specifications for these buildings and to finalize their exact location.

The pupilage to be provided for at this school will be 120 (60 boys and 60 girls). Due to the isolation of this school it is felt that frame construction should be used but that the dormitories should be in separate buildings, in order to minimize the danger from fire.

It is felt that the school should consist of the following buildings:

(1) Boys' Dormitory Block consisting of

(a) Sleeping quarters for 60 boys
(b) Two staff rooms.
(c) Wash rooms.
(d) Recreation room.
(e) Manual training shop

It is suggested that this be a one-storey building with a full basement. The sleeping quarters, staff rooms and wash rooms could be on the main floor with the recreation room and manual training shop in the basement.
(2) Girls' Dormitory Block

The general planning of this building would be as for the boys' dormitory block with the exception of course being the manual training room. In the girls' block this would be replaced by a domestic science room which should have extra electrical outlets provided for a power sewing machine and electrical rangeettes.

(3) Administration Building

This would be the main building of the group and could be of two stories in height with a full basement also. We would require the following rooms in this building:

(a) Principal's quarters.
(b) Staff quarters for six.
(c) Chapel.
(d) Four classrooms.
(e) Kitchen and dining room.
(f) Wash rooms for use of school pupils and staff.

(4) Power House

It is suggested that the buildings be heated throughout, with steam heating and that this steam be piped to them from a centrally located power house. It is suggested that a small room be provided as living quarters for the Engineer.

It is recommended that buildings 1 and 2 and 3 be joined by fireproof corridors. As Teallin is located in the coldest part of Canada it is felt that some provision will have to be made for providing covered approaches to these buildings.

I would recommend also that a meeting be held between your Architects and our school officials to finalize the exact details of the building required.

(sgd) R.A. Hoey.
Director.

Dear Mr. Keenleyside:

Re - Teslin Residential School

I am sending you herewith copies of two memoranda received from the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch. In this connection I may say that Bennett & White Construction Company of Vancouver is willing to undertake the construction of this school on a cost-plus fixed fee basis. Moreover, I have word from the President of the White Pass Company that his company would do the work under an arrangement of this kind.

From our discussions with Mr. Buck, it seems that he has not even prepared a preliminary sketch of the structure, and evidently if he had no other job in hand it would take him two months to get ready the plans and specifications that should be furnished to a contractor.

I discussed this subject briefly on the telephone today with the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, Mr. Hoey, and also with Colonel Neary who is in charge of education and welfare for that branch. Mr. Hoey said that he did not think it should be necessary to prepare complete new plans and specifications for each building erected for the Indian Affairs Branch and that we might use at places like Teslin any building designs which had proven satisfactory elsewhere. Colonel Neary told me that for reasons of fire protection it is desired to have these new schools built in four separate units and that the situation is about as follows:

(1) The school rooms are to be identical with a satisfactory design prepared for a school at Shubenacadie.
(2) The dormitories for the girls and for the boys are to be of simplest construction so long as reasonable facilities are provided and safety guaranteed as far as possible.

(3) For the administrative building they are prepared to accept the design of the school at Alberni.

(4) It will be necessary to design a central heating plant. I believe that oil is to be used at Teslin but that coal will be used in the other groups of school buildings which are to be designed for Lac la Ronge, Norway House and Seven Islands. Indian Affairs Branch seems to be of the impression that for the four schools it should not be necessary to design more than two sets of plans.

(5) One thing that is important is the availability of an adequate water supply. I think we should lose no time in verifying the sites of these buildings. A wire should be sent to Mr. MacDougall to look over the Teslin site.

(6) I shall get in touch with the Deputy Minister's office at once about the services of architects in private practice whose services could be obtained for the designs. Owing to the difficulties of communication with Telegraph Creek, I doubt whether all the children of school age will be able to be recruited for the Teslin School from that area, outside of the orphans and destitute children, unless they are brought in Teslin by special chartered plane every summer and fall. Even if they are sent by boat via Wrangel in Alaska, they will not be able to travel by boat from Wrangel to Skagway - the only passenger boats in that part of the alaskan panhandle being Canadian steamers, which are forbidden to carry passengers from an American port to an American port. When our missionaries travel this way, they have to fly from Wrangel to Skagway, and then take the train from Skagway to Whitehorse. I have a recent communication from Father O'Plourde O.M.I., our superintendent, asking me to advise you without delay regarding the kind of heating system we would prefer for the proposed school in Teslin.

You may be acquainted with the fact that, at the urgent request of the Deputy Minister himself, the coal mines of Carmacks have reopened last Fall and are in operation; their main objective, however, is to supply the Mayo Mines and the Dawson district in the northern portion of the Yukon; when and at what price shall we be able to obtain such a coal for the town of Whitehorse and the surrounding district is still a problematic question which the Deputy Minister himself could answer much better than I could.-If coal was available here in Whitehorse at a reasonable price within a year, it would be better, of course, to figure on a heating system run with coal.

Meanwhile, we are of the opinion that it would be safer for a few years to come to depend on the wood supply which is rather abundant in the surrounding of Teslin, and might be obtained at a cheaper price than the coal. We would, therefore, for the present, still vouch for a furnace heated by wood, at least for the general heating system of the buildings.

Oil tankers travel regularly along the Highway, and therefore will go right by the door of the school; I think that we could obtain at a reasonable price fuel oil from the B.Y.N. Co. for the cooking stove and the water heater. Therefore, we would favor such a system of oil heating for the kitchen and the bathrooms.

I have heard with much pleasure of your plans of entrusting the building of the proposed school to the B.Y.N. It is the best construction Co. of the North, well equipped with men, machinery and building material, and knowing well the conditions of the North; I feel sure that such a work will be carried out to the satisfaction of all, if they get the contract.

Yours sincerely,

Bishop J.L. Coudert O.M.I. Vicarap.of Whitehorse

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES.

Teslin Residential School - Draft Plans

I have had an opportunity of studying the draft plans of the above school with our educational officials and have the following comments to make:

(1) GENERAL

(a) I would suggest that these buildings be tied a little closer together. They would seem to be very widely separated. Of course I realize the fire hazard and am willing to abide by your more expert advisers in this regard.

(b) The buildings seem too large for the pupilage and staff. There will only be 120 Indian children in attendance. This point has been settled with Bishop Coudert. We have also wired him re the number of Sisters and male staff members for whom accommodation should be provided. His answer read as follows:

"Besides private bedroom to be provided in each of four dormitories in proposed Teslin school suggest eight separate bedrooms for sisters and six separate male bedrooms."

(2) ADMINISTRATION BUILDING

(a) Main Floor.

(i) Kitchen. I would ask that the actual planning of the kitchen be referred to the Nutrition Division
of the Department of National Health and Welfare. They are vitally interested in all matters concerning the diet and feeding facilities at our residential schools and I feel that the architect should 'phone Dr. Pett at 9-3103 and arrange for one of his dietitians to go over these kitchen plans when they are ready.

(ii) Dining Room. It is noted that the capacity of the dining room is one hundred and ninety-two children. Please note my general comment above with regard to the pupilage of this school being only one hundred and twenty.

(iii) Auditorium. We try to keep these residential school plans as standard as possible. It is common practice for the assembly hall, or auditorium, to be used as a chapel by the various denominations. Therefore, steps can be placed in front of the stage so as to enable it to be used as a sanctuary.

(b) First Floor.

The chapel should be eliminated as it is our intention to use the auditorium as a combined assembly hall and chapel. This is done in all our other schools and we feel that it would be much too expensive to provide both an assembly hall and a chapel.

(c) Second Floor.

This floor should be eliminated entirely. The sick bay could quite easily be placed on the first floor where the chapel is now located.

The sick bay need only have the following accommodation:

Boys' infirmary and bathroom
Girls' infirmary and bathroom
Nurses' room
First Aid room
Janitor's closet
Linen closet.
(3) **DORMITORIES**

(a) **Basement.**

This is quite satisfactory on the whole but the building will have to be smaller in view of our recommendations of the next paragraph.

(b) **Ground Floor.**

It is noted that the dormitory has a capacity for ninety-six children. This is much too large and it can be reduced to a pupilage of sixty for each dormitory. It is not necessary to provide two separate bathrooms for the supervisors; one will be quite sufficient.

(4) **CLASSROOM BUILDING**

The classroom building is quite satisfactory and we have no comment to make concerning it. It is suggested that cupboards be placed in the two teachers' rooms for the storage of books and other classroom materials.

(5) **BOILER ROOM**

We approve entirely of having the small living quarters attached as shown.

Re: Coal Supply for Teslin Indian Residential School

I am glad to have Mr. Allan's further memorandum of June 4th, giving comments from Indian Superintendent Meek in regard to the above subject. I am attaching copy of a letter dated June 8th from Mr. F. M. Connell, who is President of United Keno Hill Mines, Limited, as well as of Yukon Coal Company. The main problem of providing coal to the school at Teslin is apparently the obtaining of transportation from Carmacks to Whitehorse and you will note that Mr. Johnston, who is Mr. Connell's Consulting Engineer, was leaving for the Yukon and will investigate what can be done.

In the letter of the previous day, Mr. Connell gave me the following price schedule for coal F.O.B. the mine at Carmacks:

| Description                  | Price per ton |
|------------------------------|---------------|
| Graded and sacked            | $12.50        |
| Run of mine (sacked)         | $10.00        |
| Run of mine (loose)          | $8.00         |

(The cost of sacks extra with the understanding that price to be refunded on return)

It is noted that Mr. Meek has given you a probable selling price at Whitehorse of $17.00 per ton. If his quotation was based on the graded and sacked domestic coal which Mr. Connell quotes at $12.50 per ton Carmacks, the price would allow only $4.50 per ton for the transportation from Carmacks upstream to Whitehorse and we question whether that would be sufficient. The transportation downstream from Carmacks to Dawson, which appears to be a slightly greater distance, is quoted at $7.50 per ton according to the information in our files. Mr. Connell has stated that the navigation company has so far not set any rate from Carmacks to Whitehorse.

While insufficient may have been allowed for the transportation to Whitehorse, it would seem, on the other hand, that Mr. Meek's quotation of $11.00 per ton for hauling on the Alaska Highway from Whitehorse to Teslin, 110 miles, is a very high figure.

I think you will be interested in the following quotation from a progress report by Mr. George Miller, Mine Manager, as just received:

"Quality of Coal. Coal from underground has been used in the camp all winter and represents a very good average sample of all the development faces to date. Domestic coal plus # product has been used in the camp cook stove and has proved to be a wonderful fuel for cooking. It burns..."
completely to a fine ash and gives off great heat. Two coal burning heaters are used to heat the rest of the camp, an area of 100' x 20'. Run of mine coal is used in these heaters. Although tons of coal have been fed to each heater all winter, the grates have never been dug out at any time nor has a clinker or piece of slate been picked out of either one. All that has been necessary to do is give the grates a slight shake. The ash is very fine and is estimated to be about 9-10%. A great heat with long flame is given off from the run of mine product.

The eventual cost of coal at Teslin will, of course, depend upon whether you will require graded or run of mine coal for the school. While the information I have given you is not very definite as to what the delivered price would be, you nevertheless have a fairly close indication and I should like to know your reaction in regard to the price and the using of coal rather than wood for heating of the school. If I had your thoughts on the matter, it might enable me to exert more pressure upon Mr. Connell in regard to making arrangements for delivery of coal to Whitehorse from this Government assisted project. It seems to me that the market available from Whitehorse, including the railway, will be large and that some arrangement for the upstream transportation will have to be made as rapidly as possible.

I shall advise you further as soon as I learn the outcome of Mr. Johnston's present trip.

W. B. Timm,
Director.

Dear Mr. Neary;

I have your communication of July 7 with enclosed copies
of a correspondence between the Officials of the Yukon Coal Company
and Mr. R.A. Hoey regarding the Fuel Supply for the proposed School
of Teslin.

I have recently made a trip to Dawson and had occasion to
visit the said Coal Mine at Carmacks; and the information I gathered
from Mr. George Miller, the engineer in charge, corresponded exactly to
your own information on the subject. The coal is there, and in big
quantity, and appears to be very good for domestic use, but the great
difficulty is the transportation; the only freighting Company on the
Yukon River is the White Pass, and with all their steamers and barges
they will barely be able to handle the silver ore concentrates piled
on the shore at Mayo and Minto before the winter season.

Until the transportation company is properly organized to handle
the coal on the river or here in Whitehorse, there is little chance to
depend on that supply for the school.

From my experience with other schools in the North, I think that
your figure of 1000 tons per year is abnormally high; I was figuring on
some 600 cords of wood or 400 tons of coal for the needs of our school
per year.

At any rate, my present suggestion is the same as the one pre-
viously made, viz., that we should use wood for the first years until the
coal situation is clarified; it seems to me that the change from wood
to coal could be made with a very slight alteration in the grates of
the same furnaces.

I am really sorry that the work has not yet started; we have
been enjoying the best weather the Yukon ever had in years for the past
six weeks; it would have been an ideal weather for the laying of the foun-
dation and all the outside work to be performed in the open. I still firmly
hope that the cement foundations of all the buildings will be laid in August
before the September frosts start.

Yours sincerely,

Bishop J.L. Coudert O.M.I.

Under date of June 12 I have provided you with a memorandum in regard to the above subject and mentioned that Mr. A. W. Johnston, Consulting Engineer for Mr. F. M. Connell, was leaving for the Yukon.

Mr. Johnston thought that a wood supply should be laid in but that it might be possible to provide a small quantity of coal for trial during the coming winter.

We now have a copy of a report dated July 13 which Mr. Johnston has written for Mr. Connell, in which he states that coal from the mine at Carmacks has now started moving to Mayo and to Dawson, but that movement is slow because of a lack of barge space. While the White Pass and Yukon Route anticipates being able to move substantial quantities of coal to Dawson and Mayo during this navigation season, the delivery of coal to Whitehorse, on the other hand, is problematical. Mr. Johnston states that after several conferences with the White Pass and Yukon on this point, they feel they can give no assurance of carrying any appreciable tonnage upstream to Whitehorse this season due to congestion on the boats and barges. It is hoped that towards the end of the season some coal may be moved upriver, but Mr. Johnston says that householders and other potential users should not count upon coal this season. He also indicates that Yukon Coal is expecting the market on the river and upstream to Whitehorse to become very important, with White Pass and Yukon potential users of 10,000 to 15,000 tons of the Carmacks coal per year.

As far as the future is concerned, it would appear that Yukon Coal will be definitely making every effort to get into the Whitehorse market and to have coal available for such potential customers as the Teslin school. Mr. Rogers, President of the White Pass and Yukon, is stated to be very interested in the whole matter and realizes the necessity of providing barges especially for the coal movement.

Re: Development of Tantalus Butte Coal Mine, Yukon Territory

We gave you a memorandum on the above subject under date of July 6, 1948, and you may be interested to learn that we have information now that coal from the mine at Carmacks has definitely started to move to Mayo and to Dawson. Mr. A.W. Johnston, Consulting Engineer for Mr. F.M. Connell, President of Yukon Coal Company, reporting to Mr. Connell after date of July 13, states that at the time of his visit approximately 2,000 tons of sacked coal were ready for shipment, of which amount 1,400 tons was mine run and 600 tons domestic screen coal. Mr. Johnston stated that, although little coal had gone down the river due to lack of barge space, the White Pass and Yukon Route anticipated that the requirements of Dawson and Mayo could be met this year. These requirements would involve the delivery of at least 1,000 tons to each of the two points. He also reported that delivery of coal to Whitehorse this season was very problematical, although attempts would be made to get small quantities delivered to Whitehorse before the close of the navigation season. Efforts would be made to provide 200 tons to the White Pass and Yukon for trial in locomotives and river boats. Mr. Johnston placed the potential use of Carmacks coal by the White Pass and Yukon at 10,000 to 15,000 tons of coal per year.

We have been especially interested in the outlook for getting coal up to Whitehorse this year, particularly as Mr. Hoey has been interested in the possibilities of obtaining coal for an Indian residential school to be erected at Teslin. In a current memorandum to Mr. Hoey we have indicated that the prospects for this year are not good and that a wood supply would apparently need to be laid in for the proposed school, although some coal may possibly be provided for trial next winter.

It appears from Mr. Johnston's discussions that Mr. Rogers, President of the White Pass and Yukon, is now most interested in the new coal mine and the possibilities for large scale utilization of its product. Mr. Johnston states that Mr. Rogers realizes the necessity for additional barges on the Yukon River primarily designed to carry bulk coal. In conversation with Mr. Norrish in Toronto a few days ago, Mr. Johnston thought that the White Pass and Yukon would probably take action next winter to have a number of special barges built for the coal business.

(sgd.) J. R. Kirkconnell
Acting Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

Teslin Indian Residential School.

Our District Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of British Columbia has recently completed an educational survey of the Stikine Agency, which lies in the northeastern corner of the Province of British Columbia. In his report he states as follows:

"Northern Section

"For about three months of the year the Indians of the northern section of the agency congregate at four centres close to the Yukon border and for the remainder of the year are scattered in family groups over a very wide area. These points are Lower Post, Teslin, Carcross, and Atlin. It will be noted that two of these points are in the Yukon and that Lower Post is connected to both Teslin and Carcross by road. Atlin although not connected by road is more accessible from Carcross and the Yukon than from B.C. For these reasons the educational requirements should be considered in conjunction with those of the Southern Yukon. A visit to the office of the Yukon Agency at Whitehorse disclosed that the approximate number of Indian children of Roman Catholic faith in that agency approximates 100 and consequently there will be insufficient accommodation for this number and the 65 children of the same denomination from south of the boundary at the new residential school to be established at Teslin."

In view of this recommendation, I would like to ask that consideration be given by your Chief Architect to
the provision of dormitory and other facilities at the proposed Teslin Residential School for 160 children rather than for the 120 children originally mentioned in previous memoranda.

I understand that my Superintendent of Education has already discussed this matter with your Chief Architect.

Acting Director.
Ottawa, September 21, 1948.

Memorandum:

MAJOR MacKAY

Pupilage of Proposed Teslin Residential School.

As requested, I have prepared a summary of the pertinent facts concerning the pupilage of this proposed school.

1. Originally the pupilage was set at 120, based on an educational survey of the Yukon made by our educational survey officer.

2. When the original plans prepared by Mr. Noffke were examined, it was found that although the dormitories were designed to hold only 120 beds, eventually we could, by use of double deckers accommodate 160 pupils.

3. The estimated cost of the several buildings designed by Mr. Noffke was, as you will recall, nearly five hundred thousand dollars.

4. He was, therefore, asked to re-design his plans for the school by eliminating some of the play-room space, consolidating the buildings, etc.

5. He was not asked to reduce the size of the dormitories because of the recommendations made by Inspector Davey after his educational survey of the Stikine Agency. You will recall the contents of this report made in answer partially to a request made by Bishop Jordan for another R.C. residential School at or near Fort St. John, B.C. I have attached Mr. Arneil's letter in answer to an Army Signal sent
him concerning this report.

6. I understand from the Chief Architect that the outline of the new plans will be ready today or tomorrow.

7. In conclusion may I point out

(a) The pupilage of this school has not definitely been settled at 160. If the estimated cost of the re-designed plans is still too high, we may have to consider a much smaller pupilage for this school.

(b) It never was our intention to have this school for only the Indian children of Bishop Coudert's diocese. We have other children for whom we must provide educational facilities in the Fort St. John Agency (B.C. and Alberta) and the Stikine Agency (B.C.) as well as in the Yukon Agency.

Teslin Residential School Location

Dear Mr. Neary:

I have your communication of Dec. 23 regarding the Residential School Location in Teslin.

The proposed ground or area of school has been thoroughly surveyed twice, and lines have been cut through and through the property at given distances, and I do not think that such an elaborate work would have to be gone over again, no matter where the building is erected, as long as it is on said property.

As a matter of fact, since the plans of the proposed school have been so radically altered and we are going to have only one or two buildings at most, instead of four or five, the exact location of the proposed building still remains to be decided upon.

My main objection to the first plan of the engineers was:

1. They had the main building facing North-East and looking towards a high nearby mountain, without any chance of sunshine on the main front of the building for six months of the year.

By turning the building right around, it would face the South-West and enjoy a unique scenery over Lake Teslin, with the full benefit of every ray of sunshine available in the winter time.

n.b.-all the Residential schools I know which have been built near a lake, such as Lejac, Kenora, Fort Chipewyan, Fort Resolution, Grouard, Calais or Sturgeon Lake, Joussard, etc., etc., are all facing the nearby lake.

2. The location pointed out by the engineers, close to the Alaska Highway:

a.-will necessitate the destruction of a beautiful spruce and jackpine grove (the only one on the property) which would have made an ideal park for the children during the summer months, would have given the school a little privacy from all indiscreet visitors, and protect the school from the heavy clouds of smoke and dust arising from the Alaska Highway during the summer.

b.-it will increase the cost of excavating for the water line and the cost of operation of the same by putting the school uselessly too far away from the lake shore.

n.b.-Major Clarke can tell you, on the other hand, that closer to the lake, there is an ideal high ground, already cleared and almost level. I deeply regret that the engineers who have suggested a different location have never consulted me nor Father Dream, who was readily available at Teslin.

So, unless they have a very serious objection to the location...
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

we ourselves had in view and which I constantly pointed out to the Government Officials, I still insist that our location is the most satisfactory.

Yours sincerely in Christ

Bishop J.L. Couder O.M.I.

P.S.-I would advise you to discuss this matter with both Major Clarke and Father Plourde, who have both explored the property, and even arrange a conference between them and the man responsible for the survey, who must be in Ottawa.

After seeing the property, Father Plourde was 100% in favor of the location I pointed out to him.

Dear Mr. MacKay:

I am in receipt of a special and pressing letter from His Excellency Bishop Coudert of White Horse in which he asks me to speak to you about the site of the Teslin School.

According to plans which were shown to me and which were also forwarded to the Bishop, the main building will be situated on the Alaska Highway and at a distance of two hundred feet.

This means that the front of the building comprising the principal's rooms and main offices will face north and has as its only panorama a high mountain which even during the summer months will throw a continuous shadow of darkness. Moreover, the dust on the highway is at all times quite abundant and at a distance of 200 feet will be a real nuisance for the inhabitants of the school.

In place of the sight which is marked A on the plans, the Bishop suggests placing the school close to the lake on site B where the bank is quite high and where there is no danger of a flood, even during the spring of the year. Moreover, the lake at this point is a thing of beauty. With the sun bathing the front of the building most of the time, living in the school will be a pleasure for both the children and staff.

May I add that the Bishop is very insistent on this change, as he knows the country very well and he has asked me to place his views before you so that you may study the question of the site once more and if at all possible grant his wishes.

Yours very truly,
