Memorandum:

MAJOR MacKAY

Pupilage of Proposed Teslin Residential School.

As requested, I have prepared a summary of the pertinent facts concerning the pupilage of this proposed school.

1. Originally the pupilage was set at 120, based on an educational survey of the Yukon made by our educational survey officer.

2. When the original plans prepared by Mr. Noffke were examined, it was found that although the dormitories were designed to hold only 120 beds, eventually we could, by use of double deckers accommodate 160 pupils.

3. The estimated cost of the several buildings designed by Mr. Noffke was, as you will recall, nearly five hundred thousand dollars.

4. He was, therefore, asked to re-design his plans for the school by eliminating some of the play-room space, consolidating the buildings, etc.

5. He was not asked to reduce the size of the dormitories because of the recommendations made by Inspector Davey after his educational survey of the Stikine Agency. You will recall the contents of this report made in answer partially to a request made by Bishop Jordan for another R.C. residential school at or near Fort St. John, B.C. I have attached Mr. Arneil's letter in answer to an Army Signal sent
him concerning this report.

6. I understand from the Chief Architect that the outline of the new plans will be ready today or tomorrow.

7. In conclusion may I point out

(a) The pupilage of this school has not definitely been settled at 160. If the estimated cost of the re-designed plans is still too high, we may have to consider a much smaller pupilage for this school.

(b) It never was our intention to have this school for only the Indian children of Bishop Coudert's diocese. We have other children for whom we must provide educational facilities in the Fort St. John Agency (B.C. and Alberta) and the Stikine Agency (B.C.) as well as in the Yukon Agency.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

Re: Church of England Residential Schools

It has recently been brought to my attention that the Indian Affairs branch is calling for tenders for the erection of a large residential school at Teslin Yukon Territory to be used by the Roman Catholics. It is understood that the building is to have four floors and be in size about 200' x 67'. A Chapel also is contemplated and is planned to be 64' x 30' in size. The building will house 120 pupils, as well as a number of priests and sisters and is to cost in the neighborhood of $700,000.

I make bold to point out that the Southern Yukon area is a comparatively new field of operation for the Roman Church. On the other hand the Anglican denomination has operated an educational institution for the Indians of Southern Yukon since 1903. at Carcross. In April of 1939 the Carcross School, a government owned building, was burned and because of the urgencies of war was not replaced by Government. In 1944 however, the Anglican Church, at no cost to Government, rebuilt the present structure so that the educational needs of the Indians might be met. Archbishop Adams and The Indian School Administration Office have stressed with Indian Affairs Branch the urgent need for rebuilding and enlarging the Carcross school but to no avail. It is very disconcerting to us to find that a comparatively new group in the area is being so elaborately cared for while we who have toiled under adverse circumstances are being wholly overlooked in our pleas for assistance.
To add weight to the above statement a similar policy seems to prevail in other centres. Last year the Roman Church was built a modern day school at Atikameg where we have had, for many years, a residential school with classroom facilities to care for all the children of the little settlement.

Then too down the years a number of Church of England Schools have been burned. The Mackay School, the Pas in March 1933; Onion Lake School, Saskatchewan, November 1943; Wasbasca School, January 1945 and Lac la Ronge School in Saskatchewan in February of 1947. Mackay school has never been replaced. To take the place of the Onion Lake School the Indian Affairs Branch rents for our use a most inadequate building in Prince Albert. Wabasca School was replaced by the Church in the purchase of a number of odd buildings. Now the Government is building a new School at Wabasca, granted, but two years later than promised and without many necessary features. Just recently we were informed that the two playrooms were to be made into classrooms. The Principal's residence is more than half a mile from the School and out of sight of the building. A make-shift replacement for Lac la Ronge was given us at an army camp on the outskirts of Prince Albert where our operational costs are extremely high and where promises take the place of actual alterations in the structure of the buildings to convert them into decent living quarters.

Then too it can be stated that in cooperation with the Government's policy of establishing day schools on some reserves our Church has closed two of its residential schools, namely at Chapleau, Ontario and Elkhorn, Manitoba. I cannot recall of the Roman Church thus cooperating.

We were led to believe that this summer would see the erection of a Hostel at or near Lac la Ronge and a new classroom block at Alert Bay for the use of Anglican Indian Pupils. We are told now that funds are not available but the government, apparently, can afford to erect a $700,000. structure for the Roman Church in an area the majority of the people of which are Anglican.
I feel that after reading the above and checking its accuracy you will agree that the Anglican has justifiable cause in protesting the erection of such an expensive institution at Teslin when many of our requests might well have had priority. I sincerely trust that you will see your way clear to have justice done and I would appreciate having your comments.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) George Frederick Nova Scotia
Archbishop of Nova Scotia
and Primate of All Canada.

The Most Reverend George F. Kingston, M.A., Ph.D., D.D.,
Archbishop of Nova Scotia,
Primate of All Canada,
All Barrington Street,
Halifax, Nova Scotia.

My dear Archbishop Kingston:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 24 concerning various matters relating to the operation of Indian residential schools by the Church of England.

We have noted your comments concerning the proposed erection of an Indian Residential School at Teslin, Y.T. While tenders have been called for the erection of this building, no decision has as yet been reached with respect to the awarding of a contract. You can rest assured that the Department does not propose to spend seven hundred thousand dollars or anything approaching such an amount for the erection of this school.

We are quite aware of the work that has been done by your church in the Southern Yukon. The 1941 census of the Indians in Canada shows that there are some 307 Indians of the Roman Catholic faith in the Yukon. These are mainly situated at Burwash Landing, Pelly Banks, Frances Lake, Watson Lake and Teslin. In addition to the children of these Indians, we had of course planned to provide for the children of the northeast corner of British Columbia. There are some 450 Catholic Indians in this region, including 96 in the Atlin-Teslin Lake area, 75 at Nelson Creek, 42 in the Liard-Frances Lake area, 60 in the Nelson River district and 184 at Tahltan. There are also Indian children in the Peace River district down the Alaska highway.
as far as Prophet River, who require institutional care.

Before a decision was reached to erect this school, two separate educational surveys were carried out. Both were in agreement that such an institution was necessary.

We are aware of the situation at the Carcross Residential School, and as you know, intend to purchase these buildings as the first step in the improvement of the facilities at this institution.

With regard to your comments on the Whitefish Reserve at Atikmeg, assurance has been given to your officials that we are prepared to erect a day school for the Anglican children, similar in every way to that erected last year for the Roman Catholic children. Honourable and dear Sir:

I have received word that the Department of Indian Affairs is planning to erect an Indian Residential School at Teslin in Yukon Territory for the Roman Catholics at a cost of $700,000. Surely my information must be incorrect, for I can hardly imagine such a project by the Roman Catholic Church in the Teslin area,- especially when the Department has stated that it is not able, due to lack of finances, to build a proper school at Atikameg in the Whitefish Lake area in the Diocese of Athabasca in Northern Alberta.

For some time, I was Bishop of Yukon with headquarters at Dawson City. At that time, at the beginning of the last decade, there was only one Roman Catholic priest in permanent residence in the whole of the Yukon. I frequently visited Teslin while I was Bishop and there was no Roman Catholic priest there, although sometimes a visit was made by a priest from outside Yukon, but they had practically no Roman Catholic Indians in that area. All the Indians of that district look to the Anglican Church for spiritual administration. We also, at our own cost, provided a school teacher for the children at Teslin for five months of each year. The attendance would average about 30 children and I have been personally present at the school. The Roman Catholics did nothing of this kind for the Indian children.
Our Indian Residential School buildings at Whitefish Lake in this Diocese in Northern Alberta, are literally falling to pieces. They are all of logs and are absolutely inadequate for the accommodation of the children and staff, yet we have never been able to obtain a sufficient grant from the Department of Indian Affairs for the erection of suitable buildings,- and I assure you that the cost would be far less than $700,000.

The Department is erecting, this year, a new school for the Anglican children at Wabasca, yet there is no proper residence being provided for the Principal of the Wabasca Indian School. It also is of logs and is in terrible condition. The last time I was there in the Winter I nearly froze to death. The cold was terrible and the wind and cold penetrated the building.

We have tried to co-operate fully with your Department and we have tried to play the game. How then is the Roman Catholic Church able to obtain a grant of $700,000 for one residential school when the Anglican Church goes begging for a school at Whitefish Lake which would cost not more than one-seventh of the above amount?

Moreover, as I have pointed out, practically all of the Teslin Indians were Anglican and I do not suppose they have changed since the last decade.

I know you will forgive me as I point out this seeming injustice and lack of proportion in the granting of funds for buildings and equipment which would be used in the care of our Indian wards.

With every good wish, believe me,

Yours faithfully,

A. H. Soversign Bishop

In addition to the children of these Indians, we had of course planned to provide for the children of the northeast corner of British Columbia. There are some 450 Catholic Indians in this region, including 96 in the Atlin-Teslin area, 75 at Malmine Creek, 42 in the Liard-Frances Lake area, 60 in the Nelson River district and 184 at Tahltan. There are also Indian children in the Peace River district down the Alaska highway as far as Prophet River, who require institutional care.
Before a decision was reached to erect this school, two separate educational surveys were carried out. Both were in agreement that such an institution was necessary.

With regard to the Teslin Bay School, our records show that for many years we have paid an amount towards the salary of your seasonal school teacher, usually a theological student. We have also sent in school supplies. Only in 1933 were we unable to make such payments. For many years these teachers were nominated by the late Bishop Gedes. A joint school is now being operated at Teslin in co-operation with the Yukon Territorial Council. The teacher, Miss Joan Adams, is an Anglican.

We are aware of the condition of the buildings at the Whitefish Lake Church of England Residential School and in a recent letter to Archbishop Kingston I mentioned that we had assured your officials that we were prepared to erect a day school for the Anglican children at this point. I presume from your letter that your recommendation is for the erection of another residential school there.

Yours sincerely,

ARTICLE V: The security deposit furnished His Majesty by the Contractor shall be held and retained by His Majesty as security for the due and complete performance, observance and fulfilment by the Contractor of all the covenants and provisions of this Contract. Unless and until the security is forfeited to His Majesty as herein provided, His Majesty shall remit any revenues and income therefrom (provided that His Majesty shall in no event be obligated to invest monies at interest or otherwise) to the Contractor, and in the case of interest coupons or dividend coupons payable to bearer shall deliver the same to the Contractor as and when they mature.

In the event of any default by the Contractor in fulfilment of any of the terms and conditions of this Contract, this security shall (without prejudice to any and all other rights and recourses accruing to His Majesty) be forfeited to and retained by His Majesty as liquidated damages and not as a penalty but if the Contractor shall have duly performed, observed and fulfilled all the covenants, terms and conditions of this Contract, the security shall be returned to the Contractor.

GENERAL CONDITIONS

Contract Documents

1. The covenants, clauses, provisos and conditions of the Tender Form and General Instructions to Bidders, together with these Specifications (embracing the General Conditions, Labour Conditions, General Specifications and Trade Specifications) and the Working Drawings and such additional detail or shop drawings special specifications and instructions as may from time to time be furnished, shall be as fully part of this contract as if attached hereto, or herein repeated, and should the Contractor or Minister fail to sign them they shall nevertheless be binding on both parties.

Interpretation of Terms

2. In this contract the following words shall, unless the context requires a different meaning, have the following meanings, respectively, that is to say:

'Contractor', or other words relative thereto, or of like import, shall mean and include the party or parties of the first part as in the Agreement designated or described, jointly and severally, and their and each of their executors, administrators, successors or assigns.

'His Majesty', or other words relative thereto, or of like import, shall mean and include the reigning Sovereign or the successors or assigns of the Sovereign.

'Minister', or other words relative thereto, or of like import, shall mean and include the person holding the position or acting in the capacity of the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration for the time being, and shall include the person holding the position or acting in the capacity of the Deputy Minister of Citizenship and Immigration, for the time being.

'Chief', or other words relative thereto, or of like import shall mean and include the person holding the position or acting in the capacity of the Chief Engineer of the Department of National Defence (Army).

'Engineer', or other words relative thereto, or of like import shall mean and include the architect or engineer or any person having immediate charge of the work, and acting under the authority of the Chief.

'Department', or other words relative thereto, or of like import, shall mean that portion of the Department of Citizenship and Immigration of Canada, which the Chief is authorized to represent in the execution of the work.

'work' or 'works', or other words relative thereto, or of like import, shall mean the whole of the work and materials, matter and things required to be done, furnished and performed by the Contractor, as above described, under this contract.

Bonds of Contract

3. All the covenants and agreements in this contract binding on, and all the provisions in this contract inuring to the benefit of the Contractor shall, respectively, be binding on and inure to the benefit of the executors, administrators, successors and assigns of the Contractors, and all the covenants and agreements in this contract binding upon, and all the provisions in this contract inuring to the benefit of His Majesty, shall, respectively, be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the successors and assigns of His Majesty.
Final Approval of Instructions

4. This contract is made and entered into on the distinct understanding that all instructions, directions or certificates given, or decisions made by any one acting under the authority of the Chief, shall be subject to his approval and may be cancelled, altered, modified and changed as he may see fit:

CHIEF

PROVIDED always that any act on the part of the Chief in connection with and in virtue of the present contract, and any instructions, directions or certificates given, or decisions made by him, or by any one acting for him, shall be subject to the approval of, or modification or cancellation by the Minister.

Assignments

5. The Contractor shall not assign or sublet this contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained: Provided, however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction of such works, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any sub-contractor, and the Contractor shall be held entirely and alone responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work contracted for.

Contractor to investigate every condition of work before execution of contract

6. This contract is made and entered into by the Contractor and His Majesty on the distinct understanding that the Contractor has, before execution investigated and satisfied himself of everything and of every condition affecting the works to be executed and the labour and material to be provided, and that the execution of this contract by the Contractor is founded and based upon his own examination, knowledge, information and judgment, and not upon any statement, representation, or information made or given by, or upon any information derived from any quantities, dimensions, tests, specifications, plans, maps or profiles made, given or furnished by His Majesty or any of His officers, employees or agents; and that any such statements, representation or information, as so made, given or furnished, was made, given or furnished merely for the general information of bidders and is not in anywise warranted or guaranteed by or on behalf of His Majesty; and that no extra allowance will be made to the Contractor by, and the Contractor will make no claim against, His Majesty for any loss or damage sustained in consequence of, or by reason of any such statement, representation or information being incorrect or inaccurate, or on account of unforeseen difficulties of any kind.

Construction of Contract

7. The several parts of this contract and the specifications and plans shall be taken together to explain each other and to make the whole consistent; and if it is found that anything has been omitted or mis-stated which is necessary for the proper performance or completion of any part of the work the Contractor shall, at his own expense, execute the same as though it had been inserted and properly described, and the correction of any such omission or error shall not be deemed to be an addition to or deviation from the works hereby contracted for.
Changes in Work

8. The Engineer may, in writing, at any time before the final acceptance of the works, order any additional work, or materials or things to be done or provided, or the whole or any portion of the works to be dispensed with, or any changes to be made which he may deem expedient in, or in respect of the works hereby contracted for, or the plans, dimensions, character, quantity, quality, description, location or position of the works, or any portion or portions thereof, or in any materials or things connected therewith, on use or intended to be used therein, whether or not the effect of such order is to increase or diminish the work to be done or the materials or things to be provided or the cost of doing or providing the same; and the Engineer may, in such order or from time to time as he may see fit, specify the time or times within which each order shall, in whole or in part, be complied with. The Contractor shall comply with every such order of the Engineer. The decision of the Engineer as to whether the compliance with such order increases or diminishes the work to be done, or the materials or things to be provided, or the cost of doing or providing the same, and as to the amount to be paid or deducted, as the case may be, in respect thereof, shall be final. As a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to payment in respect of any such order of the Engineer, the Contractor shall obtain and produce the order, in writing, of the Engineer, and a certificate, in writing, of the Engineer, showing compliance with such order and fixing the amount to be paid or deducted in respect thereof.

Covenant herein applies to extra work

9. All the clauses of this contract shall apply to any changes, additions, deviations, or additional work, so ordered by the Engineer, in like manner and to the same extent as to the works contracted for.

No claim for anticipated profits

10. If any change or deviation in or omission from the works be made by which the amount of work to be done shall be decreased, or if the whole or any portion of the works be dispensed with, no compensation shall be claimable by the Contractor for any loss of anticipated profits in respect thereof.

Descriptions of work; what items include

11. The description, or descriptions of the work and materials or any portion or portions of the works, set out or referred to in or covered by any item or items for which a price or prices are given in this contract, include not only the particular kinds of materials mentioned in the said item or items, but also all and every kind of work, labour, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever necessary for the full execution, completion and delivery, ready for use, of such respective portions of the works in accordance with the plans, drawings and specifications, to the satisfaction of the Engineer. The said price or prices shall cover not only the particular descriptions of work and materials mentioned herein or shown on the plans, but also all and every kind of work, labour, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever necessary for the full execution, completion and delivery, ready for use, of the entire work as herein contracted for to the satisfaction of the Engineer. In case of disputes as to what work, labour, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things are so included or covered, the decision of the Engineer shall be final and conclusive with respect thereto.
Temporary Buildings and Office

12. The Contractor shall erect and maintain at his own expense, any temporary buildings that may be required for the work, or workmen, and shall provide an office for the use of the Engineer.

The location of all buildings, plant and equipment must be approved by the Engineer before any erection work is begun.

Execution of work directed by Engineer

13. The work shall be commenced, carried on and prosecuted to completion by the Contractor in all its several parts in such manner and at such points and places as the Engineer shall from time to time, direct, and to his satisfaction, but always according to the provisions of this contract, and if no direction is given by the Engineer, then in a careful, prompt and workmanlike manner.

Work subject to control of Engineer

14. The work shall in every particular be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Engineer; and all orders, directions or instructions at any time given by the Engineer with respect thereto, or concerning the conduct thereof, shall by the Contractor promptly and efficiently be obeyed, performed and complied with to the satisfaction of the Engineer.

Engineer's stakes or other marks not to be removed

15. The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes buoys or other marks placed on or about the said works by the Engineer or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

Orders for Engineer's Agent

16. All orders, directions, instructions or notices to be given or issued by the Engineer, under and pursuant to any section in this contract, may be given or issued by a duly and expressly authorized agent or agents of the Engineer.

Notice; how given

17. Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman, addressed to the address mentioned in this contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence. Every such notice, order, direction or communication shall be sufficient which expresses in general language and without detail the matters required or communicated, or which follows the general language of the section or sections of this contract under which it is given, and no objection shall be taken to the form thereof.

Foreman of the works

18. A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during all the working hours, to receive the orders of the Engineer. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor, and shall have full power to carry out all requisitions and instructions of the said Engineer, but this clause shall not relieve the Contractor from the duty of personally superintending the work.
Engineer sole judge of work and material

19. The Engineer shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or interpretation of this contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specification shall be final, and no work under this contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Engineer is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid therefor.

Quality

20. The works shall be constructed by the Contractor and under his personal supervision, of new materials throughout; the best materials of their several kinds, and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in the manner required by and in strict conformity with this contract, the said specifications and special plans and specifications, and the plans and drawings relating thereto, and the working or detail drawings which may from time to time be furnished, which said specifications and special plans and drawings are hereby declared to be part of this contract.

Defective work or material

21. Should the Contractor use or employ, or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools, equipment, articles or things which, in the opinion of the Engineer are not in accordance with the provisions of this contract or are in any way unsuitable for the works, or any part thereof, or should the Engineer consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively or insufficiently executed or performed the Engineer may order the Contractor to remove the same, and to use and employ proper material, plants, tools, equipment, articles and things, or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders; and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours, the Engineer may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed, the orders herein given and the Contractor shall, on demand, pay to His Majesty all costs, damages and expenses incurred in respect thereof, or occasioned to His Majesty by reason of the non-compliance by the Contractor with any such orders, or His Majesty may, in the discretion of the Minister, retain and deduct such costs, damages and expenses from any amounts then or thereafter payable to the Contractor.

Insufficient workmen, plant, etc.

22. If the Engineer shall at any time consider the number of workmen, horses, quantity of machinery, tools, plant or equipment, or of proper materials articles or things, respectively, employed or provided by the Contractor on or for the said works to be insufficient for the advancement of such works or any part thereof towards completion within the time limited in respect thereof, or that the works or any part thereof, are not being carried on with due diligence, then, and in every such case, the Engineer may, in writing, order the Contractor to employ or provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may think necessary, and in case the Contractor shall not within three days, or such other longer period as may be fixed by any such order, in all respects comply therewith, the Engineer may employ and provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, as he may think proper, and
may pay such additional workmen such wages, and for such additional horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, any such prices as he may think proper and all such amounts so paid shall, on demand, be repaid to His Majesty by the Contractor, or the same may be retained or deducted from any sum that may then or thereafter be or become due from His Majesty to the Contractor. The Contractor shall employ the additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things so provided and employed by the Engineer in the diligent advancement of the works; the workmen and horses so provided shall, however, be thereafter subject to discharge by the Contractor, but only with the consent and approval of the Engineer.

Contractor's machinery, plant, etc.

23. All machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever provided by the Contractor or by the Engineer under the provisions of sections 21 and 22 for the works, and not rejected under the provisions of section 21 shall from the time of their being so provided, become and until the final completion of the said work, shall be the property of His Majesty for the purpose of the said works, and the same shall on no account be taken away, or used, or disposed of, except for the purposes of the said works, without the consent in writing of the Engineer. His Majesty shall not, however, be answerable for any loss or damage whatsoever which may at any time happen to such machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles or things. Upon the completion of the works and upon payment by the Contractor of all such moneys loss, cost and damages, if any, as shall be due from the Contractor to His Majesty, or otherwise against the Contractor under this contract, such of the said machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things as shall not have been used and converted in the works or disposed of by His Majesty under powers conferred in this contract, shall, upon demand, be delivered up to the Contractor in such condition as they may then be in.

Work not comprised in contract

24. His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the works other contractors and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in this contract, and the Contractor shall afford to them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Engineer may deem practical.

The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the works of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed an acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the works comprised in this contract.

Co-operation with other Contractors

25. That whenever and so often as it may be necessary for the Contractor to co-operate with other contractors on this work, or any or either of them, the Contractor shall willingly and under the directions of the Engineer perform all such works as shall be requisite and proper on the part of the Contractor herein for such co-operation and for securing and placing in proper position the portion necessary herein and hereby contracted to be constructed and erected for the proposed work in a proper and secure mode, and to prevent the possibility of any accident therefrom without any extra charge therefor and shall be bound in all things to conform to the direction of the Minister or the Engineer touching such cooperation and work.

Default or delay by Contractor

26. In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the works or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under this contract, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, the Engineer may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Engineer to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in the completion of the works, or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent, or abandon the work, or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required, or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of this contract, then and in any of such cases the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and with all further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he, on His Majesty's behalf, may see fit to complete the works, and in such case the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment in respect of work performed, but shall be chargeable with and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the works, and no objection or claim shall be raised or made by the Contractor by reason or on account of the ultimate cost of the work so taken over, for any reason proving greater than in the opinion of the Contractor it should have been; and all materials, articles and things whatsoever, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights, proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Engineer under the provisions of this contract shall remain and be the property of His Majesty for all purposes incidental to the completion of the works, and may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty as fully to all intents and purposes connected with the works as they might therefore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor; and the Minister may also, at his option, on behalf of His Majesty, sell or otherwise dispose of, at forced sale prices, at public auction or private sale, or otherwise, the whole or any part or number of such materials, articles, things, horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment at such prices or prices as he may see fit, and retain the proceeds of any such sale or disposition and all other amounts then or thereafter due by His Majesty to the Contractor on account of, or in part satisfaction of any loss or damage which His Majesty may sustain or have sustained by reason aforesaid.

Power to take action in default of Contractor

27. Whenever in this contract power or authority is given to His Majesty, the Minister, the Engineer, or any person on behalf of His Majesty, to take any action consequent upon the insolvency of the Contractor, or upon the acts, defaults, neglects, delays, breaches, non-observance or non-performance by the Contractor in respect of the works or any portion or details thereof, such power or authorities may be exercised from time to time, and not only in the event of the happening of such contingencies before the time limited in this contract for the completion of the works but also in the event of the same happening after the time so limited in the case of the Contractor being permitted to further proceed with the execution of the works.
Delays

28. The Contractor shall not have nor make any claim or demand, nor bring any action or suit or petition against His Majesty for any damage which he may sustain by reason of any delay or delays from whatever cause arising in the progress of the work.

No Implied Contracts

29. It is distinctly declared that no implied contract of any kind whatsoever by or on behalf of His Majesty shall arise or be implied from anything, in the contract documents contained or from any position or situation of the parties at any time, it being clearly understood and agreed that the express contract covenants and agreements therein contained and made by His Majesty are and shall be the only contracts, covenants and agreements upon which any rights against His Majesty are founded.

Parliamentary appropriations exhausted

30. Should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment for the work hereby contracted for be at any time expended previous to the completion of the works, the Minister or the Engineer may give the Contractor written notice to that effect. Upon receiving such notice the Contractor may, if he thinks fit, stop the work and shall not be entitled to any payment for work done beyond the amount voted and applicable as aforesaid, until the necessary funds shall have been voted by Parliament in that behalf. And in no event shall the Contractor have or make any claim on His Majesty for any damages or compensation by reason of the suspension of payment, or by reason of any delay or loss caused by the stoppage of the work. And in the event of the Contractor electing to proceed, or proceeding with such work after such notice, and before such additional funds are voted, no action of the Engineer, or of any other person on behalf of His Majesty, in giving orders, instructions or directions, or otherwise acting with respect to such work, shall be taken or considered as in any manner improving the rights of the Contractor or as waiving in any particular any of the provisions of this section.

Minister may suspend work

31. The Minister may, from time to time and for such period as he may deem expedient, delay or suspend, in whole or in part, operations under this contract, either upon the whole of the works, or at any particular point or points. Should any such delay or suspension, or the stoppage of the works under the provisions of Section 30, or should any delay caused by any circumstance which, in the opinion of the Engineer, is beyond the control of or not the fault of the Contractor, in the opinion of the Minister unreasonably limit the time for the completion of the works, within the time specified by this contract, the Minister as often as the case occurs shall allow such additional time as to him may seem sufficient in the extension of such time for completion; but no such delay, suspension or stoppage shall vitiate or avoid this contract, or any part thereof, or any security or obligations for the performance thereof, nor shall the Contractor be entitled to make any claim for damages by reason thereof. Upon the termination of such delay, suspension or stoppage, or upon the removal of the cause thereof, or upon the Contractor receiving notice from the Minister or Engineer requiring him to resume the work, he shall at once resume operations and diligently carry on the same.
Waiver negatived

32. No condoning, excusing or overlooking by His Majesty, or any person acting on his behalf, on previous occasions, or breaches, or defaults similar to that for which any action is taken or power exercised, or forfeiture is claimed or enforced against the Contractor, shall be taken to operate as a waiver of any provision of this contract, nor to defeat or prejudice in any way the right of His Majesty thereunder.

Members of H. of C. not to benefit

33. Pursuant to the provision of the Statute in such case made and provided, no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

No Public Ceremony

34. The Contractor shall not allow any public ceremony in connection with the work without having previously obtained the written permission of the Minister.

Liquors

35. The Contractor shall not bring nor permit to be brought anywhere on or, as far as the Contractor can prevent the same, near the works any spirituous or intoxicating liquor; and if any person employed on the works be, in the opinion of the Engineer, intemperate, disorderly, incompetent, wilfully negligent or dishonest in the performance of his duties, he shall, on the direction of the Engineer, be forthwith discharged and the Contractor shall not employ or permit to remain on the work any person who shall have been discharged for any or all of said causes.

Sanitation

36. The Contractor shall comply with, and the works shall be carried on subject to, all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said works, and all orders given by the Engineer with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the works. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, provide suitable privies and make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

Contractor to clean premises on completion

37. The Contractor shall upon the completion of the works, remove all temporary structures and clear away all rubbish and surplus and waste materials remaining on or about the works, and place the premises in a neat and tidy condition, satisfactory to the Engineer.

Damages to persons or property

38. The Contractor, his agents and all workmen and persons employed by him, or under his control, shall use due care that no person or property is injured and that no rights are infringed in the prosecution of the work, and the Contractor shall be solely responsible for all damages, by whomsoever claimable, in respect of any injury to persons or to lands, buildings, structures, fences, trees, crops, roads, ways, ships, or property of whatever description, and in respect of any infringement of any right, privilege or easement whatsoever, occasioned in the carrying on of the works or any part thereof, or by any neglect, misfeasance or nonfeasance on the Contractor's part or on the part of any of his agents.
workmen or persons employed by him or under his control, and shall at his own expense, make such temporary provisions as may be necessary to ensure the avoidance of any such damage, injury or infringement, and to prevent the interruption of or danger or menace to the traffic on any public or private road, and to secure to all persons and corporations the uninterrupted enjoyment of all their rights in and during the performance of the said works; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions, suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by or attributable to any such damage, injury or infringement.

Damages to work in progress. Contractor assumes risk

39. The Contractor shall be at the risk of, and shall bear all loss or damage whatsoever, from whatsoever cause arising, which may occur to the work, or any part thereof, until the same be finally accepted by the Minister, and if any such loss or damage occur before such final acceptance, the Contractor shall immediately, at his own expense, repair, restore and re-execute the work so damaged, so that the whole works, or their respective portions thereof, shall be completed within the time limited for completion thereof, and any delay occasioned by the Contractor to the other contractors on the work or any interference by the Contractor with the operations which may be a cause of delay or damage shall be rectified at the cost of, and the claim for damage or delay (if any) shall be at the charge of the Contractor.

Precautions as to fire

40. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the works and employ his own workmen, to the satisfaction and under the direction of the Engineer, in extinguishing all such fires which may occur; and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given, from time to time during construction, by the Engineer with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires, and shall pay all wages and other outlay occasioned by reason of the observance or compliance with such regulations and instructions.

Fire Insurance

41. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, at all times during construction and until the final acceptance of the work, keep all buildings and structures insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts equal to at least Eighty (80) per cent of the value of work done and materials accepted by the Engineer, as may be approved by the Chief, and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty may respectively appear, and shall be deposited with the Chief.

Protection of Workmen

42. The Contractor shall protect the Department from all claims that may arise from injury to, or sickness of, any workmen employed by him on the work.
Workmen's Compensation

43. The Contractor will be required to comply with the provisions of the Workmen's Compensation Act for the province in which the work is being carried on.

Payment by Contractor for Labour, etc.

44. The Contractor shall promptly pay for all labour, service and materials in or about the construction of the works, and all payments for such purposes shall be made by the Contractor, at least as often as payments are made to the Contractor by His Majesty under this contract, and in the event of failure by the Contractor at any time so to do, or if any sum due for labour of any foreman or workman, or for hire of horses, teams or carts upon or in respect of the works, or any part thereof, remain in arrears or unpaid, or if there be at any time found to exist any claims against the Contractors, or any sub-contractor, for labour, teams, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles or things employed, hired or supplied upon or for the works or any part thereof, or if the Minister has reason to believe that any such payments, sums or claims will not be promptly made or paid, the Minister may, in addition to or in lieu of exercising any powers conferred by the Labour Conditions, at his option, retain out of any moneys due or become due to the Contractor from His Majesty such amount or amounts as the Minister may deem sufficient to satisfy the same, or pay the Contractor the moneys due him in instalments, giving him from time to time such sums as the Minister or the Engineer deems sufficient to meet such payments, sums or claims or any of them, and with-holding the balance due him after deducting the payments so made. The Contractor shall be estopped from denying the accuracy and correctness of any and all payments so made by the Minister.

Books, etc., of Contractor open for inspection

45. The Contractor's pay-rolls, time-books, books of account, invoices and statements shall be at all times open for inspection and extract by the Engineer and any authorized representative of the Minister, or either of them who shall be assisted in every possible way by the Contractor, to enable the Engineer and such representative to ascertain, as far as possible, the exact payment, sums or claims so due and remaining unpaid by the Contractor.

Work to be free from all encumbrances

46. Before making any payment on any progress estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to satisfy the Engineer, or other authorized representative of His Majesty, that all work performed and materials supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kind of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished, or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

Statutory Declaration

47. Upon completion of the work, and before payment is made on any final estimate, certificate, or statement the Contractor shall submit to the Engineer, a statement attested by Statutory Declaration showing that all works performed and materials supplied are free of all lawful liens or claims.
Proofs required for default of Contractor

48. The Minister or the Engineer may, in their discretion, at any time require proof, with such formalities or to such extent as they may deem requisite, of any claim under the said Fair Wage Clauses or Schedules, or for wages or hire of teams in arrears or of accounts for materials, or other things unpaid.

Schedule of Unit Prices

49. The Contractor shall submit with his tender a detailed schedule of unit prices of all materials worked or in place, which shall, upon approval of the Engineer, be used as a basis of payments for all work under the contract.

Classification of Costs

50. There shall also be submitted at the same time, a classification of costs at the schedule of unit prices submitted, aggregating the total contract price. This schedule shall be so computed that all incidental charges shall be distributed over the various trade items as shown on the Departmental Progress Estimate form or as approved by the Chief Engineer, and shall be used as a basis for the Engineer's Monthly Progress Estimates.

Prices to be accepted as full compensation

51. The said price or prices shall be accepted by the Contractor as full compensation for everything furnished and done by the Contractor under this contract, including all work required but not included in the items hereinabove mentioned, and also for all loss or damage arising out of the nature of the works or the action of the weather, tides, elements, or any unforeseen obstruction or difficulty encountered in the prosecution of the work, and for all risks of every description connected with the works, and for all expenses incurred by or in connection with the works, and for all works, and for all expenses incurred by or in consequence of any delay or suspension or discontinuance of the work as herein specified, and for well and faithfully completing the works as in this contract provided.

Progress payments

52. Payments equal to about ninety per cent of the value of the work done, approximately estimated from progress measurements and computed at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, will be made to the Contractor monthly if practicable, on the written certificate of the Engineer, stating what the work for or on account of which the certificate is granted has been done, and stating the value of work computed as above mentioned; and the said certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid the said ninety per cent or any part thereof. The remaining ten per cent shall be retained till the final completion of the whole work to the satisfaction of the Engineer, and will be paid within two months after such completion. The written certificate of the said Engineer certifying to the final completion of the said works to his satisfaction, shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to receive or to be paid the remaining ten per cent or any part thereof.
Engineer in certifying values for progress payments may disregard price list

53. Provided always that, where in the opinion of the Engineer the work done is not sufficiently finished, or is not of sufficient value to justify payment at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, the Engineer may, for the purpose of such payment, disregard the price or prices agreed upon or determined, and may estimate the proportionate value payable in respect of such work and issue a certificate accordingly; in which case the Contractor shall only be entitled to receive ninety per cent of such estimated proportionate value as stated in such certificate, and shall not be paid the ninety per cent of the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, until such time as the Engineer, by reason of the performance of additional work, shall certify that the Contractor is entitled thereto.

Claims under progress certificate

54. It is intended that every allowance to which the Contractor is fairly entitled will be embraced in the Engineer's monthly certificate, but should the Contractor at any time have claims of any description which he considers are not included in the progress certificates, such claims must be made in writing to the Engineer within thirty days after the date of the delivery to him of the certificate from which he considers the items of such claims to have been omitted, but in no case beyond the period of sixty days from the date of the practical completion of that portion of the work to which such claims apply. And in default of the presentation of such claims within the times so limited the Minister may treat such claims as absolutely barred.

Claims, evidence of accuracy

55. The Contractor in presenting claims of the kind referred to in the last preceding clause must accompany them with satisfactory evidence of their accuracy and the reason why he thinks they should be allowed.

Payment for additional or extra work

56. Payment for any work or additional work done, or materials or things provided, under the written orders of the Engineer, for which no price or prices are named, and which is not covered by the contract, His Majesty, in consideration and subject, as aforesaid, will pay to the Contractor the actual and reasonable cost, as determined by the Engineer, of such work, materials and things, with an additional ten per cent thereon for the use of tools, Contractor's plant, superintendence and profits.

Approximate quantities

57. The quantities (if any) given are approximate only and no claim shall be made by the Contractor against His Majesty on account of any excess or deficiency, absolute or relative, in the same.

Progress measurements and certificates not binding

58. The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Engineer, or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts: they are to be subject to the revision of the Engineer in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
Rectification

59. Should it subsequently be found that inferior materials or workmanship have been incorporated into the works, or that the contract has been departed from in any way, the Contractor shall be responsible for making good, without expense to the Department, any defects together with any and all damages that may have resulted from such defects.

PROVIDED, notice shall be given the Contractor regarding such defects within a period of one (1) year after date of the final certificate of the completion of the work.

PROVIDED, the period stipulated in any guarantee given by the Contractor has not expired.

Extension of time

60. Any extension of time requested by the Contractor due to circumstances beyond his control delaying the work, shall be made in writing, to the Chief Engineer, at least 10 days before expiration of the contract; Any extension of time that may be granted to the Contractor shall be so granted and accepted without prejudice to any rights of His Majesty whatsoever, under this contract, and no assent thereto on the part of the Contractor shall be necessary.

Minister sole judge of reasonableness of extension of time for completion

61. Provided always that after the expiration of the time limited for the completion of the works the Minister shall be sole judge as to what additional time, if any, may be allowed to the Contractor for such completion, and his decision as to the reasonableness or sufficiency thereof for the purpose of completion shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

Notice; how given

17. Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman, addressed to the address mentioned in this contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence. Every such notice, order, direction or communication shall be sufficient which expresses in general language and without detail the matters required or communicated, or which follows the general language of the section or sections of this contract under which it is given, and no objection shall be taken to the form thereof.

Foreman of the Works

18. A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during all the working hours, to receive the orders of the Engineer. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor, and shall have full power to carry out all requisitions and instructions of the said Engineer, but this clause shall not relieve the Contractor from the duty of personally superintending the work.
Engineer sole judge of work and material

19. The Engineer shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of this contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specification shall be final, and no work under this contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Engineer is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid therefor.

Quality

20. The works shall be constructed by the Contractor and under his personal supervision, of new materials throughout; the best materials of their several kinds, and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in the manner required by and in strict conformity with this contract, the said specifications and special plans and specifications, and the plans and drawings relating thereto, and the working or detail drawings which may from time to time be furnished, which said specifications and special plans and drawings are hereby declared to be part of this contract.

Defective work or material

21. Should the Contractor use or employ, or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools, equipment, articles or things which, in the opinion of the Engineer are not in accordance with the provisions of this contract or are in any way unsuitable for the works, or any part thereof, or should the Engineer consider that any work is for any reason, improperly defective or insufficiently executed or performed the Engineer may order the Contractor to remove the same and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things, or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders; and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours, the Engineer may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed, the orders so given and the Contractor shall, on demand, pay to His Majesty all costs, damages and expenses incurred in respect thereof, or occasioned to His Majesty by reason of the non-compliance by the Contractor with any such orders, or His Majesty may, in the discretion of the Minister, retain and deduct such costs, damages and expenses from any amounts then or thereafter payable to the Contractor.

Insufficient workmen, plant, etc.

22. If the Engineer shall at any time consider the number of workmen, horses, quantity of machinery, tools, plant or equipment, or of proper materials articles or things, respectively, employed or provided by the Contractor on or for the said works to be insufficient for the advancement of such works or any part thereof towards completion within the time limited in respect thereof, or that the works or some parts thereof, are not being carried on with due diligence, then, and in every such case, the Engineer may, in writing, order the Contractor to employ, or provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may think necessary, and in case the Contractor shall not within three days, or such other longer period as may be fixed by any such order, in all respects comply therewith, the Engineer may employ and provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, as he may think proper, and
may pay such additional workmen such wages, and for such additional horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, any such prices as he may think proper and all such amounts so paid shall, on demand, be repaid to His Majesty by the Contractor, or the same may be retained or deducted from any sum that may then or thereafter be or become due from His Majesty to the Contractor. The Contractor shall employ the additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things so provided and employed by the Engineer in the diligent advancement of the works; the workmen and horses so provided shall, however, be thereafter subject to discharge by the Contractor, but only with the consent and approval of the Engineer.

Contractor's machinery, plant, etc.

23. All machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever provided by the Contractor or by the Engineer under the provisions of sections 21 and 22 for the works, and not rejected under the provisions of section 21 shall from the time of their being so provided, become and until the final completion of the said work, shall be the property of His Majesty for the purpose of the said works, and the same shall on no account be taken away, removed, or disposed of, except for the purposes of the said works, without the consent in writing of the Engineer. His Majesty shall not, however, be answerable for any loss or damage whatever which may at any time happen to such machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles or things. Upon the completion of the works and upon payment by the Contractor of all such moneys lost, cost and damages, if any, as shall be due from the Contractor to His Majesty, or chargeable against the Contractor under this contract, such of the said machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things as shall not have been used and converted in the works or disposed of by His Majesty under powers conferred in this contract, shall, upon demand, be delivered up to the Contractor in such condition as they may then be in.

Work not comprised in contract

24. His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the works other contractors and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in this contract, and the Contractor shall afford to them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Engineer may deem practical.

The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the works of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed an acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the works comprised in this contract.

Co-operation with other Contractors

25. That whenever and so often as it may be necessary for the Contractor to co-operate with other contractors on this work, or any or either of them, the Contractor shall willingly and under the directions of the Engineer perform all such works as shall be requisite and proper on the part of the Contractor herein for such co-operation and for securing and placing in proper position the portion necessary herein and hereby contracted to be constructed and erected for the proposed work in a proper and secure mode, and to prevent the possibility of any accident therefrom without any extra charge therefor, and shall be bound in all things to conform to the direction of the Minister or the Engineer touching such cooperation and work.

Default or delay by Contractor

26. In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the works or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under this contract, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, the Engineer may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay; and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Engineer to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in the completion of the works, or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent, or abandon the work, or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required, or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of this contract, then and in any of such cases the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such means as he, on His Majesty's behalf, may see fit to complete the works, and in such case the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment in respect of work performed, but shall be chargeable therewith and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the works, and no objection or claim shall be raised or made by the Contractor by reason or on account of the ultimate cost of the work so taken over, for any reason proving greater than in the opinion of the Contractor it should have been; and all materials, articles and things whatsoever, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights, proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Engineer under the provisions of this contract shall remain and be the property of His Majesty for all purposes incidental to the completion of the works, and may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty as fully to all intents and purposes connected with the works as they might therefore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor; and the Minister may also, at his option, on behalf of His Majesty, sell or otherwise dispose of at forced sale prices, or at public auction or private sale, otherwise, the whole or any portion or number of such materials, articles, things, horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment at such price or prices as he may see fit, and detain the proceeds of any such sale or disposition and all other amounts then or thereafter due by His Majesty to the Contractor on account of, or in part satisfaction of any loss or damage which His Majesty may sustain or have sustained by reason aforesaid.

Power to take action in default of Contractor

27. Whenever in this contract power or authority is given to His Majesty, the Minister, the Engineer, or any person on behalf of His Majesty, to take any action consequent upon the insolvency of the Contractor, or upon the acts, defaults, neglects, delays, breaches, non-observance or non-performance by the Contractor in respect of the works or any portion or details thereof, such power or authorities may be exercised from time to time, not only in the event of the happening of such contingencies before the time limited in this contract for the completion of the works but also in the event of the same happening after the time so limited in the case of the Contractor being permitted to further proceed with the execution of the works.
Delays

28. The Contractor shall not have nor make any claim or demand, nor bring any action or suit or petition against His Majesty for any damage which he may sustain by reason of any delay or delays from whatever cause arising in the progress of the work.

No Implied Contracts

29. It is distinctly declared that no implied contract of any kind whatsoever by or on behalf of His Majesty shall arise or be implied from anything, in the contract documents contained or from any position or situation of the parties at any time, it being clearly understood and agreed that the express contract covenants and agreements therein contained and made by His Majesty are and shall be the only contracts, covenants and agreements upon which any rights against His Majesty are founded.

Parliamentary appropriations exhausted

30. Should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment for the work hereby contracted for be at any time expended previous to the completion of the works, the Minister or the Engineer may give the Contractor written notice to that effect. Upon receiving such notice the Contractor may, if he thinks fit, stop the work, but shall not be entitled to any payment for work done beyond the amount voted and applicable as aforesaid, until the necessary funds shall have been voted by Parliament in that behalf. And in no event shall the Contractor have or make any claim on His Majesty for any damages or compensation by reason of the suspension of payment, or by reason of any delay or loss caused by the stoppage of the work. And in the event of the Contractor electing to proceed, or proceeding with such work after such notice, and before such additional funds are voted, no action of the Engineer, or of any other person on behalf of His Majesty, in giving orders, instructions or directions, or otherwise acting with respect to such work, shall be taken or considered as in any manner improving the rights of the Contractor or as waiving in any particular any of the provisions of this section.

Minister may suspend work

31. The Minister may, from time to time and for such period as he may deem expedient, delay or suspend, in whole or in part, operations under this contract, either upon the whole of the works, or at any particular point or points. Should any such delay or suspension, or the stoppage of the works under the provisions of Section 30, or should any delay caused by any circumstance which, in the opinion of the Engineer, is beyond the control of or not the fault of the Contractor, in the opinion of the Minister unreasonably limit the time for the completion of the works, within the time specified by this contract, the Minister as often as the case occurs shall allow such additional time as to him may seem sufficient in the extension of such time for completion; but no such delay, suspension or stoppage shall vitiate or avoid this contract, or any part thereof, or any security or obligations for the performance thereof, nor shall the Contractor be entitled to make any claim for damages by reason thereof. Upon the termination of such delay, suspension or stoppage, or upon the removal of the cause thereof, or upon the Contractor receiving notice from the Minister or Engineer requiring him to resume the work, he shall at once resume operations and diligently carry on the same.
Waiver negatived

32. No condoning, excusing or overlooking by His Majesty, or any person acting on his behalf, on previous occasions, or breaches, or defaults similar to that for which any action is taken or power exercised, or forfeiture is claimed or enforced against the Contractor, shall be taken to operate as a waiver of any provision of this contract nor to defeat or prejudice in any way the right of His Majesty thereunder.

Members of H. of C. not to benefit

33. Pursuant to the provision of the Statute in such case made and provided, no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

No Public Ceremony

34. The Contractor shall not allow any public ceremony in connection with the work without having previously obtained the written permission of the Minister.

Liquors

35. The Contractor shall not bring nor permit to be brought anywhere on or, as far as the Contractor can prevent the same, near the works any spirituous or intoxicating liquor; and if any person employed on the works be, in the opinion of the Engineer, intemperate, disorderly, incompetent, wilfully negligent or dishonest in the performance of his duties, he shall, on the direction of the Engineer, be forthwith discharged and the Contractor shall not employ or permit to remain on the work any person who shall have been discharged for any or all of said causes.

Sanitation

36. The Contractor shall comply with, and the works shall be carried on subject to, all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said works, and all orders given by the Engineer with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the works. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, provide suitable privies and make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

Contractor to clean premises on completion

37. The Contractor shall upon the completion of the works, remove all temporary structures and clear away all rubbish and surplus and waste materials remaining on or about the works, and place the premises in a neat and tidy condition, satisfactory to the Engineer.

Damages to persons or property

38. The Contractor, his agents and all workmen and persons employed by him, or under his control, shall use due care that no person or property is injured and that no rights are infringed in the prosecution of the work, and the Contractor shall be solely responsible for all damages by whomsoever claimable, in respect of any injury to persons or to lands, buildings, structures, fences, trees, crops, roads, ways, ships, or property of whatever description, and in respect of any infringement of any right, privilege or easement whatsoever, occasioned in the carrying on of the works or any part thereof, or by any neglect, misfeasance or nonfeasance on the Contractor's part or on the part of any of his agents,
