workmen or persons employed by him or under his control, and shall at his own expense, make such temporary provisions as may be necessary to ensure the avoidance of any such damage, injury or infringement and to prevent the interruption of or danger or menace to the traffic on any public or private road, and to secure to all persons and corporations the uninterrupted enjoyment of all their rights in and during the performance of the said works; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions, suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by or attributable to any such damage, injury or infringement.

Damage to work in progress. Contractor assumes risk

39. The Contractor shall be at the risk of, and shall bear all loss or damage whatsoever, from whatsoever cause arising, which may occur to the work, or any part thereof, until the same be finally accepted by the Minister, and if any such loss or damage occur before such final acceptance, the Contractor shall immediately, at his own expense, repair, restore and re-execute the work so damaged, so that the whole works, or their respective portions thereof, shall be completed within the time limited for completion thereof, and any delay occasioned by the Contractor to the other contractors on the work or any interference by the Contractor with the operations which may be a cause of delay or damage shall be rectified at the cost of, and the claim for damage or delay (if any) shall be at the charge of the Contractor.

Precautions as to fire

40. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the works and employ his own workmen to the satisfaction and under the direction of the Engineer in extinguishing all such fires which may occur; and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires and with all regulations and instructions made and given, from time to time during construction, by the Engineer with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires, and shall pay all wages and other outlay occasioned by reason of the observance or compliance with such regulations and instructions.

Fire Insurance

41. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, at all times during construction and until the final acceptance of the work, keep all buildings and structures insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts equal to at least Eighty (80) per cent of the value of work done and materials accepted by the Engineer, as may be approved by the Chief, and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty may respectively appear, and shall be deposited with the Chief.

Protection of Workmen

42. The Contractor shall protect the Department from all claims that may arise from injury to, or sickness of, any workmen employed by him on the work.
Workmen's Compensation

43. The Contractor will be required to comply with the provisions of the Workmen's Compensation Act for the province in which the work is being carried on.

Payment by Contractor for Labour, etc.

44. The Contractor shall promptly pay for all labour, service and materials in or about the construction of the works, and all payments for such purposes shall be made by the Contractor, at least as often as payments are made to the Contractor by His Majesty under this contract, and in the event of failure by the Contractor at any time so to do, or if any sum due for work of any foreman or workman, or for hire of horses, teams or carts upon or in respect of the works, or any part thereof, remains in arrears or unpaid, or if there be at any time found to exist any claims against the Contractor, or any sub-contractor, for labour, teams, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles or things employed, hired or supplied upon or for the works or any part thereof, or if the Minister has reason to believe that any such payments, sums or claims will not be promptly made or paid, the Minister may, in addition to or in lieu of exercising any powers conferred by the Labour Conditions, at his option, retain out of any moneys due or become due to the Contractor from His Majesty such amount or amounts as the Minister may deem sufficient to satisfy the same, or pay the Contractor the moneys due him in instalments, giving him from time to time such sums as the Minister or the Engineer deems sufficient to meet such payments, sums or claims or any of them, and withholding the balance due him after deducting the payments so made. The Contractor shall be stopped from denying the accuracy and correctness of any and all payments so made by the Minister.

Books, etc., of Contractor open for inspection

45. The Contractor's pay-rolls, time-books, books of account, invoices and statements shall be at all times open for inspection and extract by the Engineer and any authorized representative of the Minister, or either of them who shall be assisted in every possible way by the Contractor, to enable the Engineer and such representative to ascertain, as far as possible, the exact payment, sums or claims so due and remaining unpaid by the Contractor.

Work to be free from all encumbrances

46. Before making any payment on any progress estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to satisfy the Engineer, or other authorized representative of His Majesty, that all work performed and materials supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kind of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished, or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

Statutory Declaration

47. Upon completion of the work, and before payment is made on any final estimate, certificate, or statement the Contractor shall submit to the Engineer, a statement attested by Statutory Declaration showing that all works performed and materials supplied are free of all lawful liens or claims.
Proofs required for default of Contractor

48. The Minister or the Engineer may, in their discretion, at any time require proof, with such formalities or to such extent as they may deem requisite, of any claim under the said Fair Wage Clauses or Schedules, or for wages or hire of teams in arrears or of accounts for materials, or other things unpaid.

Schedule of Unit Prices

49. The Contractor shall submit with his tender a detailed schedule of unit prices of all materials worked or in place, which shall, upon approval of the Engineer, be used as a basis of payments for all work under the contract.

Classification of Costs

50. There shall also be submitted at the same time, a classification of costs at the schedule of unit prices submitted, aggregating the total contract price. This schedule shall be so computed that all incidental charges shall be distributed over the various trade items as shown on the Departmental Progress Estimate form or as approved by the Chief Engineer, and shall be used as a basis for the Engineer's Monthly Progress Estimates.

Prices to be accepted as full compensation

51. The said price or prices shall be accepted by the Contractor as full compensation for everything furnished and done by the Contractor under this contract, including all work required but not included in the items hereinabove mentioned, and also for all loss or damage arising out of the nature of the works or the action of the weather, sides, floods, etc., any unforeseen obstruction or difficulty encountered in the prosecution of the work, and for all risks of every description connected with the works, and for all expenses incurred by or in connection with the works, and for all works, and for all expenses incurred by or in consequence of any delay or suspension or discontinuance of the work as herein specified, and for well and faithfully completing the works as in this contract provided.

Progress payments

52. Payments equal to about ninety per cent of the value of the work done, approximately estimated from progress measurements and computed at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract will be made to the Contractor monthly if practicable, on the written certificates of the Engineer, stating what work has been done and stating the value of work computed as above mentioned; and the said certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid the said ninety per cent or any part thereof. The remaining ten per cent shall be retained till the final completion of the whole work to the satisfaction of the Engineer, and will be paid within two months after such completion. The written certificate of the said Engineer certifying to the final completion of the said works to his satisfaction, shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to receive or to be paid the remaining ten per cent or any part thereof.
Engineer in certifying values for progress payments may disregard price list

53. Provided always that, where in the opinion of the Engineer the work done is not sufficiently finished, or is not of sufficient value to justify payment at the prices or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, the Engineer may, for the purpose of such payment, disregard the price or prices hereupon determined and may estimate the proportionate value payable in respect of such work and issue a certificate accordingly; in which case the Contractor shall only be entitled to receive ninety per cent of such estimated proportionate value as stated in such certificate, and shall not be paid the ninety per cent of the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, until such time as the Engineer, by reason of the performance of additional work, shall certify that the Contractor is entitled thereto.

Claims under progress certificate

54. It is intended that every allowance to which the Contractor is fairly entitled will be embraced in the Engineer's monthly certificate, but should the Contractor at any time have claims of any description which he considers are not included in the progress certificates, such claims must be made in writing to the Engineer within thirty days after the date of the delivery to him of the certificate from which he considers the items of such claims to have been omitted, but in no case beyond the period of sixty days from the date of the practical completion of that portion of the work to which such claims apply. And in default of the presentation of such claims within the times so limited the Minister may treat such claims as absolutely barred.

Claims, evidence of accuracy

55. The Contractor in presenting claims of the kind referred to in the last preceding clause must accompany them with satisfactory evidence of their accuracy and the reason why he thinks they should be allowed.

Payment for additional or extra work

56. Payment for any work or additional work done, or materials or things provided, under the written orders of the Engineer, for which no price or prices are named, and which is not covered by the contract, His Majesty, in consideration of the object, as aforesaid, will pay to the Contractor the actual and reasonable cost, as determined by the Engineer, of such work, materials and things, with an additional ten per cent thereon for the use of tools, Contractor's plant, superintendence and profits.

Approximate quantities

57. The quantities (if any) given are approximate only and no claim shall be made by the Contractor against His Majesty on account of any excess or deficiency, absolute or relative, in the same.

Progress measurements and certificates not binding

58. The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Engineer, or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Engineer in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
Rectification

59. Should it subsequently be found that inferior materials or workmanship have been incorporated into the works, or that the contract has been departed from in any way, the Contractor shall be responsible for making good, without expense to the Department, any defects together with any and all damages that may have resulted from such defects.

PROVIDED, notice shall be given the Contractor regarding such defects within a period of one (1) year after date of the final certificate of the completion of the work.

PROVIDED, the period stipulated in any guarantee given by the Contractor has not expired.

Extension of time

60. Any extension of time requested by the Contractor due to circumstances beyond his control delaying the work, shall be made in writing, to the Chief Engineer, at least 10 days before expiration of the contract; Any extension of time that may be granted to the Contractor shall be so granted and accepted without prejudice to any rights of His Majesty whatsoever, under this contract, and no assent thereto on the part of the Contractor shall be necessary.

Minister sole judge of reasonableness of extension of time for completion

61. Provided always that after the expiration of the time limited for the completion of the works the Minister shall be sole judge as to what additional time, if any, may be allowed to the Contractor for such completion, and his decision as to the reasonableness or sufficiency thereof for the purpose of completion shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

EXCAVATION AND DRAINAGE

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

1. CLEARING SITE:- The Contractor shall examine site and before any work is commenced shall clear and free the site of all obstructions, remove all trees and other obstructions as required for the site of the building.

2. SETTING OUT OF WORK:- The Contractor shall obtain exact highway line and refer to the Plot Plans and set out of the work as for size, locations, depths, and grades.

The Contractor shall employ a competent person during the construction of the building to establish all lines, levels, column centres, etc. No work shall be proceeded with until such lines, levels and centres have been approved by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works.

The building shall be placed on the site as indicated by the Plot Plan, Sheet No. 1 of the drawings. The site is considered generally flat. The excavation from the basement shall be graded around the premises to a height of about 1'6", which will require that amount of loss excavation as shown by the sections. The premises all around shall be graded using the top soil of the excavation, and shall all be left ready for sod or seeding.

3. SCOPE OF WORK:- The excavation work required under this contract shall be the excavating of all trenches, footings, basements, piers, drains, etc., as required for all of the building, as shown by the Plot Plan, septic tank, flag pole base and sump, all as shown and required by the several drawings and sections thereof.

4. EXCAVATION AND DISPOSAL:- The Contractor shall examine the Plot Plan together with the site, and shall make any further necessary soil tests at his own expense if required. All excavation shall be to the depths indicated by the several sections on the several plans. Excavate for all footings, walls, piers, drains for sewer and water, drains for water supply from lake, and all excavation for all inside and outside piping. All excavation shall be carried to depths shown on the drawings. Excavate for drains both inside and outside for all traces to such depths as directed, to insure proper fall. All excavation for main walls shall be 12" larger on all sides than the size of buildings, to allow for proper execution of the work. Do all refilling after all drains have been inspected. Excavate for roads, driveway and walks as required.

All excavation shall be levelled on the site where directed and refilled, packed, rolled and graded to the approval of the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works.

Should it be necessary to do any blasting, this Contractor shall employ competent persons and all precautions shall be taken to prevent damage to property or injury to persons or animals. The Contractor shall be held solely responsible for all accidents to life or property.

5. UNIT PRICE - EXTRA EXCAVATION:- When the excavations have been completed to the various depths and extent as shown on or required by the drawings for the proper installation of the work, the Contractor shall immediately notify the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works so that he may have the same inspected and tested if necessary. If in the opinion of the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works it should be found necessary, the excavations shall be carried to a greater depth or extent than shown on drawings and the Contractor will be entitled to additional payment only for such extra excavated material as authorized. The Contractor will be held responsible and will not be entitled to extra payment should he carry the excavations to a greater depth or extent without authority from the supervising architect or Clerk of Works.

Each pipe shall be closely butted into the socket of the preceding pipe, and special care must be taken that any excess cement is neatly cleaned off as each joint is made.
Any earth, cement or material is to be thoroughly cleaned out of the pipes by drawing a closely fitting wad through them as the work proceeds.

CONCRETE WORK

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

SCOPE OF WORK: The work required to be done under this Contract will be all the concrete work of all walls, footings, piers, septic tank and sump, concrete stops and slabs, all as shown by the several drawings hereto attached and as hereinafter specified.

1. PORTLAND CEMENT: All cement shall be first-class Portland cement of a standard brand, bearing a good reputation and of uniform quality. It shall be free from lumps and be packed in barrels or strong cloth sacks. Each package shall have printed upon it the brand and name of the Manufacturer. All cement shall conform with the requirements of the Standard Specification for Portland cement of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association. The cement shall be protected from the weather and the floor upon which it is placed shall be at least 12" above the ground. It shall be stored so as to permit of easy access for inspection and identification of each shipment. A sufficient quantity shall be kept on hand at all times so that tests may be made to determine its quality. At least 12 days shall be allowed for inspection and the necessary test. The Contractor shall furnish mill cement tests from start to finish and hand same to the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works from time to time during the construction.

2. FINE AGGREGATE: The fine aggregate used for making concrete shall be clean sand, free from clay, loam, mud and other impurities and shall be washed if required. It shall be well graded mixture of coarse and fine grains with the coarse grains predominating and shall be screened to remove all particles not passing a ¼" mesh.

3. COARSE AGGREGATE: The coarse aggregate used for making concrete shall be hard, compact and durable broken stone of approved quality free from dirt and graded to size ranging from ¼" to 1½" for concrete referred to as Class "B" and ¼" to 1½" for concrete referred to as Class "A."

4. WATER: Provide a supply of clean, fresh water for use of all the works.

5. STRENGTH OF CONCRETE: All concrete for exterior basement walls, footings and basement floor slab shall have a compressive strength at the age of 28 days of 3000 lbs. per square inch with a water cement ratio of 4½ Imperial Gallons of water per 87½ lbs. net sack of cement.

6. WATER-CEMENT RATIO: All concrete must be proportioned to give the necessary workability without exceeding the quantities of mixing water stipulated in Clause 5. This water-cement ratio is the maximum permissible. The mixers shall be proportioned for somewhat lower ratios so that with the normal fluctuations from batch-to-batch this ratio will not be exceeded. Moisture contained in the aggregate must be included as part of the mixing water in computing the water-cement ratio.

The water-cement ratio shall not be changed except when directed by the Department's Representative. In the event of such change being ordered, the Contractor shall do so without extra cost to the Government.

7. CONCRETE PROPORTIONS: The proportions of aggregate to cement for concrete of the water-cement ratio specified shall be such as to produce concrete of the consistency specified hereafter.
The approximate proportion of the volume of cement to the sum of the separate volumes of fine and coarse aggregate measured dry is one of cement to 4 parts of aggregate and shall be adjusted to give proper workability. The supervising Architect or the Clerk of Works reserves the right to increase or diminish the proportions of aggregate if found necessary, without extra cost to the Government. All concrete referred to as Class "A" shall have coarse aggregate of a maximum size of 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inches and referred to as Class "B" shall have coarse aggregate of a maximum size of 2\(\frac{1}{2}\)" inches. Combined aggregate shall be such composition of sizes that when separated by the \#4 sieve the weight retained on the sieve shall be not less than one-third nor more than two-thirds of the total.

The proportions of fine and coarse aggregate shall be such that the ratio of the fine to total shall be not less nor more than that given in the following table, nor shall the amount of coarse material be such as to produce harshness in placing or honey-combing:

| Maximum size of coarse aggregate | Ratio of fine to total aggregate on basis of dry and compact volumes |
|---------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|
| inches                          | Minimum | Maximum |
| 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" (Class "A" concrete) | .30     | .50     |

In case the concrete resulting from a mixture of aggregates approaching the extreme limits of gradation is not of a workable character, or when finished does not exhibit a proper surface, the Contractor shall alter the grading as will be directed by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works, the water-cement ratio remaining constant.

8. CONTROL OF PROPORTIONS:- The methods of measuring materials shall be such that the proportions of water to cement can be easily controlled during the progress of the work and easily checked at any time. The aggregates shall be of uniform quality and grading and shall be delivered to the building and handled in such a manner that variations in moisture content shall not occur.

9. MIXING:- All materials for concrete are to be mixed by a mechanical batch mixer of approved type equipped with suitable charging hopper, reservoirs and measuring devices for all materials. The rim speed of the mixer shall be not less than 200' per minute and the charge not exceeding the manufacturer's rated capacity. The mixing of each batch shall continue for not less than three minutes after all the materials are in the mixer. No hand mixing of concrete will be permitted.

10. CONSISTENCY:- The concrete shall be of a plastic consistency which shall be so established by the Department's Representative who may employ the slump test for maintaining the consistency required.

11. SLUMP TESTS:- The Contractor shall provide a metal form of #20 gauge galvanized iron for making slump tests also a 5/8" metal rod 21" long. The form shall be 4" diameter at the top and 8" diameter at the bottom and 12" high. Tests shall be made by the Contractor in the presence of the Inspector, once or twice daily, as may be directed by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works. The slump shall be from 2" to 4" for plain concrete and 4" to 6" for reinforced concrete. All test samples shall be dated and stored where directed by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works, and shipped.

PAINTING AND GLAZING WORK

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

1. PAINTING:- This Contractor shall carefully examine the plans of the buildings and the specifications of other trades to ascertain the amount and character of the work required to be painted, such as carpentry, sheet metal, iron work, etc. This Contractor shall include for painting all exposed plumbing and heating pipes and cooking, also all radiators and the outside of plumbing fixtures that are not enamelled.

2. PREPARATION FOR PAINTING:- This Contractor shall go over the building to see that all nail heads in finished woodwork have been countersunk, that all work has been properly executed and that all is ready for painting. Unless this Contractor notifies the Clerk of Works or the Contractor before starting, it will be assumed that all work is in proper condition for painting, and he will be held responsible for delivering workmanship that is perfect in every way.

The walls and ceilings of all buildings are finished with 3/8" gypsum board. The Contractor shall prepare a mastic and putty preparation which shall be made for this purpose and shall go over all joints and intersections of all gypsum board, walls and ceilings, in such a way that when the painting is done, no marks of joints will be shown. All colours shall be submitted by the Contractor and approved by the Department. The Contractor shall prepare samples of such tints or from samples furnished.

3. MATERIALS:- All materials used in the work shall be the very best of their respective kinds, and shall be applied in a workmanlike manner.

4. WORKMANSHIP:- All material shall be delivered at the work in the original packages with the seal unbroken and applied according to Manufacturer's specifications, unless otherwise specified. All surface shall be thoroughly dry before Painters begin work. No coat shall be applied before the preceding one is thoroughly dry. All paint shall be evenly spread and well brushed, so that there will be no drops, runs or sagging of materials. After the priming is applied, all nail holes and other defects shall be putty stopped with putty coloured to match the woodwork after staining. All interior finished woodwork will be back-painted one coat of lead and oil, and exterior woodwork primed upon all faces and edges as the case may require, before leaving mill, by the Carpenter Contractor.

5. PAINTING PIPES:- All exposed plumbing and heating pipes and outside of unglazed plumbing fixtures and radiators shall be given one coat of red lead and linseed oil and two coats white lead and linseed oil. All piping shall be finished in the same colours as the adjoining wall surfaces.

- All outside window frames and sash
- All outside wood finish
- All interior woodwork not otherwise specified

7. EXTERIOR PAINTING:- All exterior woodwork shall receive three coats of lead and oil paint such shades as will be selected. Galvanized iron work and other metal work shall receive two coats of special metal paint.

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

1. **SCOPE OF WORK:** The work required under this contract will be the covering of all roofs with tar, felt and gravel as hereinafter specified. All timemitting and ventilation work is also required under this contract.

2. **GENERAL:** The roofing Contractor shall examine the roof decks before commencing the work and arrange with the General Contractor to rectify any defects. He shall also co-operate with other trades in placing of flashing, ventilation, etc.

All roof work shall be done in a neat and workmanlike manner free from defects and left perfect on completion.

3. **INSULATION:** Insulation of all roofs as shown on the several sections and drawings shall be as provided under the Carpenter and Joinery Trade.

4. **ROOFING:** Over roof deck as specified under the Carpentry Specification, lay one thickness of sheathing paper or unsaturated felt lapping, the sheets at least one inch. Over this lay two plies of fifteen pound tarred rag felt lapping, each sheet 19 inches over preceding one and nail as often as necessary to hold in place until remaining felt is laid; coat the entire surface uniformly with pitch, then over the entire surface, lay third plies of tarred felt lapping, each sheet 24" over preceding one mopping with pitch the full 24" lap on each sheet so that in no place shall felt touch felt. Such nailing as is necessary shall be done along the upper edge of each sheet so that all nails will be covered by not less than two plies of felt. Over the entire surface, pour from a dipper a uniform coating of pitch into which, while hot, embed not less than 400 pounds of gravel for each hundred square feet. The gravel shall be from #4 to 5/8" in size, dry and free from dirt. Care shall be taken during the application that felt is laid without wrinkles or buckles. Not less than 150 pounds of pitch shall be used for the construction of each 100 sq. ft. of completed roof, and the pitch shall not be heated above 400 degrees Fahrenheit. At the edge of all roofs, the felt shall be turned down over fascia at cornice 3" and trimmed off neatly. At the intersection of horizontal and vertical surfaces, flash walls and roof as shown on the drawings.

The engine shall be equipped with radiator cooling, using a blower fan to discharge the cooling air outside the powerhouse.

7. CONDENSATE PUMPING UNITS:- The condensate pumping units will be automatic in operation and shall be single or duplex as shown on the drawings. They will be vertical or horizontal type as indicated.

Horizontal units shall consist of one or two pumps, each direct-connected to their motors with a single receiver, all mounted on a suitable cast iron or steel base. The pumps shall be of the Centrifugal or Turbine type, bronze fitted throughout with impellers of bronze or corrosion resistant metal as approved by the Department. The pumps shall be free from air binding when handling condensate with temperatures up to 200 degs. F. Motors will be drip-proof or completely protected motors. Receivers shall be of no less than 3/16 inch thick black iron or steel and shall be provided with all the necessary reinforced threaded openings, including condensate return vent, overflow and pump suction connections. Receivers shall have an approved rust resisting coating on the inside. The vent pipe shall be galvanized steel and the fittings shall be galvanized malleable iron. The vent pipe shall be extended so as to provide against damage through escaping steam or water. Basket type cast iron dirt strainers will be supplied at the inlet of each pump. Vertical Units will conform to the above, except that the pumps and motors will be for vertical operation, and the pumps will be constructed for operation submerged in hot water. Bearings and glands will be suitable for such operation.

Float switches will have copper ball floats tested to not less than 25 pounds pressure and shall have an overload relay incorporated in the switch. Float rods will have stuffing boxes; float will be of adequate size to operate the float switches without binding or sticking.

The pumping units shall be tested by the manufacturer before shipment and a certified copy of the test data of each pump shall be submitted to the engineer. Pumps shall be tested with hot water at 200 degs. F.

8. PIPING:- Pipe shall be cut accurately to measurements established at the building and shall be worked into place without springing or forcing, properly clearing all windows, doors and other openings. Risers to upper floors will be run exposed and also run-outs on the ceilings below. Every effort will be made to preserve the appearance of the rooms or spaces in which the piping runs. Excessive cutting or other weakening of the building structure to facilitate piping installation will not be permitted. All pipes shall have burrs removed by reaming and shall be so installed as to permit free expansion and contraction without damage to joints or hangers.

All changes in direction shall be made with fittings, except the bending of pipe up to and including two inch nominal diameter shall be permitted, provided a hydraulic pipe bender is used. Bent pipe showing kinks, wrinkles or other malformations will not be acceptable. All boiler outlets shall be run full size to the main or header. All horizontal mains shall pitch down in the direction of flow with a grade of not less than 1 inch in 40 feet or as shown on drawings. Piping connections or equipment shall be in accordance with details shown on the drawings or as directed by the engineer. All openings of pipe lines or equipment shall be properly capped or plugged during installation to keep dirt or other foreign material out of the system. All pipe not otherwise specified shall be uncoated. Fittings smaller than 4" shall be screwed. Fittings 4" and larger shall be flanged. Fittings

may be welded as specified below. Unless otherwise specified, or shown on drawings, final connection to all appliances shall be made with black malleable iron unions for pipe 3 inches in diameter or less and 1/4 flanges for all pipe 3½ inches in diameter or more.

All pipe will be new, black, wrought iron pipe except cold water pipe, which will be galvanized. All piping will be designed for steam working pressure of 125 pounds per square inch gauge.

All joints between sections of pipe and between pipe and fittings 1½ inches and larger may be fusion-welded. The welding shall be in accordance with the recommendations of the American Welding Society or other recognized authority. All changes in direction and intersections of lines shall be made with welding fittings except as otherwise specifically permitted hereinbefore. Mitering of pipe to form elbows, notching straight runs to form tees, or any similar construction will not be permitted. Welding fittings shall be installed on all welded lines.

Gaskets for flanged connections shall be of 1/16 inch thick asbestos packing. Branches shall be taken from the top of the supply mains at an angle of 45 degrees above the horizontal, unless otherwise indicated on the drawings. Branches shall pitch up from the mains towards the undrilled risers or radiator connections with a grade of not less than one inch in ten feet. All connections shall be carefully made to ensure unrestricted circulation, eliminate air pockets, and permit the complete drainage of the system. Any change to supply mains shall be made through concentric reducing fittings. Location of all risers shown on the drawings is approximate. Exact location of risers shall be approved by the Contracting Officer. Down feed risers to radiators shall terminate in a dirt pocket and shall be dripped through a trap to the return pipe.

All screwed joints shall be made with tapered threads properly cut. Screwed joints shall be made perfectly tight with a stiff mixture of graphite oil and applied with a brush to the pipe threads only and in no case to the fittings. All flanged joints shall be faced true, packed and made up perfectly square and tight.

All horizontal runs of pipe shall be securely supported and suspended pipe shall be held by adjustable expansion pipe hangers having bolted hinge loops and turn buckles or other approved devices. Chain or flat steel strap hangers will not be acceptable. Pipes, 2 inches or less in diameter, that are supported from side walls shall have brackets and roller supports. Pipes installed in finished trenches shall rest upon suitable side wall or floor supports equipped with rollers. Pipe in earth trenches shall be hung from above. Supports for pipes less than 6 inches in diameter shall be spaced 10 feet on centres. Supports for pipes 6 inches or larger in diameter shall be spaced not more than 20 feet on centres. Where available structural supports will not permit the above, deviations may be permitted by the Engineer.

Pipe anchors shall consist of heavy steel collars with lugs and bolts for the clamping and attaching anchor braces, unless otherwise shown on the drawings. Anchor braces shall be installed in the most effective manner to secure the desired results using turn buckles where required. No supports, anchors or stays shall be attached in places where they will injure the construction either in installing or by the weight or the expansion of the pipe line. Detail drawings of all pipe anchors shall be submitted to the Engineer for approval before installation.
All pipes passing through masonry construction shall be fitted with sleeves. Each sleeve shall extend through its respective floor or wall and shall be cut flush with each surface unless otherwise required. Unless otherwise specified, sleeves shall be two pipe sizes larger in diameter than the passing pipe when uncovered, and one pipe size larger than the overall outside diameter of the pipe when insulated. Sleeves in bearing walls shall be made of steel or other approved pipe. Sleeves in other masonry walls shall be of gauge metal, fiber or other approved material. Sleeves in floors of toilets, bathrooms and kitchens shall be cast iron with intricately cast flanges. Spaces between such floor sleeves and passing pipe shall be caulked with graphite packing and a plastic and water-proof caulking compound as approved by the Engineer. The floor sleeves shall extend 1 inch above the finished floor. All sleeves shall be properly installed and securely cemented in place. All piping passing through walls or ceilings of finished wood shall be fitted enamel floor, wall or ceiling plates of cast iron or steel, securely fastened in place. Where pipe passes through combustible materials, the opening shall be sufficiently large to provide 1 inch clearance between the pipe and floor or partition.

Slip type, double guided expansion joints shall be installed where shown on the drawings or directed by the Engineer. The joints shall be single or double slip joints, as required, and shall be designed to carry the weight of the expansion tube by means of machined guides at both ends of the tubes. A gland will not be considered as a guiding element. Expansion tubes shall be fitted at one end with piston guides that are so designed as to prevent wearing of grooves in bearing surfaces. The body of each joint shall be of fine grained gray cast iron. Expansion tubes shall be accurately machined and provided with suitable protective plating. Each expansion joint shall have a traverse suitable for application, but not less than 4 inches for each slip. All joints shall be designed for w.p. of 125 lbs. per square in. gauge.

Piping running in concrete floor construction will be either run in trench with ventilated cover, or pipe will be copper with gaskets to insulate the two different metals.

Pressure reducing valve with by-passes as shown on plans shall be supplied and installed as shown on plans. The main P.R.V. will be double seat, lever and weight type, flanged valve. The smaller valves will be single seat, lever and weight type, suitable for dead-end service. Valves for kitchen steam and medium pressure heating service will be single seat, spring type, suitable for dead-end service.

One pound per square inch gauge for steam and average water temperature of 195 degrees F for gravity water under 190 degrees F for final water with heat emission of 240 BTU and 150 BTU per square foot per hour respectively.

11. STEAM TRAPS:- Thermostatic Traps shall be installed in the return connection from each radiator and elsewhere as indicated on the drawings. The size and capacity of the traps will be as indicated on the drawings, or as approved by the Contracting Officer, but in no case less than 200 sq. ft. of equivalent steam radiation. Drip Traps for Mains, risers and similar lines shall be installed with a cooling leg of 5 ft. of uncovered 3" pipe. The capacity of all traps shall be based on a pressure differential of three pounds per square inch. The Traps shall be designed for a steam working pressure of 15 pounds per square inch gauge, but shall operate with a supply pressure of approximately 5 pounds per square inch gauge. The traps shall be of the patterns best suited to the units they serve and will have union inlet connections.

Float and Thermostatic Traps shall be designed for a steam working pressure of 15 pounds per square inch gauge, but shall operate with supply pressure of approximately five pounds per square inch gauge. Basket shall be of not less than .025 inch thick, 22 gauge sheet metal, having perforations to provide a net free area through the basket of at least four times that of the entering pipe. The flow shall be into the basket and out through the perforations.

15. CLEANING BOILER AND PIPING:- Before any covering is installed, the entire Heating System will be cleaned under supervision of the Engineer. Each Boiler will be filled with water and fire started. A temporary connection will be made from the safety valve or surface blow off opening to the sewer or elsewhere outside the building. The boiler Stop Valve will be closed. When the water in the boiler starts boiling, the feed cock shall be opened a small amount and sufficient to keep the water in the boiler at the point where the water, oil and grease will siphon through the hose connection at the top of the boiler. This will be kept up for two hours during which time a good hot fire will be maintained and not over five pounds per square inch gauge pressure will be kept on the boiler. Should a steady water line not be obtained when the stop valves are opened and the entire system connected to the boiler, then the above process will be repeated as often as necessary. When the boiler has been cleaned, a steam pressure of ten pounds gauge will be maintained on the entire system for a period of six hours or for sufficient time to allow of an inspection of all heating units, pipe fittings and connections to be made by the Engineer. Any leaks found will be noted and made good and the test will be repeated as often as necessary until no leaks can be found. During the above test or tests, temporary connections will be made from the return mains to sewer or out of doors and no condensate will be allowed to enter pump receivers. The receivers will be inspected and cleaned during this period. During the test, all units must heat uniformly and without noise. Any trap found defective or any cases of water hammer whatever must be corrected. All strainers will be inspected and cleaned as often as necessary to insure that the system has been cleared of all dirt, oil, grease, sand or scale.

With reference to the proposed Teslin Indian Residential School, and file 942-5 (E), and file I.A. 1856-8 of Engineering and Construction Division of Lands and Development Services Branch.

I beg to advise that drawings and specifications of the proposed school were received at this office, and every assistance was given to contractors interested in the building.

After an examination of the drawings and investigation of the source of the 120 Indian pupils for the school, and in view of changing circumstances, it is my opinion that such a large school is not justified. The buildings do not take advantage of native materials such as logs, and in some instances the specifications are difficult to fulfill and will prove costly. For instance Page 23, para. 38 of the Specifications calls for walks and drives to be rolled with a twenty ton roller, as there is no machine of this size in the Territory, the roller will have to be brought in at enormous expense. No advantage has been taken of the surplus electricity from the nearby R.C.A.B. powerhouse.

The 1939 Census of Indians of Canada shows approximately 11%, or 146 Indians, of the Yukon Agency to be Roman Catholic. Census figures for the Stikine Agency show 466 Roman Catholic and 305 Protestant Indians. There are 1352 Indians of the Yukon Agency shown as Anglican. As the latter group have only a small (45 pupil) school at Carcross, and as they have been established for some 40 years there, it is possible they will request a justification of the proposed school.

The changing circumstances mentioned above include the formation of a school board and the building of a new day school by the Province of B.C. at Lower Post, B.C., which will materially assist the 100 or so Indians of that immediate
area. They have been served in the past by a well-conducted seasonal school under the direction of Fr. P. Poulet O.M.I., who informed me recently that his school would probably close when the Provincial school became a reality.

On July 15th, 1949, I was requested to attend a meeting of the Directors of the Board of Trade, Whitehorse, at which I was asked to outline the events and steps leading up to the present situation with regard to the proposed Teslin Residential School. I gather there is a strained feeling, probably with no justification, by the parents in Whitehorse, owing to the almost complete lack of school facilities for more than 300 white children of the town. Until Mines and Resources in conjunction with Department of National Defence can build a school in Whitehorse, there will undoubtedly be opposition to any large scale school building for smaller population groups in the Yukon.

I would recommend that a smaller school be built at Teslin; one to accommodate 50 or 60 children, as was originally proposed by Bishop Coudert O.M.I.

Facilities for white children should, no doubt, concern the Dept. of National Defence and whatever tax-collecting authority is constituted at Whitehorse.

Long ago I wrote in a memo that the Yukon whites have little appreciation of the Indians' status as wards. Our agent might assure us that he has reminded the Board of Trade of the special responsibility of the Gov't of Canada.

I agree that we have come a long way from the pattern Bishop Coudert had in mind.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent Indian Agency.

Following the visit of Bishop Coudert, Vicar Apostolic of Whitehorse and Reverend J.O. Plourde O.M.I., to the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch and subsequently to the Director of the Lands and Development Services Branch, a meeting was arranged in the Chief Architect's office, where the matter of attempting to bring the cost of construction for the Teslin Residential School down to the level where it could be built at a cost approaching the funds allotted by the Department.

At the meeting were Bishop Coudert, Reverend J.O. Plourde, Col. R.F. Neary, Superintendent of Education for the Indian Affairs Branch and C.H. Buck, Chief Architect for the Lands and Development Services Branch.

The initial item discussed was the difference in what the building would cost if erected on the basis of the lowest tender received namely $536,215.00 and funds provided by the Indian Affairs Branch in the amount of $300,000.00.

The Church officers realized that in as remote a region as Teslin, costs for the purchase and transportation of materials, and the cost of obtaining, feeding and housing the necessary working staff would remain constant, and that to reduce the finished cost of the building to an acceptable level, a reduction in the volume must be made.

The Church officers had agreed previously to eliminate the chapel shown in the school design, and those present at the meeting carefully studied the drawings prepared by W.F. Noffke, F.R.A.I.C., of Ottawa, with a view to further reduction in volume.

As a result, it was agreed that the following accommodation now included in the school design, would be omitted,

(a) The chapel, occupying approximately........30,500 cu.ft.

(b) Storage for provisions, as agreed to by Architect Noffke and Indian Affairs at the suggestion of dietetic personnel Department of National Health and Welfare, occupying approximately..................11,200 cu.ft.

(c) The whole third floor, occupying approximately..........................44,250 cu.ft.

(d) Boiler room staff sleeping quarters in boiler house, occupying approximately........6,150 cu.ft.

Total decrease in volume...............92,100 cu.ft.

Having decided that this reduction in volume would not prevent efficient operation of the school, the meeting agreed that the Church officers present would further study the drawings, with a view to determining if any other space, if any, might be eliminated and that the Branch Chief Architect would explore the possibility of substitutions in materials and equipment in the specifications that might effect further reductions.

The meeting then adjourned.

(Continued)
Since August 15th, the Noffke plans as drawn, have been cubed and the volume of construction for which the lowest tender of $36,215.00 was submitted is approximately 487,000 cubic feet, producing a cost of $1.10 per cubic foot. It is reasonable to assume therefore, that by eliminating 92,100 cubic feet of volume, a saving of approximately $101,310.00 would be possible. The total approximate cost thus produced, amounting to $434,905.00 which still is $134,905.00 higher than allotted funds.

Mr. Noffke and the writer, discussed the drawings and specifications on the 17th instant, and Mr. Noffke is now giving consideration to a number of modifications suggested by your Chief Architect. Mr. Noffke will analyze the suggestions and if adoptable will incorporate them into his drawings and specifications for the use of those contractors whom we wish to approach for a revised tender.

While this Branch has not been officially notified, it is understood that in an attempt to reduce the cost of transporting material to the site of the school, Bishop Coudert has agreed to a change in location from Teslin in the Yukon, to Lower Post in British Columbia. If a suitable site is available at Lower Post, the reported existence of lumber mills there, would be no mean factor in reducing transportation costs and structural timber costs for a revised tender.

No value is attached of course to the report that a suitable site is available at Lower Post until a thorough investigation has been carried out.

Chas. H. Buck,
Chief Architect.

Since the above was written Major MacKay's memorandum of August 25th in regard to the change in the site of the school has been received.

Mr. Aubrey Simmons, M.P., has asked for information about the progress which is being made with the plans for the construction of the residential school at Lower Post in British Columbia. I suppose this information should be furnished through the Minister's office on a report from your branch.

The Engineering and Construction Division of our branch report that the working drawings and specifications are now complete; the drawings have been checked and blueprinted, and the specifications mimeographed. Particulars have not been had about the site peculiarities but it is proposed to have tenders called for on the premise that normal soil conditions exist. We have been advised that water supply and sewage disposal should present no unusual difficulties.

To prepare and issue tendering data and allow time for the contractors to prepare and submit their tenders, and to allow further time for securing the authority from Council, it is estimated that it would take at least six weeks. However, one important feature of a job at a place like Lower Post is the transportation of materials to the site, and it would seem that a lot of this could be done in the wintertime when the Alaska Highway is kept in excellent condition.

I gather from what Mr. Simmons says that he is in favour of the contract being awarded as soon as possible.

R.A. Gibson,
Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Lower Post Indian Residential School

I have noted the contents of your memorandum of October 31 and the inquiries made by Mr. Aubrey Simons, M.P.

We are pleased to note that the working drawings and specifications are now complete and that preparations are being made to prepare and issue tendering data.

I have been advised by the Superintendent of Education that Mr. M. Taylor of the Bond Construction Company also pointed out to him the advantages of advertising this project in the near future. With road transportation the only means of communication to the school site, it is understood that winter trucking is much faster than spring hauling when the roads are soft and dangerous.

His attitude was that most contractors would prefer to have the matter settled and the supplies shipped in by February or March.

Therefore this Branch is in agreement with the action suggested in your letter of advertising for tenders and, if found to be satisfactory, that the contract be let before the end of January, 1950.

Dear Mr. Simmons:

I understand that you have been making inquiries with regard to the progress being made with the plans for the construction of an Indian residential school at Lower Post in British Columbia.

As you are aware, it was originally our intention to erect this school near Teslin in the Yukon Territory and that tenders were called for its construction last summer.

However, the bids which were received were higher than could be recommended for acceptance and it was decided to move the school to Lower Post in British Columbia. There an ideal site was available closer to railhead and also more accessible for the Indian pupils who would attend.

The Lands and Development Services Branch of this Department have been at work revising their plans and reducing in several ways the estimated cost of this building.

I understand that it will take about six weeks to prepare and issue tendering data so that you can anticipate advertisements appearing for this project soon after mid-December.

AGREEMENT REGARDING ARCHITECTURAL SERVICES

THIS AGREEMENT made (in triplicate) the...20th day of........August..................in the year Nineteen Hundred and Forty-eight A.D.

BETWEEN

His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, hereinafter called "the Minister"

OF THE FIRST PART

and

W.E. Noffke, F.R.A.I.C. of Ottawa, Canada, hereinafter called "the Architect"

OF THE SECOND PART

WHEREAS the Minister intends to construct in Teslin, Yukon Territories:

An Indian Residential School hereinafter called "the Work".

AND WHEREAS the Minister will require the professional services of the Architect in connection with the said work.

WITNESSETH that the parties hereto, for the considerations hereinafter named agree each with the other as follows:

The Architect agrees to provide professional services for the above-named work as stated in Article 1 of this Agreement.

The Minister agrees to pay the Architect at the rate of Four Per Cent (4%) hereinafter called the basic rate; computed and payable as stated in this Agreement, and to make any other payments and reimbursements set forth in said Agreement.
CONDITIONS OF AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE MINISTER AND ARCHITECT

Article 1: THE ARCHITECT'S SERVICES The Architect's professional services consist of the necessary conferences, the preparation of preliminary studies, his working drawings, specifications, large scale and full size detail drawings as required, including structural, heating and electrical engineering, and to furnish the Minister with blueprints of the working drawings and copies of the specifications up to the number of forty of the former and sixty of the latter.

Article 2: THE ARCHITECT'S FEE The fee payable by the Minister to the Architect for the performance of the said professional services is the percentage hereinbefore defined as the basic rate, computed upon the cost of the work in respect of which such services have been performed, subject, however, to any modifications growing out of these Conditions of Agreement.

Article 3: REIMBURSEMENTS The Minister will reimburse the Architect for the costs of transportation and living expenses incurred by him while travelling in discharge of duties solely connected with the work.

Article 4: EXTRA SERVICES The Architect's services do not include supervision or inspection of the work, but the Minister or his representative may, at any time, request the Architect to carry out such inspection and the Architect will be paid at the rate of Fifty Dollars ($50.00) per day for the time spent on such inspection, in addition to the basic rate hereinbefore mentioned and any reimbursements payable under Article 3 above.

Article 5: PAYMENTS Whether the work be executed or whether its execution be suspended or abandoned in part or whole, payments to the Architect on his fee are to be made as follows:

Upon completion of the preliminary studies, a sum equal to Twenty Per Cent (20%) of the basic rate computed upon a reasonable estimated cost.

Upon completion of specifications and general working drawings (exclusive of details) a sum sufficient to increase payments
in the fee to Seventy-five Per Cent (75%) of the rate of commission arising from this Agreement, computed upon a reasonable cost estimated on such completed specifications and drawings, or if tenders have been received, then computed upon the lowest bona fide tender or tenders.

From time to time during the execution of the work and in proportion to the amount of service rendered by the Architect, payments shall be made on account of the fee under this Article, but not including any covered by the provisions of Article 4, shall be a sum equal to the rate of commission arising from this Agreement, computed upon the final cost of the work.

Payments to the Architect, other than those on his fee, fall due from time to time as his work is done or as costs are incurred.

No deduction shall be made from the Architect's fee on account of penalty, liquidated damages, or other sums withheld from payments to Contractors.

Article 6: MINISTER'S DECISIONS The Minister shall give thorough consideration to all sketches, drawings, specifications, proposals, and other documents laid before him by the Architect and, wherever prompt action is necessary, he shall inform the Architect of his decisions in such reasonable time as not to delay the work of the Architect.

Article 7: SURVEY, BORINGS, AND TESTS The Minister shall furnish the Architect with a complete and accurate survey of the building site, giving the grades and lines of streets, pavements, and adjoining properties; the rights, restrictions, easements, boundaries, and contours of the building site, and full information as to sewer, water, gas and electrical service. The Minister is to pay for borings or test pits and for chemical, mechanical, or other tests when required.
Article 8: PRELIMINARY ESTIMATES When requested to do so, the Architect will make or procure preliminary estimates on the cost of any part of, any additions to, or deductions from the work and he will endeavour to keep the actual cost of such work as low as may be consistent with the purpose of the building and with proper workmanship and material, but no such estimate can be regarded as other than an approximation.

Article 9: DEFINITION OF THE COST OF THE WORK The words "the cost of the work" as used in Articles 2 and 5 hereof are ordinarily to be interpreted as meaning the total of the contract sums incurred for the execution of the work, not including Architect's fees, but in certain rare cases, e.g., when labour or material is furnished by the Minister below its market costs or when old materials are re-used, the cost of the work is to be interpreted as the cost of all materials and labour necessary to complete the work, as such cost would have been if all materials had been new and if all labour had been fully paid at market prices current when the work was ordered, plus contractor's profits and expenses.

Article 10: SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNMENT The Minister and the Architect, each binds himself, his successors, executors, administrators, and assigns to the other party to this Agreement, and to the successors, executors, administrators and assigns of such other party in respect of all the covenants of this Agreement.

The Architect shall have the right to join with him in the performance of this Agreement, any architect or architects with whom he may in good faith enter into partnership relations. In case of the death or disability of one or more partners, the rights and duties of the Architect, if a firm, shall devolve upon the remaining partner or partners or upon such firm as may be established by him or them, and he, they or it shall be recognized as the "successor" of the Architect, and so on until the service covered by the Agreement has been performed. The Minister shall have the same rights, but in his case no limitation as to the vocation of those admitted to partnership is imposed.
Article III: DEFAULT

In case the Architect or his assistant shall make default, or fail to carry out his duties in connection with the work, or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of this Agreement, then and in any of such cases, the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Architect's hands, and in such case the Architect shall have no claim for any further payment on account of the basic rate or any reimbursement stipulated to be payable to the Architect in this Agreement, but shall be chargeable with, and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty, occasioned by such default or delay.

The Minister and the Architect hereby agree to the full performance of the covenants contained herein.

Foreman of the Works

18. A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during all the working hours, to receive the orders of the Engineer. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor, and shall have full power to carry out all requisitions and instructions of the said Engineer, but this clause shall not relieve the Contractor from the duty of personally superintending the work.
Engineer sole judge of work and material

19. The Engineer shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of this contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings and specification shall be final, and no work under this contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Engineer is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid therefor.

Quality

20. The works shall be constructed by the Contractor and under His personal supervision, of new materials throughout; the best materials of their several kinds, and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in the manner required by and in strict conformity with this contract, the said specifications and special plans and specifications, and the plans and drawings relating thereto, and the working or detail drawings which may from time to time be furnished, which said specifications and special plans and drawings are hereby declared to be part of this contract.

Defective work or material

21. Should the Contractor use or employ, or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools, equipment, articles or things which, in the opinion of the Engineer are not in accordance with the provisions of this contract or are in any way unsuitable for the works, or any part thereof, or should the Engineer consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, insufficiently executed or performed, the Engineer may order the Contractor to remove the same and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things, or to properly re-construct or perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders; and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours, the Engineer may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed, the orders so given and the Contractor shall, on demand, pay to His Majesty all costs, damages and expenses incurred in respect thereof, or occasioned to His Majesty by reason of the non-compliance by the Contractor with any such orders, or His Majesty may, in the discretion of the Minister, retain and deduct such costs, damages and expenses from any amounts then or thereafter payable to the Contractor.

Insufficient workmen, plant, etc.

22. If the Engineer shall at any time consider the number of workmen, horses, quantity of machinery, tools, plant or equipment, or of proper materials articles or things, respectively, employed or provided by the Contractor on or for the said works to be insufficient for the advancement of such works or any part thereof towards completion within the time limited in respect thereof, or that the works or some parts thereof, are not being carried on with due diligence, then, and in every such case, the Engineer may, in writing, order the Contractor to employ, or provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may think necessary, and in case the Contractor shall not within three days, or such other longer period as may be fixed by any such order, in all respects comply therewith, the Engineer may employ and provide such additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, as he may think proper, and
may pay such additional workmen such wages, and for such additional horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things, respectively, any such prices as he may think proper and all such amounts so paid shall, on demand, be repaid to His Majesty by the Contractor or the same may be retained or deducted from any sum that may then or thereafter be or become due from His Majesty to the Contractor. The Contractor shall employ the additional workmen, horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things so provided and employed by the Engineer in the diligent advancement of the works; the workmen and horses so provided shall, however, be thereafter subject to discharge by the Contractor, but only with the consent and approval of the Engineer.

Contractor's machinery, plant, etc.

23. All machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things whatsoever provided by the Contractor or by the Engineer under the provisions of sections 21 and 22 for the works, and not rejected under the provisions of section 21 shall from the time of their being so provided, become and until the final completion of the said work, shall be the property of His Majesty for the purpose of the said works, and the same shall on no account be taken away or used, or disposed of, except for the purposes of the said works, without the consent in writing of the Engineer. His Majesty shall not, however, be answerable for any loss or damage whatsoever which may at any time happen to such machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles or things. Upon the completion of the works and upon payment by the Contractor of all such moneys loss, cost and damages, if any, as shall be due from the Contractor to His Majesty, or chargeable against the Contractor under this contract, such of the said machinery, tools, plant, materials, equipment, articles and things as shall not have been used and converted in the works or disposed of by His Majesty under powers conferred in this contract, shall, upon demand, be delivered up to the Contractor in such condition as they may then be in.

Work not comprised in contract

24. His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the works other contractors and workmen with such horses, machinery, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Engineer may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in this contract, and the Contractor shall afford to them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Engineer may deem practical.

The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the works of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed an acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the works comprised in this contract.

Co-operation with other Contractors

25. That whenever and so often as it may be necessary for the Contractor to co-operate with other contractors on this work, or any or either of them, the Contractor shall diligently and under the directions of the Engineer perform all such works as shall be requisite and proper on the part of the Contractor herein for such co-operation and for securing and placing in proper position the portion necessary herein and hereby contracted to be constructed, the erection for the proposed work in a proper and secure mode, and to prevent the possibility of any accident thereto, without any extra charge therefor, and shall be bound in all things to conform to the direction of the Minister or the Engineer touching such cooperation and work.
