Default or delay by Contractor

26. In case the Contractor shall make default or delay in commencing, or in diligently executing any of the works or portions thereof to be performed, or that may be ordered under this contract, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, the Engineer may give a general notice to the Contractor requiring him to put an end to such default or delay, and should such default or delay continue for six days after such notice shall have been given by the Engineer to the Contractor, or should the Contractor make default in the completion of the works, or any portion thereof, within the time limited with respect thereto in or under this contract, or should the Contractor become insolvent, or abandon the work, or make an assignment of this contract without the consent required, or otherwise fail to observe and perform any of the provisions of this contract, then and in any of such cases the Minister, for and on behalf of His Majesty, and without any further authorization, may take all the work out of the Contractor's hands and may employ such persons as he, on His Majesty's behalf, may see fit to complete the works, and in such case the Contractor shall have no claim for any further payment in respect of work performed, but shall be chargeable with and shall remain liable for all loss and damage which may be suffered by His Majesty by reason of such default or delay, or the non-completion by the Contractor of the works, and no objection or claim shall be raised or made by the Contractor by reason or on account of the ultimate cost of the work so taken over, for any reason proving greater than in the opinion of the Contractor it should have been; and all materials, articles and things whatsoever, and all horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment, and all rights, proprietary or otherwise, licences, powers and privileges, whether relating to or affecting real estate or personal property, acquired, possessed or provided by the Contractor for the purposes of the work, or by the Engineer under the provisions of this contract shall remain and be the property of His Majesty for all purposes incidental to the completion of the works, and may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty as fully to all intents and purposes connected with the works as they might therefore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor; and the Minister may also, at his option on behalf of His Majesty, sell or otherwise dispose of, at public sale prices, or at public auction or private sale or otherwise, the whole or any part or number of such materials, articles, things, horses, machinery, tools, plant and equipment at such price or prices as he may see fit, and detain the proceeds of any such sale or disposition and all other amounts then or thereafter due by His Majesty to the Contractor on account of, or in part satisfaction of any loss or damage which His Majesty may sustain or have sustained by reason aforesaid.

Power to take action on default of Contractor

27. Whenever in this contract power or authority is given to His Majesty, the Minister, the Engineer, or any person on behalf of His Majesty, to take any action consequent upon the insolvency of the Contractor, or upon the acts, defaults, neglects, delays, breaches, non-observance or non-performance by the Contractor in respect of the works or any portion or details thereof, such power or authorities may be exercised from time to time, and not only in the event of the happening of such contingencies before the time limited in this contract for the completion of the works but also in the event of the same happening after the time so limited in the case of the Contractor being permitted to further proceed with the execution of the works.
Delays

28. The Contractor shall not have nor make any claim or demand, nor bring any action or suit or petition against His Majesty for any damage which he may sustain by reason of any delay or delays from whatever cause arising in the progress of the work.

No Implied Contracts

29. It is distinctly declared that no implied contract of any kind whatsoever by or on behalf of His Majesty shall arise or be implied from anything, in the contract documents contained or from any position or situation of the parties at any time, it being clearly understood and agreed that the express contract covenants and agreements therein contained and made by His Majesty are and shall be the only contracts, covenants and agreements upon which any rights against His Majesty are founded.

Parliamentary appropriations exhausted

30. Should the amount voted by Parliament and applicable towards payment for the work hereby contracted for be at any time expended previous to the completion of the works, the Minister or the Engineer may give the Contractor written notice to that effect. Upon receiving such notice the Contractor may, if he thinks fit, stop the work, but shall not be entitled to any payment for work done beyond the amount voted and applicable as aforesaid, until the necessary funds shall have been voted by Parliament in that behalf. And in no event shall the Contractor have or make any claim on His Majesty for any damages or compensation by reason of the suspension of payment, or by reason of any delay or loss caused by the stoppage of the work. And in the event of the Contractor electing to proceed, or proceeding with such work after such notice, and for such additional funds are voted, no action of the Engineer, or of any other person on behalf of His Majesty, in giving orders, instructions or directions, or otherwise acting with respect to such work, shall be taken or considered as in any manner improving the rights of the Contractor or as waiving in any particular any of the provisions of this section.

Minister may suspend work

31. The Minister may, from time to time and for such period as he may deem expedient, delay or suspend, in whole or in part, operations under this contract, either upon the whole of the works, or at any particular point or points. Should any such delay or suspension, or the stoppage of the works under the provisions of Section 30, or should any delay caused by any circumstance which, in the opinion of the Engineer, is beyond the control of or not the fault of the Contractor, in the opinion of the Minister reasonably limit the time for the completion of the works, within the time specified by this contract, the Minister as often as the case occurs shall allow such additional time as to him may seem sufficient in the extension of such time for completion; but no such delay, suspension or stoppage shall vitiate or avoid this contract or any part thereof, or any security or obligations for the performance thereof, nor shall the Contractor be entitled to make any claim for damages by reason thereof. Upon the termination of such delay, suspension or stoppage, or upon the removal of the cause thereof, or upon the Contractor receiving notice from the Minister or Engineer requiring him to resume the work, he shall at once resume operations and diligently carry on the same.
Waiver negatived

32. No condoning, excusing or overlooking by His Majesty, or any person acting on his behalf, on previous occasions, or breaches, or defaults similar to that for which any action is taken or power exercised, or forfeiture is claimed or enforced against the Contractor, shall be taken to operate as a waiver of any provision of this contract, nor to defeat or prejudice in any way the right of His Majesty thereunder.

Members of H. of C. not to benefit

33. Pursuant to the provision of the Statute in such case made and provided, no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

No Public Ceremony

34. The Contractor shall not allow any public ceremony in connection with the work without having previously obtained the written permission of the Minister.

Liquors

35. The Contractor shall not bring nor permit to be brought anywhere on or, as far as the Contractor can prevent the same, near the works any spirituous or intoxicating liquor; and if any person employed on the works be, in the opinion of the Engineer, intemperate, disorderly, incompetent, wilfully negligent or dishonest in the performance of his duties, he shall, on the direction of the Engineer, be forthwith discharged and the Contractor shall not employ or permit to remain on the work any person who shall have been discharged for any or all of said causes.

Sanitation

36. The Contractor shall comply with, and the works shall be carried on subject to, all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said works, and all orders given by the Engineer with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the works. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, provide suitable privies and make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Engineer, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

Contractor to clean premises on completion

37. The Contractor shall upon the completion of the works, remove all temporary structures and clear away all rubbish and surplus and waste materials remaining on or about the works, and place the premises in a neat and tidy condition, satisfactory to the Engineer.

Damages to persons or property

38. The Contractor, his agents and all workmen and persons employed by him, or under his control, shall use due care that no person or property is injured and that no rights are infringed in the prosecution of the work, and the Contractor shall be solely responsible for all damages, by whomsoever claimable, in respect of any injury to persons or to lands, buildings, structures, fences, trees, crops, roads, ways, ships, or property of whatever description, and in respect of any infringement of any right, privilege or easement whatsoever, occasioned in the carrying on of the works or any part thereof, or by any neglect, misfeasance or nonfeasance on the Contractor's part or on the part of any of his agents,

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6482, file 942-5, part 3)
workmen or persons employed by him or under his control, and shall at his own expense, make such temporary provisions as may be necessary to ensure the avoidance of any such damage, injury or infringement, and to prevent the interruption of or danger or menace to the traffic on any public or private road, and to secure to all persons and corporations the uninterrupted enjoyment of all their rights in and during the performance of the said work; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions, suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by or attributable to any such damage, injury or infringement.

Damages to work in progress. Contractor assumes risk

39. The Contractor shall be at the risk of, and shall bear all loss or damage whatsoever, from whatsoever cause arising, which may occur to the work, or any part thereof, until the same be finally accepted by the Minister, and if any such loss or damage occur before such final acceptance, the Contractor shall immediately, at his own expense, repair, restore and re-execute the work so damaged, so that the whole works, or their respective portions thereof, shall be completed within the time limited for completion thereof, and any delay occasioned by the Contractor to the other contractors on the work or any interference by the Contractor with the operations which may be a cause of delay or damage shall be rectified at the cost of, and the claim for damage or delay (if any) shall be at the charge of the Contractor.

Precautions as to fire

40. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the works and employ his own workmen, to the satisfaction and under the direction of the Engineer, in extinguishing all such fires which may occur; and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given, from time to time during construction, by the Engineer with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires, and shall pay all wages and other outlay occasioned by reason of the observance or compliance with such regulations and instructions.

Fire Insurance

41. The Contractor shall, at his own expense, at all times during construction and until the final acceptance of the work, keep all buildings and structures insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts equal to at least Eighty (80) per cent of the value of work done and materials accepted by the Engineer, as may be approved by the Chief, and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty may respectively appear, and shall be deposited with the Chief.

Protection of Workmen

42. The Contractor shall protect the Department from all claims that may arise from injury to, or sickness of, any workmen employed by him on the work.
43. The Contractor will be required to comply with the provisions of the Workmen's Compensation Act for the province in which the work is being carried on.

Payment by Contractor for Labour, etc.

44. The Contractor shall promptly pay for all labour, service and materials in or about the construction of the works, and all payments for such purposes shall be made by the contractor, at least as often as payments are made to the Contractor by His Majesty under this contract, and in the event of failure by the Contractor at any time so to do, or if any sum due for labour of any foreman or workman, or for hire of horses, teams or carts upon or in respect of the works, or any part thereof, remains in arrears or unpaid, or if there be at any time found to exist any claims against the Contractors, or any sub-contractor, for labour, teams, tools, plant, equipment, materials, articles or things employed, hired or supplied upon or for the works or any part thereof, or if the Minister has reason to believe that any such payments, sums or claims will not be promptly made or paid, the Minister may, in addition to or in lieu of exercising any powers conferred by the Labour Conditions, at his option, retain out of any moneys due or become due to the Contractor from His Majesty such amount or amounts as the Minister may deem sufficient to satisfy the same, or pay the Contractor the moneys due him in instalments, giving him from time to time such sums as the Minister or the Engineer deems sufficient to meet such payments, sums or claims or any of them, and withholding the balance due him after deducting the payments so made. The Contractor shall be stopped from denying the accuracy and correctness of any and all payments so made by the Minister.

Books, etc., of Contractor open for inspection

45. The Contractor's pay-rolls, time-books, books of account, invoices and statements shall be at all times open for inspection and extract by the Engineer and any authorized representative of the Minister, or either of them who shall be assisted in every possible way by the Contractor, to enable the Engineer and such representative to ascertain, as far as possible, the exact payment, sums or claims so due and remaining unpaid by the Contractor.

Work to be free from all encumbrances

46. Before making any payment on any progress estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to satisfy the Engineer, or other authorized representative of His Majesty, that all work performed and materials supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kind of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished, or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

Statutory Declaration

47. Upon completion of the work, and before payment is made on any final estimate, certificate, or statement the Contractor shall submit to the Engineer, a statement attested by Statutory Declaration showing that all works performed and materials supplied are free of all lawful liens or claims.
Proofs required for default of Contractor

48. The Minister or the Engineer may, in their discretion, at any time require proof, with such facilities or to such extent as they may deem requisite, of any claim under the said Fair Wage Clauses or Schedules, or for wages or hire of teams in arrears or of accounts for materials, or other things unpaid.

Schedule of Unit Prices

49. The Contractor shall submit with his tender a detailed schedule of unit prices of all materials worked or in place, which shall, upon approval of the Engineer, be used as a basis of payments for all work under the contract.

Classification of Costs

50. There shall also be submitted at the same time, a classification of costs at the schedule of unit prices submitted, aggregating the total contract price. This schedule shall be so computed that all incidental charges shall be distributed over the various trade items as shown on the Departmental Progress Estimate form or as approved by the Chief Engineer, and shall be used as a basis for the Engineer's Monthly Progress Estimates.

Prices to be accepted as full compensation

51. The said price or prices shall be accepted by the Contractor as full compensation for everything furnished and done by the Contractor under this contract, including all work required but not included in the items hereinabove mentioned, and also for all loss or damage arising out of the nature of the works or the action of the weather, tides, elements, or any unforeseen obstruction or difficulty encountered in the prosecution of the work, and for all risks of every description connected with the works, and for all expenses incurred by or in connection with the works, and for all works, and for all expenses incurred by or in consequence of any delay or suspension or discontinuance of the work as herein specified, and for well and faithfully completing the works as in this contract provided.

Progress Payments

52. Payments equal to about ninety per cent of the value of the work done, approximately estimated from progress measurements and computed at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, will be made to the Contractor monthly if practicable, on the written certificate of the Engineer, stating that the work for or on account of which the certificate is granted has been done, and stating the value of work completed as above mentioned; and the said certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to be paid the said ninety per cent or any part thereof. The remaining ten per cent shall be retained till the final completion of the whole work to the satisfaction of the Engineer, and will be paid within two months after such completion. The written certificate of the said Engineer certifying to the final completion of the said works to his satisfaction, shall be a condition precedent to the right of the Contractor to receive or to be paid the remaining ten per cent or any part thereof.
Engineer in certifying values for progress payments may disregard price list

53. Provided always that, where in the opinion of the Engineer the work done is not sufficiently finished, or is not of sufficient value to justify payment at the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, the Engineer may, for the purpose of such payment, disregard the price or prices agreed upon or determined, and may estimate the proportionate value payable in respect of such work and issue a certificate accordingly; and while hence the Contractor shall only be entitled to receive ninety per cent of such estimated proportionate value as stated in such certificate, and shall not be paid the ninety per cent of the price or prices agreed upon or determined under the provisions of this contract, until such time as the Engineer, by reason of the performance of additional work, shall certify that the Contractor is entitled thereto.

Claims under progress certificate

54. It is intended that every allowance to which the Contractor is fairly entitled will be embraced in the Engineer's monthly certificate, but should the Contractor at any time have claims of any description which he considers are not included in the progress certificates, such claims must be made in writing to the Engineer within thirty days after the date of the delivery to him of the certificate from which he considers the items of such claims to have been omitted, but in no case beyond the period of sixty days from the date of the practical completion of that portion of the work to which such claims apply. And in default of the presentation of such claims within the times so limited the Minister may treat such claims as absolutely barred.

Claims, evidence of accuracy

55. The Contractor in presenting claims of the kind referred to in the last preceding clause must accompany them with satisfactory evidence of their accuracy and the reason why he thinks they should be allowed.

Payment for additional or extra work

56. Payment for any work or additional work done, or materials or things provided, under the written orders of the Engineer, for which no price or prices are named, and which is not covered by the contract. His Majesty, in consideration and subject, as aforesaid, will pay to the Contractor the actual and reasonable cost, as determined by the Engineer, of such work, materials and things, with an additional ten per cent thereon for the use of tools, Contractor's plant, superintendence and profits.

Approximate quantities

57. The quantities (if any) given are approximate only and no claim shall be made by the Contractor against His Majesty on account of any excess or deficiency, absolute or relative, in the same.

Progress measurements and certificates not binding

58. The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Engineer, or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Engineer in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
Reaffirmation

59. Should it subsequently be found that inferior materials or workmanship have been incorporated into the works, or that the contract has been departed from in any way, the Contractor shall be responsible for making good, without expense to the Department, any defects together with any and all damages that may have resulted from such defects.

PROVIDED, notice shall be given the Contractor regarding such defects within a period of one (1) year after date of the final certificate of the completion of the work.

PROVIDED, the period stipulated in any guarantee given by the Contractor has not expired.

Extension of time

60. Any extension of time requested by the Contractor due to circumstances beyond his control delaying the work, shall be made in writing, to the Chief Engineer, at least 10 days before expiration of the contract; any extension of time that may be granted to the Contractor shall be so granted and accepted without prejudice to any rights of His Majesty whatsoever under this contract, and no assent thereto on the part of the Contractor shall be necessary.

Minister sole judge of reasonableness of extension of time for completion

61. Provided always that after the expiration of the time limited for the completion of the works the Minister shall be sole judge as to what additional time, if any, may be allowed to the Contractor for such completion, and his decision as to the reasonableness or sufficiency thereof for the purpose of completion shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

ARTICLE V: The security deposit furnished His Majesty by the Contractor shall be held and retained by His Majesty as security for the due and complete performance, observance and fulfilment by the Contractor of all the covenants and provisions of this Contract. Must Explain Fees Paid Ottawa Architect

High officials of the Federal Works Department and the Citizenship and Immigration Department will be summoned before the Public Accounts Committee of the Commons to explain fees paid to Ottawa architect W. E. Noffke.

Opposition members this morning brought assurance from Chairman David Croll that a full explanation of two payments made to Mr. Noffke would be forthcoming from departmental officials.

Cited in Report.

The payments were cited in the 1948-49 report of Auditor-General William Short, which today was under discussion.

The Auditor-General's report said an agreement was made by the Mines and Resources Department with Mr. Noffke through his son-in-Council in February, 1948. In August he received payment of $13,800, 75 percent of his total fee for plans for a school building in the Yukon Territory.

The Indian Affairs Branch of the Works Department now comes under Citizenship and Immigration.

Later Mr. Noffke had been asked to draw a second plan of the same school at a lower cost and had received $7,200 on account.

Progressive Conservative Leader Robert Drew objected to the payments in view of the fact that no construction had gone on in the fiscal year.

Ross Thatcher, CCF-Moosejaw, asked why Public Works Department architects haven't have prepared the plans. Mr. Thatcher said the payments seemed excessive.

He asked why Works Department architects should be standing idly by while the Department was hiring outside architects to do work in another province.

John Hambacher, Progressive Conservative member for Lake Centre, asked for the total amount of government paid to outside architects by the Works Department in the 1948-49 fiscal period.

"Was this contract let without competition?" Mr. Drew asked.

Calling Witnesses.

Chairman Croll said officials of the Works and Citizenship departments would be called to answer such questions.

Mr. Thatcher asked why the architect's fee had been paid even before the building was started.

"Is he finished now or is he putting in further bills?" the CCP member pursued.

"Of course he is putting in further bills," Mr. Croll answered. "For the supervision of the job."

"There's something wrong here," Mr. Thatcher insisted.

Construction of a temporary fish products laboratory in Ottawa on rented land was criticized. Mr. Thatcher said it would have been cheaper to build when the Government's lease on the land was due to expire.

The following General Conditions shall apply to and govern all the trades under these specifications.

1. DRAWINGS:- The works covered by this contract shall be in accordance with the accompanying drawings, together with such other working and detail drawings as will be furnished to the Contractor by the Architect from time to time during progress of the works.

2. QUALIFICATIONS:- The Department reserves the power and right to reject tenders received from parties who cannot show a reasonable acquaintance with, and preparation for, the proper performance of the class of work herein specified and shown on plans. Evidence of such competency must be furnished by the tenderers if requested to do so.

3. EXAMINATION OF SITE:- All parties tendering shall, before sending in their tender, examine the site of the proposed work and make themselves thoroughly acquainted with same and obtain for themselves all information that may be necessary for the proper carrying out of this contract. No extra claim will be allowed or entertained for any work, or material, that may be requisite and necessary for the proper execution and completion of this contract.

All parties tendering shall, before sending in their tender, ascertain definitely for their own protection the nature and amount of material that it may be necessary to excavate to reach the depths as shown on drawings, also the amount of grading and nature thereof. The Department does not guarantee any information furnished to the Contractor regarding the nature, amount and class of materials to be excavated or removed.

4. TENDER FORM:- Persons tendering are notified that tenders will not be considered unless made on the printed forms furnished, and signed with their actual signatures, with their occupations and places of residence. In the case of firms, the actual signature, the nature of the occupation and place of residence of each member of the firm must be given.

The Department does not bind itself to accept the lowest or any tender.

5. **SALES' TAX:** The amount of the tender shall include all sales' tax in force, or applicable at the time. In the event of reduction in such sales' tax being legally authorized between the time of the acceptance of the tender and the completion of the works, the benefit derived from such reduction shall accrue and be payable to the Department, and an amount covering such reduction will accordingly be deducted from the sum or sums payable to the Contractor under the original agreement.

6. **SECURITY:** Each tender must be accompanied by a certified cheque on a chartered bank, in Canada, made payable to the Order of The Receiver General of Canada, equal to five per cent (5%) of the amount of the tender or, in lieu of such certified cheque, by Guaranty Bonds of the Dominion of Canada or of the Canadian National Railway Company and its constituent companies, unconditionally guaranteed as to principal and interest by the Dominion of Canada or the aforementioned Bonds and certified cheque, if it is necessary to make up an odd amount.

The deposit will be forfeited if the tenderer declines to enter into a contract when called upon to do so, or if he, as Contractor, fails to complete the contract.

If the tender is not accepted, the deposit will be returned.

7. **INTEREST ON DEPOSIT:** Tenderers are notified that they must make their own arrangements with their bankers as to the payment of interest, if any, on the amount of the marked cheque accompanying their tender. The Government of Canada will not pay interest on said cheque pending the awarding of the contract, nor be responsible for the payment of interest under any arrangement made by the tenderers. The cheque of the tenderer to whom the contract has been awarded will forthwith be deposited in the Department of Finance, and interest on the amount thereof at the prevailing rate per annum under the regulations governing deposits in Post Office Savings Banks will be allowed.

8. **CONTRACT:** The Contractor will be required to sign a contract similar to the form exhibited at the same time as the plans and specifications and such contract is made subject to the Public Works (Health) Act, (R.S.C. 1927 Chapter 91.)

9. **TIME OF COMPLETION:** The work must be commenced immediately after the Contractor is notified of the acceptance of his tender, and must be proceeded with in such a manner as to ensure its completion within eight (8) months as from date of such notification.

10. **DELAYS:** No charges shall be made by the Contractor for any delays or hindrances from any cause during the progress of any portion of the work embraced in this contract. If the delay be caused by any act or neglect of the Department of Mines and Resources, the Contractor will be granted an extension of time for the completion of the work, sufficient to allow for the delay. Such extension will be determined by the Clerk of Works through the Department of Mines and Resources, providing the Contractor shall give him immediate notice of the cause in writing.

11. **WATER SUPPLY:** The Contractor is to arrange for water supply for all trades and pay all fees for same.

12. **PERMITS AND BY-LAWS:** The Contractor must obtain and pay for all permits for the execution of the work, and must pay for all charges incidental to such permits as may be required in the District, if any.

The Contractor shall make himself fully acquainted with local conditions relating to the work herein specified as he will be required to comply with all by-laws, if any, without extra compensation of any nature.

The Contractor shall furnish at his own expense all heating apparatus and fuel for heating his temporary buildings, and the office used by the Clerk of Works.

16. 19. GOODS AND MATERIALS:- All goods and materials of whatsoever nature used in the execution of this contract must be natural or manufactured products of Canada unless, in the opinion of the Minister of Mines and Resources, such goods and materials are not produced or manufactured in Canada. If goods or materials required in the execution of this contract be not produced or manufactured in Canada, preference will be given to goods and materials produced or manufactured in other parts of the British Empire.

If, in the execution of any portion of this contract, the use of coal is required, it must be of Canadian production.

The notation as to country or origin of materials should in all cases be given by bidders, if tender is to receive consideration.

Unless otherwise expressly provided in the specification, all goods and materials supplied shall conform with the specifications of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association or to the specifications of the recognized Standards Association in the country of origin in the Empire and in cases where goods or materials are required, which are not of Canadian production or manufacture, that the standards above mentioned shall apply.

20. TRANSPORTATION OF MATERIALS AND PLANT:- All material and plant used in connection with the execution of this contract must be transported over railways operating in Canada or Canadian waterways to the greatest possible extent.

21. DEFECTIVE MATERIALS:- All materials of whatsoever nature used throughout the works must be new and of the very best quality; no used, second-hand, defective, unsound or improper materials, worked on otherwise, shall be brought to the premises, or used in the building and should the Contractor in case that such material be brought, refuse to remove such material, the Minister of Mines and Resources or the Clerk of Works, or any person appointed, may cause the same to be removed and replaced with fit and proper material at the cost and charge of the Contractor and deduct the expenses from the amount due or accruing due.

No certificate given, payment made, partial or entire use of the building or equipment by the Government shall be construed as an acceptance of defective work or of improper materials and the Contractor shall make good at once, without cost to the Government, all such defective work or material and the consequence resulting therefrom, before final certificate is issued.

22. CARE OF WORK:- The Contractor will be held absolutely responsible for the care of the work and whatever appertains thereto from the commencement of same to its actual completion.

23. DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS:- The work is intended to be complete in every respect. The Contractor shall abide by and comply with the true intent and meaning of all the drawings and the specifications, taken as a whole as they are intended, to cooperate and to provide for and comprise everything necessary for the complete finish of the work. Any work shown on the drawings, even if not particularly described in the specification, or vice versa, is to be done by the Contractor as if it were both shown and specified.
Should any dispute arise respecting the true construction and meaning of the drawings or specification, or should any portion of same be obscure or capable of more than one construction, the same shall be decided by the Architect or Chief Engineer, whose decision shall be final.

All lettering on the drawings is to be considered as part of the specification and contract.

Drawings, specifications and details to be produced when required, carefully used and returned to the Department at the completion of the building.

In all cases, figured dimensions are to be followed in preference to those ascertained by scale.

24. SHOP DRAWINGS:- The Contractor shall furnish to the Architect or Chief Engineer in charge, for approval, duplicate sets of detailed shop drawings for all structural steel or any other specific work for which these drawings may be required.

The Contractor is to keep the walls covered every night and at all other times when liable to be damaged by the weather. Should any damage arise from any cause, the same shall be made good by the Contractor to the satisfaction of the Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources.

30. CLOSING DOWN WORK:- Should the work be closed down for any cause, the Contractor must assume all responsibility for its proper protection during such period. He must protect all footings, foundation work or any other work liable to be damaged.

EXCAVATION AND DRAINAGE

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

1. CLEARING SITE: The Contractor shall examine site and before any work is commenced shall clear and free the site of all obstructions, remove all trees and other obstructions as required for the site of the building.

2. SETTING OUT OF WORK: The Contractor shall obtain exact highway line and refer to the Plot Plans and set out of the work as for size, locations, depths, and grades.

The Contractor shall employ a competent person during the construction of the building to establish all lines, levels, column centres, etc. No work shall be proceeded with until such lines, levels and centres have been approved by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works.

The building shall be placed on the site as indicated by the Plot Plan, Sheet No. 1 of the drawings. The site is considered generally flat. The excavation from the basement shall be graded around the premises to a height of about 1'6", which will require that amount of less excavation as shown by the sections. The premises all around shall be graded using the top soil of the excavation, and shall all be left ready for sod or seeding.

3. SCOPE OF WORK: The excavation work required under this contract shall be the excavating of all trenches, footings, basements, piers, drains, etc., as required for all of the buildings, as shown by the Plot Plan, septic tank, flag pole base and sump, all as shown and required by the several drawings and sections thereof.

4. EXCAVATION AND DISPOSAL: The Contractor shall examine the Plot Plan together with the site, and shall make any further necessary soil tests at his own expense if required. All excavation shall be to the depths indicated by the several sections on the several plans. Excavate for all footings, walls, piers, drains for sewer and water, drains for water supply from lake, and all excavation for all inside and outside piping. All excavation shall be carried to depths shown on the drawings. Excavate for drains both inside and outside for all traces to such depths as directed, to insure proper fall. All excavation for main walls shall be 1/2" larger on all sides than the size of buildings, to allow for proper execution of the work. Do all refilling after all drains have been inspected. Excavate for roads, driveway and walks as required.

All excavation shall be levelled on the site where directed and refilled, packed, rolled and graded to the approval of the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works.

Should it be necessary to do any blasting, this Contractor shall employ competent persons and all precautions shall be taken to prevent damage to property or injury to persons or animals. The Contractor shall be held solely responsible for all accidents to life or property.

5. UNIT PRICE - EXTRA EXCAVATION: When the excavations have been completed to the various depths and extent as shown on or required by the drawings for the proper installation of the work, the Contractor shall immediately notify the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works so that he may have the same inspected and tested if necessary. If in the opinion of the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works it should be found necessary, the excavations shall be carried to greater depth or extent than shown on drawings and the Contractor will be entitled to additional payment only for such extra excavated material as authorized. The Contractor will be held responsible and will not be entitled to extra payment should he carry the excavations to a greater depth or extent without authority from the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works.

The drain pipes shall be bedded in such a manner that the pipes will rest solidly for their entire length. No drain pipes are to be laid until the trenches for same have been inspected and approved; nor any drain to be covered in before being tested and approved. The filling in over all drains shall be done in the most careful manner with approved material furnished by the Contractor so as not to damage or displace the pipes; and the filling in shall be well rammed at every foot in height to the finished ground surface.

Drains to septic tank and disposal bed shall be of best quality, slip-glazed socket-joined, earthenware pipes from the main line to septic tank of such sizes as indicated on the drawings, filletted with the best Portland cement on a gasket of oakum and to be provided with all necessary bends and junctions, etc. All pipes shall be accurately laid with proper and approved fell. Each pipe shall be closely butted into the socket of the preceding pipe, and special care must be taken that any excess cement is neatly cleaned off as each joint is made.
Any earth, cement or material is to be thoroughly cleaned out of the pipes by driving a closely fitting wad through them as the work proceeds.

The size of the pipes and the quantity thereof and the method of laying shall be as indicated on the drawings showing the septic tank.

The pipes from septic tank to filter beds shall be graded towards the latter. No-Co-Rode Perforated Fibre Tile, or equal, in the filter bed shall be laid level and shall be laid on a prepared gravel bed covered with 18" of gravel.

Provide and lay 6" No-Co-Rode Perforated Fibre Tile, or equal, in line with the bottom of footings all around main building, carried to a lower level as indicated on the plot plan emptying into a prepared sump. The 6" No-Co-Rode Perforated Fibre Tile, or equal, around building shall have proper slope and shall be covered with clean stone, straw and paper as will be directed in such a manner that sand will be prevented from entering into No-Co-Rode Perforated Fibre Tile, or equal, pipes.

12. IRON DRAINS:- Refer to "Plumbing and Drainage."

13. CLEANING UP PREMISES:- Upon completion of the building, the Contractor shall thoroughly clean up the premises, removing all rubbish, building materials and debris, both in and around the building.

CONCRETE WORK

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

SCOPE OF WORK: The work required to be done under this Contract will be all the concrete work of all walls, footings, piers, septic tank and sump, concrete steps and slabs, all as shown by the several drawings hereto attached and as hereinafter specified.

1. PORTLAND CEMENT: All cement shall be first-class Portland cement of a standard brand, bearing a good reputation and of uniform quality. It shall be free from lumps and be packed in barrels or strong cloth sacks. Each package shall have printed upon it the brand and name of the Manufacturers. All cement shall conform with the requirements of the Standards Specification for Portland cement of the Canadian Engineering Standards Association. The cement shall be protected from the weather and the floor upon which it is placed shall be at least 6 inches above the ground. It shall be stored so as to permit of easy access for inspection and identification of each shipment. A sufficient quantity shall be kept on hand at all times so that tests may be made to determine its quality. At least 12 days shall be allowed for inspection and the necessary test. The Contractor shall furnish mill cement tests from start to finish and hand same to the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works from time to time during the construction.

2. FINE AGGREGATE: The fine aggregate used for making concrete shall be clean sand, free from clay, loam, mud and other impurities and shall be washed if required. It shall be well graded mixture of coarse and fine grains with the coarse grains predominating and shall be screened to remove all particles not passing a ¼" mesh.

3. COARSE AGGREGATE: The coarse aggregate used for making concrete shall be hard, compact and durable broken stone of approved quality free from dirt and graded to size ranging from ¼" to 4" for concrete referred to as Class "B" and ¼" to 1½" for concrete referred to as Class "A."

4. WATER: Provide a supply of clean, fresh water for use of all the works.

5. STRENGTH OF CONCRETE: All concrete for exterior basement walls, footings and basement floor slab shall have a compressive strength at the age of 28 days of 3000 lbs. per square inch with a water cement ratio of 4½ Imperial Gallons of water per 97½ lbs. net sack of cement.

6. WATER-CEMENT RATIO: All concrete must be proportioned to give the necessary workability without exceeding the quantities of mixing water stipulated in Clause 5. This water-cement ratio is the maximum permissible. The mixes shall be proportioned for somewhat lower ratios so that with the normal fluctuations from batch-to-batch this ratio will not be exceeded. Moisture contained in the aggregates must be included as part of the mixing water in computing the water-cement ratio.

The water-cement ratio shall not be changed except when directed by the Department's Representative. In the event of such change being ordered, the Contractor shall do so without extra cost to the Government.

7. CONCRETE PROPORTIONS: The proportions of aggregate to cement for concrete of the water-cement ratio specified shall be such as to produce concrete of the consistency specified hereafter.
The approximate proportion of the volume of cement to the sum of the separate volumes of fine and coarse aggregate measured dry is one of cement to 4\(\frac{1}{2}\) parts of aggregate and shall be adjusted to give proper workability. The supervising Architect or the Clerk of Works reserves the right to increase or diminish the proportions of aggregate if found necessary, without extra cost to the Government. All concrete referred to as Class "A" shall have coarse aggregate of a maximum size of \(1\frac{1}{2}\)" and that referred to as Class "B" shall have coarse aggregate of a maximum size of 2".

The combined aggregate shall be such composition of sizes that when separated by the #4 sieve the weight retained on the sieve shall be not less than one-third nor more than two-thirds of the total.

The proportions of fine and coarse aggregate shall be such that the ratio of the fine to total shall be not less nor more than that given in the following table, nor shall the amount of coarse material be such as to produce harshness in placing or honey-combing:

| Maximum size of coarse aggregate inches | Ratio of fine to total aggregate on basis of dry and compact volumes |
|----------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|
|                                        | Minimum | Maximum |
| \(1\frac{1}{2}"\) (Class "A" concrete) | .30     | .50     |
| "B"                                    | .40     | .60     |

In case the concrete resulting from a mixture of aggregates approaching the extreme limits of gradation is not of a workable character or when finished does not exhibit a proper surface, the Contractor shall alter the grading as will be directed by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works, the water-cement ratio remaining constant.

8. CONTROL OF PROPORTIONS:- The methods of measuring materials shall be such that the proportions of water to cement can be easily controlled during the progress of the work and easily checked at any time. The aggregates shall be of uniform quality and grading and shall be delivered to the building and handled in such a manner that variations in moisture content shall not occur.

9. MIXING:- All materials for concrete are to be mixed by a mechanical batch mixer of approved type equipped with suitable charging hopper, reservoirs and measuring devices for all materials. The rim speed of the mixer shall be about 200' per minute and the charge not exceeding the Manufacturer's rated capacity. The mixing of each batch shall continue for not less than three minutes after all the materials are in the mixer. No hand mixing of concrete will be permitted.

10. CONSISTENCY:- The concrete shall be of a plastic consistency which shall be so established by the Department's Representative who may employ the slump test for maintaining the consistency required.

11. SLUMP TESTS:- The Contractor shall provide a metal form of #20 gauge galvanized iron for making slump tests also a 5/8" metal rod 21" long. The form shall be 4" diameter at the top and 8" diameter at the bottom and 12" high. Tests shall be made by the Contractor in the presence of the Inspector, once or twice daily, as may be directed by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works. The slump shall be from 2" to 4" for plain concrete and 4" to 6" for reinforced concrete. All test samples shall be marked and stored where directed by the supervising Architect or Clerk of Works, and shipped.

When after excavation isolated areas show signs of frost, no concrete shall be placed before such areas are free of frost. No walls or footings shall be placed on frozen ground.

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

1. PAINTING:- This Contractor shall carefully examine the plans of the buildings and the specifications of other trades to ascertain the amount and character of the work required to be painted, such as carpentry, sheet metal, iron work, etc. This Contractor shall include for painting all exposed plumbing and heating pipes and covering, also all radiators and the outside of plumbing fixtures that are not enamelled.

PREPARATION FOR PAINTING:- This Contractor shall go over the building to see that all nail heads in finished woodwork have been countersunk, that all work has been properly executed and that all is ready for painting. ROOFING, FLASHING AND VENTILATION

All clauses set forth in the General and Labour Conditions shall apply to and govern this trade.

1. SCOPE OF WORK:- The work required under this contract will be the covering of all roofs with tar, felt and gravel as hereinafter specified. All tinsmithing and ventilation work is also required under this contract.

2. GENERAL:- The roofing Contractor shall examine the roof decks before commencing the work and arrange with the General Contractor to rectify any defects. He shall also co-operate with other trades in placing of flashing, ventilation, etc.

All roof work shall be done in a neat and workmanlike manner free from defects and left perfect on completion.

3. INSULATION:- Insulation of all roofs as shown on the several sections and drawings shall be as provided under the Carpenter and Joinery Trade.

4. ROOFING:- Over roof deck as specified under the Carpentry Specification, lay one thickness of sheathing paper or unsaturated felt lapping, the sheets at least one inch. Over this lay two plies of fifteen pound tarred rag felt lapping, each sheet 19 inches over preceding one and nail as often as necessary to hold in place until remaining felt is laid; coat the entire surface uniformly with pitch; then over the entire surface, lay three plies of tarred felt lapping, each sheet 24" over preceding one mopping with pitch the full 24" lap on each sheet so that no place shall felt touch felt. Such nailing as is necessary shall be done along the upper edge of each sheet so that all nails will be covered by not less than two plies of felt. Over the entire surface, pour from a dipper a uniform coating of pitch into which, while hot, embed not less than 400 pounds of gravel for each one hundred square feet. The gravel shall be from ¼" to 5/8" in size, dry and free from dirt. Care shall be taken during the application that felt is laid without wrinkles or buckles. Not less than 150 pounds of pitch shall be used for the construction of each 100 sq. ft. of completed roof, and the pitch shall not be heated above 400 degrees Fahrenheit. At the edge of all roofs, the felt shall be turned down over fascia or cornice 3" and trimmed off neatly. At the intersection of horizontal and vertical surfaces, flash walls and roof as shown on the drawings.

5. FLASHING:- The contractor is to do all flashing as shown by the several drawings. Flash at all mouldings under asbestos siding shingles and the two inch gravel strip as shown by the several sections. The flashing shall be of 26 gauge galvanized iron and shall be stop flashed and carried up to the height as indicated, and all flashing shall be back painted before being placed into position. All flashing shall be properly interlocked and soldered in workmanlike manner.

6. VENTILATION:- Contractor shall supply and install one kitchen range hood as shown on drawings, Sheet No. 3, made of twenty gauge steel, neatly shaped as shown. The range vent stack will be made of 24 gauge steel connected to cowl vent through roof.

Provide one 12" Robertson, or equal, exhaust vent over diesel engine in Boiler Room, properly flashed to roof. All galvanized iron vents extending through roofs shall be asphaltum covered.

The engine shall be equipped with radiator cooling, using a blower fan to discharge the cooling air outside the powerhouse.

The ventilating system for this engine cooling shall be thermostatically controlled and so arranged that the hot air from the radiator shall be recirculated in the engine room whenever the engine room temperature is below the thermostat setting. The engine shall be equipped with electric starting supplied from a tapping on the main battery bank at a voltage to suit the engine starting system. The engine speed shall not be in excess of 1500 r.p.m. and shall be accurately governed at this speed by a gear driven governor mounted on the engine.

The engine shall be suitable for operation on furnace fuel oil and shall be supplied from the main storage tank and all necessary piping and controls shall be included.

The exhaust from the engine shall be equipped with a flexible exhaust bend acoustic type of muffler, wall thimble with insulation and 15' of suitable pipe to cut to size at the site.

7. CONDENSATE PUMPING UNITS: The condensate pumping units will be automatic in operation and shall be single or duplex as shown on the drawings. They will be vertical or horizontal type as indicated.

Horizontal units shall consist of one or two pumps, each direct-connected to their motors with a single receiver, all mounted on a suitable cast iron or steel base. The pumps shall be of the Centrifugal or Turbine type, bronze fitted throughout with impellers of bronze or corrosion-resistant metal as approved by the Department. The pumps shall be free from air binding when handling condensate with temperatures up to 200 degs. F. Motors will be drip-proof or equally protected motors. Receivers shall be not less than 3/16 inch thick black iron or steel and shall be provided with all the necessary reinforced through openings, including condensate return vent, overflow and pump suction connections. Receivers shall have an approved rust resisting coating on the inside. The vent pipe shall be galvanized steel and the fittings shall be galvanized malleable iron. The vent pipe shall be extended so as to provide against damage through escaping steam or water. Basket type cast iron dirt strainers will be supplied at the inlet of each pump. Vertical Units will conform to the above except that the pumps and motors will be for vertical operation, and the pumps will be constructed for operation submerged in hot water. Bearings and glands will be suitable for such operation.

Float switches will have copper ball floats tested to not less than 25 pounds pressure and shall have an overload relay incorporated in the switch. Float rods will have stuffing boxes; float will be of adequate size to operate the float switches without binding or sticking.

The pumping units shall be tested by the manufacturer before shipment and a certified copy of the test data of each pump shall be submitted to the engineer. Pumps shall be tested with hot water at 200 degs. F.

Slip type, double guided expansion joints shall be installed where shown on the drawings or directed by the Engineer. The joints shall be single or double slip joints, as required, and shall be designed to carry the weight of the expansion tube by means of machined guides at both ends of the tubes. A gland will not be considered as a guiding element. Expansion tubes shall be fitted at one end with piston guides that are so designed as to prevent wearing of grooves in bearing surfaces. The body of each joint shall be of fine grained grey cast iron. Expansion tubes shall be accurately machined and provided with suitable protective plating. Each expansion joint shall have a traverse suitable for application, but not less than 4 inches for each slip. All joints shall be designed for w.p. of 125 lbs. per square in. gauge.

Piping running in concrete floor construction will be either run in trench with ventilated cover, or pipe will be copper with gaskets to insulate the two different metals.

Pressure reducing valves with by-passes as shown on plans shall be supplied and installed as shown on plans. The main P.R.V. will be double seat, lever and weight type, flanged valve. The smaller valve will be single seat, lever and weight type, suitable for dead-end service. Valve for kitchen steam and medium pressure heating service will be single seat, spring type, suitable for dead-end service.

9. CONVICTOR RADIATORS:- Convictor radiators shall be of type and sizes indicated on the plans. Heating elements and enclosures will be the product of one manufacturer. Elements will be fin and tube type with universal headers and with suitable side plates and tube supports. Radiators will have not less than 60 sq. ft. of heating surface per s. ft. of E.D.R. Fins will be permanently attached to tubes. Fins may be aluminum or copper; tubes to be copper not less than 3/8 O.D. Assembly will be tested at factory to withstand a pressure of 125 pounds per square inch gauge pressure. Enclosures or Cabinets will be made of cold rolled steel, not less than .062 gauge or of aluminum alloy not less than .064 inches thick, properly stiffened and braced. Panel fronts will be removable and attached to enclosure with slotted fasteners or other permanent type fasteners. Exposed corners or ends will be rounded. Steel enclosures will be given a ground coat of paint by the manufacturer before shipping to protect them against rust. Ratings will be based on a standard test code and under standard conditions of 70 degrees still air with 36 inch enclosure height. One pound per square inch gauge for steam and average water temperature of 195 degrees F for gravity water under 190 degrees F for final water with heat emission of 240 BTU and 150 BTU per square foot per hour respectively.

Extended surface steel-tube type radiators shall be of the type and sizes indicated on plans and shall consist of 1/2 inch seamless condenser type tubing with 3/8 inch square fins mechanically bonded to tubing, with either 50 or 38 fins per foot. Heaters will be suspended on suitable brackets and supplied with or without enclosures as indicated. Ratings indicated on plans are based on elements without enclosures and with steam pressure or average water temperature shown on plans still air at 60 deg. F and with heat emission of 240 BTU and 150 BTU per sq. ft. per hour respectively. Elements will be suitable for pressures up to 200 lbs. per sq. inch gauge. Elements will be joined together by means of malleable iron unions. Enclosures will be expanded metal covers or sheet steel covers with integral grille of not less than 16 gauge metal and given a ground coat of paint by the manufacturer before shipment. Dampers of an approved type will be supplied with all Convector Radiators or extended surface steel tube radiators when so indicated on plans.

10. UNIT HEATERS:- Unit Heaters will have capacities not less than those shown on the drawings. Inlet connections shall be the same size as those shown on the drawings. Unit Heaters will be rated on a basis of 240 BTU per hour per sq. ft., D.R. for steam and 150 BTU for water, in accordance with standard test codes and unless otherwise indicated will conform to the following. Ratings shall not exceed those shown by more than 25%.

Steam units will be rated on a basis of 60 degs. F. entering air temperature and 2 lbs. per sq. inch gauge pressure. Forced hot water units on a basis of an average water temperature of 190 degs. F. and for gravity on a basis of 195 degs. F.

Unit Heaters shall be the product of an approved Canadian firm recognized as being engaged in manufacture of Unit Heaters and advertising as such.

Unit Heater motors to be designed so as not to cause radio interference of any kind. Units to operate without undue noise or vibration.

Heating element will be of the fin and tube type, sized and connections suitable for the operating pressure of the system to which they form a part. Tubes will be not less than 1/2 inch O.D. red brass .025" wall thickness. Fins may be aluminum or copper with permanent contact between fin and tube. Headers for units to operate under 150 pounds per sq. inch gauge pressure may be of close grained grey cast iron with permanent leak-proof connection between tube and headers.

For units to operate over 150 pounds per square inch gauge pressure and up to 500 pounds, headers shall be seamless copper or brass tubing with tubes brazed to headers with high temperature brazing alloy. Heaters will be given a hydrostatic test of 150 or 500 pounds per square inch gauge respectively and a certificate to this effect shall be supplied by the manufacturer and delivered to the engineer. The heating element will be mounted so that it is easily removable. Steam heaters subject to inlet air temperature below freezing or when shown as required will be equipped with an approved method of distributing the steam evenly across the coil.

Propeller type Unit Heaters shall be of the suspended type arranged for horizontal or vertical discharge of air, as indicated on drawings. Motors will be totally enclosed. Horizontal unit motors to be gear yarn lubricated. Vertical Unit motors to be ball bearing grease lubricated, designed for vertical operation and mounted in such a manner so as to be protected from damage by heat from the coil. Casings shall be solid and rigid and of approved finish. Suitable efficient air deflectors shall be provided on all horizontal units. Motor speeds will not exceed those indicated. Units will be equipped with suitable mounting or hanger brackets.

Multiblade type unit heaters with a capacity of under 100,000 Btu will be Trane Force-Flo Convectors or approved equal, arranged for floor, wall or ceiling mounting, as indicated, and be equipped with variable speed motors with double shaft extensions and two fans mounted on motor shafts. Cabinets will be of attractive appearance with air inlet and outlet to approval. They will generally be finished to blend with the Convector-radiators.

Unit Heaters will be controlled automatically by thermostats located where shown on the drawings. Thermostats will be high voltage type with thermometer and fitted with locking device. Range 5° to 85 degs. F. A Thermal type switch will provide manual shut-off and protect the motors.

11. STEAM TRAPS:— Thermostatic Traps shall be installed in the return connection from each radiator and elsewhere as indicated on the drawings. The size and capacity of the traps will be as indicated on the drawings or as approved by the Contracting Officer, but in no case less than 200 sq. ft. of equivalent steam radiation. Drip Traps for Mains, Risers and similar lines shall be installed with a cooling leg of 5 ft. of uncovered 3" pipe. The capacity of all traps shall be based on a pressure differential of three pounds per square inch. The Traps shall be designed for steam working pressure of 15 pounds per square inch gauge, but shall operate with a supply pressure of approximately 5 pounds per square inch gauge. The traps shall be of the patterns best suited to the units they serve and will have union inlet connections.

Float and Thermostatic Traps shall be designed for a steam working pressure of 15 pounds per square inch gauge, but shall operate with supply pressure of approximately five pounds per square inch gauge. The capacity of the traps shall be as indicated on the drawings or as directed by the Engineer, but in no case less than 200 pounds of condensate per hour. The traps capacity shall be based on pressure differential of three pounds per square inch. Each Float and Thermostatic Trap shall be provided with a hard bronze valve seat and mechanism and a float of brass, all of which can be easily removed for inspection or replacement without disturbing the piping connections. The inlet to each trap shall have a brass strainer as an integral or separate part of the trap.

Bucket Traps will be used for all steam pressures 30 pounds per square inch gauge or over and where they must function against elevated returns. Bodies will be semi-steel, seats and plungers of heat-treated, stainless steel. Traps will be sized with load factors of not less than 3 to 1, based on full discharge capacity at the minimum pressure differential.

12. VALVES:— Valves shall be installed at the locations shown on the drawings where specified and where required for the proper function of the system. Gate Valves shall be used unless otherwise shown, specified or directed. All valves shall be installed with their stems or spindles above the horizontal. Radiator Valves shall be plated bronze body, packless valves of the quick opening type, fitted with black heat resisting, non-breakable composition wheel handles. Stems are to be non-rising and valve seats removable. Radiator Valves will be bellows, packless type or diaphragm packless type.

13. STRAINERS:— Basket or 'Y' type Strainers shall be of the same size as the pipe lines in which they are installed. The strainer bodies shall be heavy and durable of the best grade grey cast iron with bottoms drilled and plugged. The bodies shall have arrows clearly cast on the side to indicate the direction of flow. Each Strainer shell be equipped with an easy removable cover and sediment basket. Basket shall be of not less than .025 inch thick, 22 gauge, sheet brass, having perforations to provide a net free area through the basket of at least four times that of the entering pipe. The flow shall be into the basket and out through the perforations.

14. ELECTRICAL WORK: This contractor shall be responsible for all necessary wiring in connection with this heating system and supply all switches, thermostats, etc., required for proper performance of the heating equipment. All units and associated thermostats to be wired to circuits provided by others.

No wire smaller than #12 B&S gauge shall be installed. Wiring shall be concealed wherever building construction permits. All electrical work shall be done by qualified electricians and shall be in accordance with the Rules and Regulations of the Local Authorities and of the Canadian Electrical Code. The contractor shall obtain all necessary permits and, on completion of the job, shall obtain a certificate of acceptance from the Provincial Inspection Department for the Officer in charge of Works.

15. CLEANING BOILER AND PIPING: Before any covering is installed, the entire Heating System will be cleaned under supervision of the Engineer. Each boiler will be filled with water and fire started. A temporary connection will be made from the safety valve or surface blow off opening to the sewer or elsewhere outside the building. The boiler Stop Valve will be closed. When the water in the boiler starts boiling, the feed cock shall be opened a small amount and sufficient to keep the water in the boiler at the point where the water, oil and grease will siphon through the hose connection at the top of the boiler. This will be kept up for two hours during which time a good fire will be maintained and not over five pounds per square inch gauge pressure will be kept on the boiler. Should steady water line not be obtained when the stop valves are opened and the entire system connected to the boiler, then the above process will be repeated as often as necessary. When the boiler has been cleaned, a steam pressure of ten pounds gauge will be maintained on the entire system for a period of six hours or for sufficient time to allow of inspection of all heating units, pipe fittings and specialties to be made by the Engineer. Any leaks found will be noted and made good and the test will be repeated as often as necessary until no leaks can be found. During the above test or tests, temporary connections will be made from the return mains to sewer or out of doors and no condensate will be allowed to enter pump receivers. The receiver will be inspected and cleaned during this period. During the test, all units must heat uniformly and without noise. Any trap found defective or any cases of water hammer whatsoever must be corrected. All strainers will be inspected and cleaned as often as necessary to insure that the system has been cleared of all dirt, oil, grease, sand or scale.

16. BOILER COVERING: If unjacketed the boiler shall be covered with magnesia, glass-fiber, or rock-wool insulation at least 1/8" thick. Insulation shall be applied over 1/8" mesh wire netting. The netting shall be held away from the boiler by metal spacers fastened to the wire. A finish coat, containing a suitable amount of Portland cement, shall be applied and trowelled to a hard smooth surface. Cleanout and access doors shall not be insulated, but the insulation shall be neatly bevelled off at the edges of such openings.

17. PIPE COVERING: Steam piping exposed in heated spaces and all piping located in unheated spaces shall be insulated with pipe covering. All concealed piping shall be covered. Pipe covering for piping carrying steam with pressure of 30 lbs. per square inch or over and piping exposed in unexcavated spaces shall be of standard-thickness magnesia, or a mineral wool, glass-fibre, or vermiculite of such thickness as to give an overall thermal conductivity at the applicable temperature not in excess of standard-thickness magnesia. All other pipe covering shall be asbestos air-cell, one inch thick, or equivalent pipe covering approved by the Engineer. All covering shall be held in place with brass strips not less than 1/4" wide. Strips shall be spaced...
to hold the centre end ends of each section and in no case shall the spacing exceed 18 inches. Valves and fittings, except unions and flanges, shall be covered with magnesia cement, glass-fibre, or mineral-wool cement of the same thickness as the pipe covering. All plastic insulation shall be protected by means of cotton sheeting, weighing not less than 3.5 ounces per yard per 37½ inches wide, pasted neatly over the material.

18. PAINTING AND FINISHING:- This contractor will be responsible for painting and finishing in all unfinished rooms or spaces including Boiler Room, Pump Room, etc. All floors, walls and ceilings will be left in a clean condition and in good state of repair. All exposed piping and iron work of stokers, boilers, pumps, etc., will be given two coats of paint to colour as selected by the Engineer. Paint will be high quality and suitable for the surface to be covered and must be approved by the Engineer before use.

19. TOOLS:- All tools necessary for the proper operation and maintenance of the pumps and other equipment shall be installed in a location and in a manner acceptable to the Engineer.

20. OPERATING AND MAINTENANCE INSTRUCTIONS:- Printed instructions covering the operation and maintenance of each item of equipment shall be posted at locations designated by the Engineer. Upon completion of the work and at a time designated by the Engineer, the services of a competent engineer shall be provided for a period of not less than one day to instruct a representative of the government in the operation and maintenance of the heating systems. Parts lists for all equipment will be supplied.

21. TEST:- Upon completion and prior to acceptance of the installation, the contractor shall subject the heating system to such operating tests as may be required by the Engineer to demonstrate satisfactory functional and operating efficiency. Operating tests shall cover a period of not less than six hours for each system, and all tests shall be conducted at such times as the Engineer may direct. All instruments, facilities and labour required to properly conduct the tests shall be provided by the contractor at no additional cost to the Government and all fuel, water and electricity required for the tests will be furnished by the Government.

22. PNEUMATIC CONTROLS:- Pneumatic Controls may be provided in lieu of electrical controls. Where pneumatic controls are furnished, an air compressor of the standard piston type, complete with tank, valves, gauges, filters and the necessary appurtenances shall be provided. All air lines shall consist of suitable tubing with airtight fittings. The air compressor and tank shall be located as directed by the Engineer.

23. GUARANTEE:- The following equipment to be furnished under this section of the specifications shall be guaranteed for a period of one year from the date of final acceptance thereof against defective materials, design and workmanship:

Boiler
Boiler Fittings and Fixtures
Automatic Heat-Regulating Equipment
Condensate Pumping Units
Unit Heaters
Heating and Ventilating Units
Steam Traps
Pressure Reducing Valves
Radiators
Convector
Valves

Upon receipt of notice from the Government of failure of any part of the guaranteed equipment during the guarantee period, the affected part or parts shall be replaced promptly with new parts without additional cost to the Government. In addition, there will be provided a written guarantee of performance from the boiler manufacturers covering the boiler, oil burner and control equipment.

Major D.M. MacKay, Director,

Dear Major MacKay;

I am writing in regard to some used lumber stored at Teslin, Y.T. This lumber came from dismantled Army buildings and was purchased by the Indian Affairs Branch about three years ago, with a view of using it for the construction of temporary buildings, while the proposed Residential School was being built. Inasmuch as the Residential School site was transferred to Lower Post, this material has been lying here at Teslin, unused and is rapidly deteriorating.

I believe that we could make very good use of this lumber and certain pieces of equipment at the Lower Post Residential School for the construction of service buildings, such as garage, storehouse etc. If we could obtain this material now, it would save us considerable expense later on. Furthermore if it is left much longer where it is, its value will be so impaired as to be of little value to anyone. If we were able to obtain this material for the Lower Post School, we would be careful to finish and paint any buildings made with it, so as to harmonize with the new main building.

The equipment in question consists of several thousand feet of used lumber, beams, rafters, flooring and some V-joint; also a steel storage tank and a couple of stoves. Not so very far in the future we will be looking for material like this and it would be a decided help to have this on hand.

I have not seen the Lower Post School for the past six weeks, as I have been travelling around the Territory. However latest reports from the Army supervisor indicate that construction is going very well. I trust that you will give the above request your sympathetic attention.

With kind personal regards.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

You will find enclosed the list of equipment etc. for the Indian School at Lower Post, which supplements the previous list forwarded to you. I am also returning the list which you kindly sent me some time ago. I have tried to make my list as complete as possible and hope the Department will find it satisfactory. I would respectfully suggest that the equipment and appliances be of a heavy duty type for institutional purposes; thus the children's crockery should be of hotel ware type. If plastic is chosen, there should be a guarantee that it will stand up under very hot water. Enamelware is not at all suitable for kitchen pots. It chips and leads to unsanitary conditions. The regular heavy hotelware type lasts almost indefinitely, new bottoms can be put in when necessary and each vessel re-tinned yearly at small cost.

There will be need for quite a bit of shelving to be erected after the contractor is finished, and in certain rooms well finished heavy seat benches should be installed. For these purposes I have requested lumber, which can be supplied by a local mill for $70.00 per M. If there is any question about the list please get in touch with me.

The school is coming along nicely. The top floor is just about completed and the painters will soon start decorating. DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Attached you will find requisitions for equipment and supplies for the Lower Post Indian Residential School. This school is a new building and the requirements are for all items required for the opening and efficient operation of the school. It is expected that the school will go into operation on or about January 1, 1951. The capacity of the school is for approximately 120 pupils plus a staff of 20 adults. The Department is anxious to provide the most suitable equipment for an institution of this size. It should be noted that the Specifications definitely state that all changes must receive the approval of and be authorized by this Department where the authority originates.

Kindly give this matter your immediate attention.

Yours very truly,

Chas. H. Buck,
Chief, Engineering and Construction Service.

Table shall be provided with doors along one side, fitted to slide in stainless steel track. Doors shall have cast aluminum handles, similar to that shown on Page 91 of McClary Food Service Equipment Catalogue.

8. LAUNDRY TUBS: Laundry tubs shall be as shown, one two-compartment 24" x 48", and one one-compartment 22" x 48". They shall be of porcelain enamelled cast iron, one piece, flat rim, with integral back, on painted adjustable pedestals, Crane C31228, or equal. The two-compartment laundry tub shall have C32740-S, or equal, swinging spout faucet with soap dish. The one-compartment laundry tub shall have C31220 P" Teiss, or equal, compression faucets.
