9. BOILER FOR LAUNDRY: The boiler for the laundry shall be placed where shown in the Boiler Room and shall be semi-portable, hand fired, 15 h.p., built for 125 lb. working power pressure, and operated at 100 lb. pressure with grates for wood, similar to Eclipse type as manufactured by E. Leonard & Sons, Limited, London, Ontario, or equal, complete with all fittings and fixtures, including operating valves, safety valves, water glass, 16 gauge iron smoke breeching with control dampers connecting to chimney, injector and piping. Boiler shall be lined with 4½" fire brick laid in high temperature cement, 1½" Vitrobestos, ¼" steel casing, and shall be

covered with 1" thick magnesia blocks, securely wired on to the boiler, and finished with 2" coat of asbestos cement, trowelled to a hard, smooth finish. 10. STEAM AND RETURN SYSTEM:- This contract shall include the furnishing of all steam and return lines, with all valves, and steam separating traps (lift type). Supply and install with system an electric driven boiler feed pump of the pressure equalizing type, having a capacity of not less than 150% of the boiler rating. 11. WATER LINES, DRAINS AND ELECTRICAL CONNECTIONS:- This contract shall include the setting of equipment, and the providing of all necessary hot and cold water lines, drains and electrical connections. Electrical connections will be made from the panel in the Heating Plant. Hot and cold water connections will be made from source in the Heating Plant. Drainage will be to drain in building. Major D.M. MacKay, Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Major MacKay;

Some time ago, I wrote you in regard to our obtaining for the use of the new Indian School at Lower Post, some lumber and equipment, that has been stored at Teslin for a number of years. I am now pleased to say that Mr. Neary has authorized me to take possession of this material and I wish to thank you for your kind attention to my request.

You will be glad to know that the new school is rapidly nearing completion. It appears to be very satisfactory and the Department deserves great credit for this undertaking. I am rather anxiously looking forward to the opening and hope that we will be successful in making this institution a real benefit to the Indian people, according to your purpose.

I have written to Dr. Tennant, requesting that the Department authorize the employment of a trained nurse at the Lower Post School. I have given him the reasons, at length, why a nurse is specially needed on the staff of this school. It is sufficient to say now that I know of no more important part of the school personnel, when our extremely isolated position is considered. I would be very grateful for your kind assistance and recommendation, when my request reaches the Department.

I wish to take this opportunity of thanking you for past kindnesses in my relations with the Department. With kind regards.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I.

Referring to the conversation with yourself by our General Manager, Mr. L. A. Wendling and myself before Christmas, concerning your Request for Quotation No. 2602, File 4/37 for the newer Post Indian Residential School, I have now had word from Mr. Wendling along the following lines.

After consultation with our engineers, it is not considered feasible to have a thinner plywood on the 8' and 10' banquet tables than presently given, as they do not consider the table would have sufficient top strength. Therefore it is suggested in both cases adding 1/4" thick brown linoleum glued on to our regular tables too, although this would mean there would be nothing around the edge of this linoleum, but we do believe it would be so glued that there would be no trouble with pupils prying it loose with their finger nails. The extra costs for the above would be as follows:

(a) The 9 folding banquet tables 30" x 96" would be priced at $5.75 additional each, which would give an individual cost of $27.75 each, plus 5% sales tax, plus the same freight as originally quoted.

(b) On the 15 folding banquet tables 30" x 120" there would be an additional charge of $6.25 each, which would come to $53.75 each, plus 5% sales tax, plus the same freight as originally quoted.
Concerning the kindergarten tables 36" x 48" with book shelf, we feel that the reinforcing we discussed with you can be done at no extra charge, although to be on the safe side it would be appreciated if you would consider $1.50 extra for each table, if this is necessary, on future orders. However, we feel it can be done at the same price as originally quoted you, namely $25.25 per table, plus sales tax, plus freight.

Your early comments will be awaited with a great deal of interest, and we would appreciate receiving this additional business.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Attached you will find requisitions for equipment and supplies for the Lower Post Indian Residential School. This school is a new building and the requirements are for all items required for the opening and efficient operation of the school. It is expected that the school will go into operation on or about January 1, 1951. It is, therefore, respectfully requested that every effort be made to have this equipment delivered prior to that date.

The capacity of the school is for approximately 120 pupils plus a staff of 20 adults. The Department is anxious to provide the most suitable equipment for an institution of this size. The large stock pots should be in bi-metal or aluminum. The smaller articles should be in aluminum or stainless steel. Enamelware will not be acceptable except where indicated.

For dishes and dinnerware, the heavy hotelware chinaware should be supplied. Plastic will not be accepted.

For staff, dinnerware and flatware, Eaton's Western catalogue was used as a guide. Simpson's Western catalogue was not satisfactory as many of the items were missing.

As Dawson Creek is 620 miles from the school, it is imperative that this Branch be informed immediately when an order has been placed with a firm, in order that we might inform the parties concerned to be on the lookout for the ordered items and arrange for trucking as soon as the items reach the end of the railway. Therefore, it would be
appreciated if our copies would be forwarded to this office as soon as the suppliers copy has been sent out.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Indian Education.

Encl:

Dear Bishop Coudert:

Lower Post Indian Residential School

In your letter of January 3rd forwarding accounts for rental of school buildings, you referred to the Lower Post Residential School.

The purchase of the truck has not yet been finally completed, but it is expected that we will receive the Purchase Order within the next week. There is no doubt about obtaining the truck, but as I explained to you when you were in Ottawa, there are a great number of formalities to be carried out before vehicles can be purchased, and while the delay is apparently bothering Father Fleury, it is due to circumstances beyond our control.

We have, however, placed purchase orders for a major portion of the furnishings required for the school. Copies of these purchase orders have been addressed to Father Fleury at Watson Lake, and as I was not certain if he had left Saskatoon, a copy of our letter to Watson Lake was also forwarded to him at Saskatoon. In the majority of cases, we requested the firm to ship at the earliest possible date and I feel that by February 15th some of the furnishings at least should reach the school. We have notified North American Trucking and Transporting Co. Limited, that they are to handle the trucking of the equipment from Dawson Creek to the school.

.....2
In our letter to Father Fleury, I pointed out that as soon as the furnishings are received and if they are satisfactory, he should certify the accounts and forward same to Ottawa for payment. From your experience with us, you will realize the importance of having all the accounts reach us before the end of March, the close of our fiscal year.

The copies of the purchase orders sent to Father Fleury showed the approximate date on which shipment should be made by the firm with whom the order was placed. If there is any undue delay in this particular regard, Father Fleury should wire us at once so that we can communicate with the firm and have all shipments reach the school before the end of March.

Yours sincerely,

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Neary;

Supplementing my letter, dated January 19th, I am listing below several additional matters, which I wish to draw to your attention:

1. Now that the school kitchen is finished, only awaiting reception of equipment, it becomes apparent that an extraordinary length of stove pipe will be needed to reach from the stove to the chimney. This presents a twofold disadvantage; firstly, because the ceiling is not very high and the pipe will have to be large, it will detract greatly from the appearance of the kitchen and bakery room. It will have to pass through the wall into the bakery room and continue its ugly length to the far corner of same, dodging a few steam and water pipes on the way. Secondly, and far more serious, this long length of stove pipe will drip creosote constantly, no matter how well it is fitted. This is due to the type of firewood in this country. I have been told that it will be necessary to hang pails at each joint and further that the whole length of pipe will have to be taken down once a week and cleaned. If this is so, and dependable local inhabitants have assured me that it is, some change will have to be made, otherwise we will be put to a considerable degree of trouble and a mess will be created in the two places, kitchen and bakery, where it is necessary to maintain a high degree of cleanliness, above all others. Will you please take this matter up with the architect at once. I would suggest that for the time being, the kitchen stove flue should run through the roof right above the stove, utilizing what is called a 'Yukon chimney'. Later on during the summer a permanent solution could be found. There are enough bricks left over here to build an extra chimney.

2. A number of parcels have arrived here from the Department, mostly stationery supplies, on which we have had to pay cartage charges from Dawson Creek, B.C. I know that it is the intention of the Department to prepay all the way to the school, so I would like to know what procedure I should follow in securing re-imbursement for past payments and also for the future. So far I have receipts for all expenditures of this nature.

3. As you know, it is the Bishop's intention, with the approval of the Department, to bring the children from the Grouard School and the
Lejac School to Lower Post as soon as the building is ready. Apparently the expenses of these transfers have to be borne by the Lower Post School. We are anxious to have these children so that the school may get under way promptly, but we will require some financial assistance in the way of a special transportation grant from the Department. Will you therefore, please consider this as an application for a grant to cover the transportation of children from these two schools. I can ascertain the exact cost and so inform you as soon as possible. I would be very grateful if you would let me know the Department's attitude in this matter, by return mail.

4. In a previous requisition, I requested for the use of the School, one 16mm sound projector. This machine would have educational as well as recreational benefits. I see no mention of this equipment in the purchase orders and thought that perhaps it was overlooked. I need hardly tell you how important such a machine would be to us up here. We are very limited in our recreational facilities and the children coming from other schools can hardly help but draw comparisons to our disadvantage, since they have enjoyed moving pictures, both recreational and educational in their former schools. I trust that you will ask the Department to give special consideration to this matter.

5. In a previous letter, I requested information about installation of the school telephone. The cost of services to connect the school was quoted by the C.N.T. as about $75.00. I did not receive any reply to my request for information, but I notice on my return to Lower Post that the poles have been erected by the C.N.T. to carry the wires to the school. Apparently they had to get the poles set up before the ground froze too hard. Please advise me on this matter.

I wish to take this opportunity to thank you and other members of the Department for your kind co-operation and assistance in getting the Lower Post Indian School under way. Naturally, in an undertaking of this nature, it is to be expected that many unforeseen difficulties and problems will crop up, whose solution requires mutual understanding. We, who are to live in the school are apt to see things solely from a practicable standpoint. I mention this to assure you of my utmost sincerity in requesting adjustments of furnishings and equipment, as above.

Very sincerely,

A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. Principal

Dear Mr. Fortier:

I have been notified by the Rev. A.H. Fleury, O.M.I. who is going to be the Principal of the new "Indian Residential School at Lower Post" that the contractors "Dawson and Hall" are going to complete their contract on Feb. 15 inst. and that as a consequence the upkeep of the building from that date on shall be our sole responsibility.

On the other hand, I am in receipt of a letter from the Educational Service of the Indian Branch, dated Jan. 30 (File 942-5 El) pointing out how doubtful it will be for us to expect all the furnishings of the school before the end of March, and a consequence warning us not to count on the transfer of the Indian children from the Grouard or Lejac Schools before April.

I am sure that you will realize how costly the upkeep of such a building will be for us in this north country during the two or three intervening months from the date of completion of the building contract to the time of reception of the Indian children.

Our whole male staff, which has arrived already at Lower Post for some months, will be constantly occupied looking after the boiler, the electric plant and the various other mechanical devices, checking and uncrating the furniture as it arrives, watching day and night over the building.

The maintenance and supervising of everything connected with the building will entail, I am sure, an expenditure of well over $3,000. for which there will be no available funds until the school proper is in operation under the per capita grant system. We have
already spent the $3,500 already allocated for fuel alone.

I beg, therefore, your Department to allocate an extra sum of $3,000 for our present emergency.

Yours sincerely,

"J.L. Coudert, O.M.I.,"

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of Jan. 30.

Father Fleury has just visited Whitehorse and we discussed together several problems connected with the turnover of the School Building from the contractors "Dawson and Hall" to us.

In this connection I am sending you herewith a copy of my letter to Deputy Minister Laval Fortier, who had asked me, when I was in Ottawa to let him know whether we were in need of more money before the school is actually in operation.

I hope that the Officials of the Branch will back our demands, as we are certainly in urgent need of financial assistance to carry on until the children come in.

We have advised the Sisters of Saint Ann (three or four in number) to come to Lower Post after Easter, and help us to prepare the arrival of the children, as soon as it will be possible to look properly after them.

You will also notice the postscriptum of my letter to the Deputy Minister regarding the cost of transportation of the children of Grouard and Lejac back to their country and the Lower Post School.

May I ask your Officials further information concerning the School?

1.- Is it possible to call the School "Saint John's Residential School" or, if the Department is reluctant to give it a Christian name, could it be called by a name recalling the Indian tribes it will serve, e.g., "Nahanni Residential School"? Nahanni is the Indian name for "People of the Setting Sun"; it is the name given by the Dene or Athabascans of the River McKenzie to all their Dene or Athabascan brothers living beyond the Rockies, where the sun sets.

2.- Why is it that Superintendent Clarke has not been designated to supervise the School, since the School is located in his agency, and the Lower Post Indians come under his present care? We find it strange that Agent Meek, who has already more than he can handle in his own huge Agency of the Yukon should be designated to supervise the Lower Post School. The ideal set up would be to have Superintendent Clarke moved to Lower Post with a subagent located at Telegraph Creek; such was my suggestion to the Officials of the Branch last Fall.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Fortier;

I have been notified by the Rev. A.H. Fleury O.M.I., who is going to be the Principal of the new Indian Residential School at Lower Post, that the contractors "Dawson and Hall" are going to complete their contract on Feb. 15 inst., and that, as a consequence, the upkeep of the building from that date on shall be our sole responsibility.

On the other hand, I am in receipt of a letter from the Educational Service of the Indian Branch, dated Jan. 30 (file 942-5 El), pointing out how doubtful it will be for us to expect all the furnishings of the school before the end of March, and as a consequence warning us not to count on the transfer of the Indian children from the Grouard or Lejac Schools before April.

I am sure that you will realize how costly the upkeep of such a building will be for us in this north country during the two or three intervening months from the date of completion of the building contract to the time of reception of the Indian children.

Our whole male staff, which has arrived already at Lower Post for some months, will be constantly occupied looking after the boiler, the electric plant and the various other mechanical devices, checking and uncrating the furniture as it arrives, watching day and night over the building.

The maintenance and supervising of everything connected with the building will entail, I am sure, an expenditure of well over $3,000, for which there will be no available funds until the school proper is in operation under the per capita grant system. We have already spent the $5,500 already allocated for fuel alone.

I beg, therefore, your Department to allocate an extra sum of $3,000 for our present emergency.

Yours sincerely,

J.L. Coudert O.M.I., Vic.Ap.of Whitehorse

P.S.-I also presume that the expenses connected with the transfer of some 45 children of our Vicariate from the Grouard and Lejac Schools shall be taken care of by the Indian Branch, as there will be no funds available for such an expenditure at the School. J.L.C.

New Lower Post Residential School (St. John's) During the latter part of May construction of the above noted school commenced. Although schedule to be completed during the following December delays in construction were unavoidable due to material delivery and later cold weather which slowed work. Recent advice reveals that the school is due to open April 1st 1951 having an accommodation of between 100 to 120 pupils in residence. With the opening of this institution, many problems effecting the general welfare of large Indian families located at various bush camps can be solved by the admission of their children and due to its location in this Agency transportation costs for those being admitted will be greatly reduced in comparison to previous costs paid by the Department to Grouard and Lejac located many miles distant. To date there are fifteen children of the Atlin-Teslin Band and Tahltan Bands whose applications have been received at this office and it is expected that an added ten or more will be placed there from the isolated bush camps adjacent to Lower Post and Telegraph Creek, thereby avoiding possible starvation and illiteracy which are most evident amongst these camps and neglected children. It is proposed to have these cases dealt with during the summer months forthcoming and in some cases at the time of school opening whenever it is possible to contact the families in question. Arrangements are currently underway with Father Fleury, Principal of the new school, to carry out this work. With the accent on the admission of those children whose father or mother is deceased resulting in the Department supplying direct relief to widow and children the relief costs for this Agency should take a notable decrease.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Citizenship & Immigration, OTTAWA

Reference D.L.981-10(E) dated February 22/50.

Application is made herewith for the enrollment of Patricia WILLIAMS, daughter of Steve and Elizabeth Williams, native of the Atlin-Teslin Band in the St John's Residential School at Lower Post, B.C.

In January 1950 an application was made for the admission of Patricia's brothers and sister to the Lejac Residential school following their father's removal to Miller Bay Hospital for treatment of his active T.B. condition, on receipt of department approval.

As the child Patricia is now of school age and since she cannot obtain academic training in Atlin it is respectfully requested that her admission be approved following a satisfactory medical examination enroute at Whitehorse, Y.T.

Since the father Steve Williams is due for continued lengthy hospitalization it has been necessary for this office to maintain the child from welfare funds. This office is in receipt of written request that her child be placed at the Lower Post institution from the mother.

As this family is destitute it is requested that travel costs be paid from public funds. Exact costs can not be quoted as arrangements will be made for her removal in group with other applicants but should not exceed $50.00.

May favourable consideration be granted in this instance?

F.T. CLARK,
Superintendent.

Attached hereto, application forms for the admission of William, Belfry Harry, Albert Henry, and Eugene Etzerza, natives of the Tahltan Band to the new Lower Post Indian Residential School, Lower Post, B.C.

Following the death of her first husband, Nanook Etzerza, the mother married Jimmy Lew of white status. Immediately after her marriage with Lew the latter party deserted his wife and his whereabouts have since been unknown to both this office and Mrs. Lew. Special permission was granted by the Department for this woman to live on Tahltan I.R. 1 so that she could care for her family of Indian status. During this time these children have received regular relief assistance amounting to approximately $50.00 per year over the past five years.

Due to the location of their home some fifteen miles from Telegraph Creek the children have been unable to attend school. They have not received satisfactory supervision or training. Furthermore, due to their location they are undergoing hardship as they must transport their food supplies, by dog team some fifteen miles, since the family head is without a husband these chores and others fall upon the mother and small children.

With a view of improving the welfare of this family, this office has recently communicated with Father Fleury, principal of the new school explaining these circumstances and enquiring if it would be possible to employ Mrs. Lew in the new institution. Father Fleury has advised that he would be able to employ Mrs. Lew in the kitchen and bakery when it is opened April 1st next.

The children have been examined by the local resident physician and are in his opinion fit for admission.
It should be mentioned that the child Eugene Etzerza is the illegitimate Indian son of Dorothy Edna Etzerza eldest daughter of Mrs. Low. This girl with her mother reside in the same household and as the same circumstances are prevalent in this case as those for the other three children listed, Eugene's admission is also recommended.

In view of the above, will the Department approve of these applications and grant authority to provide for their air passenger costs from Telegraph Creek to Lower Post from public funds? These charges would amount to $175.00, the only means available, an approximate $44.00 per child.

Re: Roy James JOHNS, age 4.

With regard to the above named and previous exchange of correspondence concerning the mother Lucy Johns (158/19-1) the following is submitted.

Following the conviction and removal of Lucy Johns to the Provincial Gaol at Prince George, B.C. during the spring of 1950 the responsibility in obtaining an Indian person or couple to care for this child fell upon this office. After considerable difficulty arrangements were made with Mrs. Paddy Ward, an aged widow and grandmother of the child to undertake this work for a monthly fee of $15.00. No other party could be interested in caring for this child.

Recent reports from the Resident Nurse at Atlin, B.C. revealed that the child was not being properly fed or attended. Mrs. Ward does not speak a great deal of English and although Nurse Reddis has attempted to correct the situation by making periodic visits to this home and instructing the old lady it has been to no apparent avail. Lucy Johns has not returned to Atlin and for all intents and purposes this child could almost be classed as that of an orphan and certainly a destitute or neglected child.

The matter was discussed with Father Fleury of the Lower Post Residential school recently and he informed this office that he would be prepared to admit Roy pending the approval of the Branch.

The cheapest travel from Atlin to Lower Post amounts to approximately $80.00 and in addition it would probably be necessary to arrange for an escort in this instance. However, it may be possible to arrange to have Supt. Meek visit Atlin with his agency car thereby avoiding this expenditure.

May 31, 1951

With reference to Mr. Phelan's signal message of May 26th regarding administration of the Lower Post Indian Residential School, our enquiry which apparently was misinterpreted, was for the purpose of determining whether or not applications for admissions to this school should be processed through the office of Supt. Meek at Whitehorse or through the Superintendent at Telegraph Creek and the reason the enquiry was made was because we propose to hold whichever Superintendent is indicated responsible for the immediate reporting of admission and discharges to the Family Allowance Division.

In a circular letter dated March 15th to Superintendents and school Principals, a copy of which was sent to you, we stated: "It shall be the responsibility of the Superintendent in whose Agency the residential school is located, to check the quarterly return with the application forms and to delete from the return the names of those pupils for whom no application form was completed and submitted, and to facilitate checking, application forms from outside agencies shall be forwarded to the Superintendent in charge of the agency in which the residential school is located, for forwarding to the Department."

In the case of the Lower Post Residential School we shall have to make an exception to this statement of procedure if the school is to remain under the supervision of Mr. Meek.

Dear Father Fleury:

With the coming of September and the opening of schools across the country, we are anxious to know whether the Lower Post Indian Residential School will open classes on September 4th.

We are under the impression that most of the necessary supplies and equipment have been shipped. Would you kindly advise whether we are correct in this respect.

There are accounts for the following Purchase Orders outstanding:

P.O. # 2128 Refrigerator
    2198 Laundry equipment
    2621 Darning machine
    2694 Fencing material
    2845 Hair clippers
    2129 Kitchen and bakery equipment

If these items have been delivered and you have the accounts, you should certify them in the usual manner.

Our records indicate that we have approved admissions for about thirty pupils to enter the school for the first time.
On November 22, 1950, we forwarded you copies of letters sent to Reverend J. Mulvihill, O.M.I., Principal, Lejac School and Reverend G. Tessier, O.M.I., Principal, Grouard School advising them of the children that will be transferred to the Lower Post School when it opens.

It would be appreciated if you would advise as soon as possible whether these pupils have been transferred, whether the new pupils have been admitted and what other pupils you are expecting shortly after opening. It would also be appreciated if you would let us know how many pupils are enrolled and have commenced their studies.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Fr. Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of the School states: "These two children were sent to the school by authority of the doctor who was in Ross River." A very severe form of measles recently swept through the Indians at Ross River and it would appear that the doctor who was sent there by Indian Health Services sent the children to the Lower Post school to protect them. Unfortunately he did not conduct a physical examination.

May approval be given for the admission of these children. They will be medically examined by a doctor being sent by Indian Health Services at Edmonton.

Dear Father Fleury:

I am in receipt of your letter of Aug. 27th regarding the admission of Alice Bill, Aida Jack and Dorothy Johnson to the School. I understand that more definite information about these cases is desirable and very willingly I hasten to give it.

Apart from the fact that these girls are anxious to get more education but have no chance to go to any other school, the social environment in which they live presently is a great danger to their morals; they are good, want to stay good, but it seems that everything is up against them. They belong to very small bands (2 or 3 Indian families) living along the Alaska Highway, in proximity of army camps and taverns. Since there is no police around, drunks and hobos are free to go and mix with the Indians, especially women and girls. In the past few years, we had to deplore quite a few cases of illegitimate babies. And what makes the situation worse is the fact that these many girls actually can't get acquainted with Indian boys that they would contemplate to marry later on, because there are very few boys and they are all too closely related to them; there is no big Indian village in this part of the Yukon but only small bands living hundreds of miles apart and closely related to one another.

Alice was 14 years old when Johnny Bill married her mother. Johnny and his wife don't get along too well and can't have children so Johnny is trying to go with Alice, who has to live in the same house since she doesn't have any other place to go. Alice doesn't want that business and so gets beaten every once in a while.

Aida and Dorothy are not spoiled yet but other big girls who are running wild with soldiers and hobos are trying to get them in their ways. Their parents can't control everything and feel more or less helpless; they want protection for their daughters, especially at that critical age. In my opinion, a period at the Lower Post Residential School is a "must" for these girls if they are to start well in life.

Hoping that these explanations are satisfactory, I remain

Yours very truly in Christ and Mary Immaculate

"Father E. Morisset. O.M.I."

January 8, 1952.

Mr. R.J. Meek,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Whitehorse, Y.T.,

With reference to your letter of December 28th regarding Caroline Jim who is at present a pupil in the Lower Post Indian Residential School, you are advised that we have been informed by Mr. McCrimmon of the Status and Membership Division that this girl was enfranchised as you indicated in your letter and that she should be discharged from the Lower Post school immediately.

As this is a Government-owned school and as this child has been enfranchised we would be subject to criticism if this child was maintained in the school even if the Principal did not claim grant for her.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

On January 8th Bishop J.L. Coudert, O.M.I., visited this office. He advised me that he had received word that Dick Ladue, son of Jack Ladue, 026, Selkirk Band, now living at Ross River, was destitute and uncared for. The mother of Dick is presently a patient at the Charles Camsell Hospital, the father is out on his trap-line, and the boy is being maintained temporarily by his grandfather who is unable to continue this care. Dick Ladue is nearly six years old.

Bishop Coudert requested authorization to bring in Dick on the next available aircraft from Ross River and to have him admitted to the Lower Post Residential School. I advised His Excellency that I felt sure no difficulty would be found in admitting Dick a few months before his sixth birthday.

There is no regular fare from Ross River by aircraft; charges are usually split into different amounts between traders, missionaries, Government officials and others. I trust my actions meet with your approval.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent

VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

Mr. Philip Phelan
Superintendent of Education
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Citizenship and Immigration
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Admission to Lower Post School of Catholic orphan Clyde Blackjack

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I beg to bring before you the case of a Catholic orphan boy, about 14 years of age, who should have been sent to Lower Post School last Fall.

As you may see from the local missionary's exposition of the case, no cooperation was given to us in helping us to have said orphan boy placed in Lower Post School.

I am personally well acquainted with the whole family; they all joined the Catholic Church nearly ten years ago; two of the children were sent to the Grouard School; the father is now dead for some years, and the mother, along with four of her children, is in Camsell Hospital.

Under those conditions, the boy Clyde, only 14 years of age, is allowed to roam around free, from camp to camp among his relatives, without any proper physical, moral, religious and educational supervision.

I was amazed to hear that Agent Meek, far from showing any interest in the educational welfare of the boy, looked for every possible excuse to discourage Father Turenne to have the boy admitted to the Lower Post School.

In my estimation the Indian Boarding School at Lower Post has been constructed by the Indian Branch primarily for such typical cases as that of Clyde Blackjack; and Agent Meek should be clearly instructed in his duty of making every possible effort to send catholic orphan children to such an Institution, without even waiting for our own request.

I may say that Agent Clarke of the Stikine Agency seemed to have thoroughly understood his duty in this respect and has given our missionaries his full cooperation regarding the admittance of all needy children of his Agency to the Lower Post School.

Hoping that Clyde Blackjack's case will be thoroughly investigated by the Branch and that the boy will be sent without delay to Lower Post, while he is still of school age and able to learn,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

J.L. Goudert O.M.I., Vic.Ap.of Whitehorse
Most Reverend Bishop Jean-Louis Coudert O.M.I.
P.O. Box 95
Whitehorse, Yukon

Your Excellency,

I would like to bring to your attention the case of Clyde Blackjack, of the Carmacks Indian Band.

Clyde, 14 years of age, is now without a home. His father died few years ago. His mother was sent to Cassell Hospital last fall. I understand that Clyde was left in charge of his brother Roddy; but he too has spent most of his time in Whitehorse Hospital, where he still is as a patient. Consequently Clyde is left by himself, taking refuge with some of the Indians trapping up the Yukon river.

This boy has never been to school. Being an orphan, I think that he should be directed to a boarding school. I took the matter up with the Indian Agent, Mr. Meek, last fall, but the Agent insisted that we could not force Clyde to go to school if he did not want to. He tried to argue with the new Indian Act in hand that no compulsory action could be taken in such a case. Is the government spending thousands of dollars to build and upkeep schools only for children who feel that they would like to attend these schools?

I do not have to go over all what the Indian Act says in regard to school, but permit me to quote No. 115: "... every Indian child who has attained the age of seven years shall attend school." No. 119-b says: "An Indian child who refuses or fails to attend school regularly shall be deemed to be a juvenile delinquent within the meaning of The Juvenile Delinquents Act."

If I see clear through this, it seems to me that the official government policy is that every Indian child should attend school and that proper measures should be taken when one does not abide by the Law.

Clyde being of school age and a catholic should normally be sent to a catholic school, in this instance to the Lower Post Catholic Indian Residential School. Here again the Indian Agent seemed to have a different opinion. He told me that if Clyde would decide to go to school, we could not "ipso facto" direct him to the Catholic school. Reason: his mother being away, she could not sign the required application form. Therefore any guardian, (to my knowledge no one has been officially appointed) being protestant, could sign in favor of a protestant school. This opinion seems to me to be contrary to the letter and the spirit of No. 117 of the Indian Act.

I hope, Excellency, that you will give due consideration to this case since it is in the best interest of the child involved.

I have the honor to be, Your Excellency,

Sincerely yours in Christ Jesus,

[Signature]

February 7, 1952.

Mr. R.J. Meek,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Whitehorse, Y.T.,

We have a letter from Bishop Coudert regarding Clyde Blackjack.

From his correspondence it is noted that this boy is of school age and is a Roman Catholic. We also note that he is an orphan and it is felt that it is in the boy's interest to receive institutional care. With this in mind he should be placed in the Lower Post school. The Department does not see any reason why this boy shall not be placed in the Lower Post Indian Residential School.

It would be appreciated if you would arrange to place this boy in the Lower Post school provided he meets medical requirements and forward the necessary application for his admission, to this office.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Reference your letter of 7th instant, file 942-10 (E6), re Clyde Blackjack, Carmacks Band. Acting on your instructions I made enquiries as to Clyde's whereabouts and found he was out on the trap-line of his uncle. On February 18th I received the following telegram from A.R. Hayes, J.P., Carmacks:

CAN YOU PLACE CLYDE BLACKJACK WITH REV LEE OR CARCROSS SCHOOL IMMEDIATELY STOP HAS BEEN SUPPORTED BY GEORGE CHARLIE ALL WINTER BUT POOR FUR CATCH WITH LOW PRICES MAKE IT IMPOSSIBLE FOR GEORGE TO CONTINUE ARRANGEMENTS STOP PLEASE WIRE REPLY BY NOON TUESDAY

There was considerable correspondence concerning the sending of two Blackjack children to the Grouard Residential School some years ago instead of the Carcross Residential School where David Blackjack, (deceased) the father, wished them sent. See your file 131-1-10 (W1), August 15, 1947, and November 18, 1947, also my letter of June 28, 1948, wherein I quoted statement from him as follows:

"Mr. Ward came down river with preacher, he asked me 'Do you want to send your children to school?' I said 'Yes, Dolly and Sally to Carcross School.' I signed three papers for Mr. Ward. A week or two later Father Bob he came with papers and asked me to sign for my kids to Catholic School. My wife said she don't want to send to Catholic School, so I don't sign papers. That's all I know until I hear my kids at Grouard School."

In view of this I sent the following telegram to George Charlie, uncle of Clyde Blackjack:

RETET CLYDE BLACKJACK HAVE LETTER FROM DEPARTMENT STATING CLYDE SHOULD BE PLACED LOWER POST CATHOLIC SCHOOL STOP AS MY RECORDS SHOW HIM ANGLICAN REQUEST FURTHER INFORMATION PREFERABLY FROM OLDER MEMBER HIS FAMILY HIS RELIGIOUS AFFILIATIONS AND IF DESIRED TO ADMIT TO LOWER POST SCHOOL
The following reply was received from A.R. Hayes, J.P., acting for George Charlie who cannot write:

CLYDE BLACKJACK STATES HE DOES NOT WISH TO ATTEND CATHOLIC SCHOOL AND PREFERENCES CARCROSS STOP NO OLDER MEMBER OF HIS FAMILY HERE STOP DURING LAST YEAR CENSUS TAKING HIS MOTHER REGISTERED HERSELF AND ALL HER CHILDREN THEN IN CARMACKS AS ANGLICANS TO MY KNOWLEDGE STOP GEORGE CHARLIE RELATIVE CONFIRMS THIS

The mother of Clyde is in the Charles Camsell Hospital. His oldest brother Roddy Blackjack, who has been acting as his guardian since the death of Clyde's father, is in the Whitehorse General Hospital. Yesterday I interviewed him on his wishes and he made the following statement:

"I want my brother Clyde to be near me and to go to Whitehorse or Carcross School. Before my mother left Carmacks for Charles Camsell Hospital she told me to send Clyde to Carcross School. Signed.

Roddy Blackjack."

May I have your instructions.

c.c. Indian Commissioner for B.C.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent
March 7, 1952.

Mr. R. J. Meek,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Whitehorse, Yukon.

Re: Clyde Blackjack

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo with reference to the above-named boy.

The contents of your letter have been very carefully considered and it is difficult to understand why you found it necessary to communicate with so many people.

As we had previously informed you, this boy is only 14 years of age and his immediate relatives are in no position to support him. This information is borne out by the messages which you quote in your letter of February 20th. Consequently, it is in the boy's best interests to be in a residential school.

Official letter of February 7th instructed you to place this boy in the Lower Post Residential School. It is felt that it was unnecessary for you to consult other people as these instructions were specific and should have been carried out.

I will expect to hear from you in the near future, stating that this boy is in the Lower Post School.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Reference your letter of 7th instant, file 942-10 (E), re Clyde Blackjack. I beg to advise that on Thursday March 13th, I proceeded by car to Carmacks to pick up Clyde Blackjack, however he was not then in the village and I decided to return later.

On March 20th Clyde was brought to Whitehorse by Fr. Turenne, he was given a medical examination, and was sent to Lower Post Residential School on March 22nd.

Application for admission form is attached hereto. Copy of same has gone forward to the principal of the School.

(R.J. Meek)
Superintendent

Application is hereby made on behalf of Mr. J. T. Jack, native of the Atlin-Teslin Band, residing at Telegraph Creek I.R. 6 for the admission of his three children Cecelia Jack, Margery Jack & Lydia Jack to the Lower Post Residential School this coming September 1952.

These children have had three, four and one years of schooling respectively to date. The home conditions with which these girls are faced daily are such to definitely warrant their admission to the Lower Post School.

The mother of these children, Rosie T. Jack is separated from her legally married husband. She has been repeatedly brought to Court for the making of intoxicants and living an immoral life. Even so, no penalty appears to correct her ways and as a result the environment with which her young daughters are being brought up in is and will be a disaster for them. This woman openly lives with another man, other than her husband, has had one illegitimate child and is now expecting another. The girls on whose behalf we are now applying for admission are definitely in need of a home away from home and proper discipline.

Mr. Jack is anxious that his daughters be granted the privilege of attending the Lower Post School. He is unable to meet the transportation charges by aircraft which would of necessity be borne from public funds and would amount to $60.00 per child. Father Fleury has signaled his acceptance of them on or about September 1st next, if authorized by the Department.

May favourable consideration be given in this instance. Completed application forms duly signed are attached hereto.

Re: Gertie DENNIS #05-025.

The above named, born November 19th 1934 formerly attended the Lejac Indian Residential School until such time as she developed a tubercular condition and was temporarily discharged and admitted to the Miller Bay Indian Hospital at Prince Rupert in 1946.

I am enclosing a copy of a report on this girl received from Miss. G. Harris, P.H.N., of Miller Bay Hospital which is self explanatory.

Although applicant is almost 18 years of age this office would recommend that every consideration be given to have her admitted to the Lower Post Indian Residential School for a least one full year term commencing September 1952. Gertie has no parents living, her relatives are most incompetent to ensure that she receives the proper rest necessary after her lengthy illness and supervise her using the necessary T.B. rehabilitation ration authorized by Dr. Galbraith, Medical Superintendent of Miller Bay Hospital. It is apparent from Nurse Harris's report that this child is not content nor will she possibly improve in her present location.

This office has contacted Father Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of the Lower Post School and he has consented to admit this girl for a period of one year.

May this office be notified by wire if transportation costs will be met from public funds for Gertie Dennis Prince Rupert to Lower Post, B.C. at an approximate cost of $95.00 since there are no relatives to financially assist.

Indian Superintendent.

Re: Gertie Dennis

Dear Mr. Clark:

The above named girl came to Miller Bay Hospital December 28th 1946 where she remained until June 12th 1951 when she was transferred to Ceqaleetza Hospital for surgery. She has had a right upper thoracic plasty and returned to Miller Bay Hospital March 28th 1952. On June 29th 1952 she was discharged a little earlier than Dr. Galbraith wished but not against medical advice.

Since discharge she has been living with Peggy Etzerza at Port Edward in very crowded housing at Port Edward. Dr. Galbraith would like to have Gertie take rest periods and go to bed early for another two year period. She should not undertake any work for some time yet. Tuberculosis ratings have been issued from the day of her discharge.

Because the present living conditions at Port Edward are most unsuitable for post hospital care of a patient Dr. Galbraith has asked me to write to you about alternative plans for Gertie. This girl who is less than eighteen years of age, has had only about two years schooling at Lejac plus some tuition whilst in hospital. Besides her tubercular handicap she is also suffering from impaired hearing. Her elder brothers and sisters at Telegraph Creek seem to have no interest in Gertie whatsoever. None of them have ever written to her nor have they ever visited her. The only person whom Gertie seems interested in are her younger brothers and sisters at Lower Pest, B.C.

Considering all the facts above, Dr. Galbraith was wondering if it would be possible for Gertie to have one more year's schooling at Lower Pest, B.C., where she would not only have the additional instruction but would have a regular routine and close supervision. If this could be arranged she probably would be well enough to work by the end of the school year June 1953.

We would very much appreciate an early reply as to what you think Gertie should do now.

Yours very truly,

SGD.
Miss. G. Harris, P.H.N.

With reference to your letter dated March 13th 942-10(E6) concerning the admission of E. Johnston to the Lower Post Indian Residential School.

According to our band book records this family was considered to be of the Roman Catholic faith and still so indicate. During a visit to Teslin, Y.T. in June 1951 the father of the child approached the writer concerning the admission of his daughter to the Lower Post Residential School. Since there was some doubt by church officials with their records that this child was or was not Catholic or non-Catholic a statement concerning the denomination was signed by the father who indicated that she was not Roman Catholic.

As a result, Johnston was advised that the child could not be admitted to the Lower Post Residential School unless the girl was properly received into the Roman Catholic Church and if this was his wish he should take the necessary steps. Prior to admission the child was received on the 13th day of September 1951 and both documents sent with the application to positively establish that according to the parent

(a) The child had not been a member of the Roman Catholic Church.

(b) That the child through the baptism was now positively a member of the church and eligible for admission.

[Signature]

Reference your letter of 7th instant, file 942-10 (E6) and Elizabeth Johnston. Due to poor transportation and communication facilities in the more remote areas of the Yukon and northern B.C. it occasionally happens that a child is placed in Residential School before the authorization for admission is received from Headquarters. In the case under review, the Application for Admission Forms were forwarded to the Indian Superintendent in charge Stikine Agency, at that time I believe it was F.A. Clark. In the summer time mail does not fly in to Telegraph Creek but has a very long roundabout route and it is probable that quite a few weeks elapsed before the Superintendent was able to forward the Application to Ottawa.

On speaking to Mr. J.F. Orman, who signed as a witness to the signature of Chief Wm. A. Johnston, he states that Johnston was anxious to have his child Elizabeth attend Carcross Residential School, and that the baptism of Elizabeth is recorded in the Anglican Register at Teslin.

I have for acknowledgment your letter 942-10(E6) dated May 7th 1952 concerning Elizabeth Johnson member of the Atlin-Teslin Band currently attending the Lower Post Indian Residential School.

A search has been made of our records at this office concerning the original admission of this girl to the Carcross Residential School during 1948 and we are unable to trace any past correspondence concerning same.

The family file indicates by way of family allowance notices that she was in attendance at this school and also in a letter from Father Dream of Teslin, Y.T. that Johnson's girl was currently at the school, in letter to this office dated December 8th 1950, stating that the father intended to remove her to the Lower Post School when opened.

As stated, our band books indicate that the girl was of the Roman Catholic faith. This could be an error. We had no positive record until the baptismal certificate was received and forwarded to Ottawa with her application to the Lower Post School.

As previously stated, the father approached the writer in June 1951 requesting that she be enrolled at Lower Post and the steps taken by this office have been outlined in letter dated April 4th 1952, to definitely establish her denomination.

If so instructed, may this matter be held in abeyance until a visit is made to Teslin in June whereupon the father can be again interviewed and the written direction of the parent obtained as applicable under section 117 of the Indian Act?

Indian Superintendent.

When visiting Teslin Band last week I was requested by Charlie Jules to have his daughter Kitty, returned to her home to assist her mother who is ill. Kitty Jule is No. 014 on the Register of the Lower Post Indian Residential School, age 13, and in Grade IV.

I visited their home, the mother, Graffie, has three young children to care for, and is not well. I spoke to Fr. A. Dream, O.M.I., and we agreed that the request was reasonable. Kitty would return to school in September 1953, her older sister Effie will have then reached the age of 16 and be discharged from Lower Post School.

I sent a message to Fr. A.H. Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of Lower Post Residential School asking for his recommendation. By telegram received yesterday he concurs in discharge of Kitty Jule. May authorization be received for the discharge (or leave of absence) of Kitty Jule for the remainder of the present school term.

Superintendent
To my great surprise, I was told by Father Murray, Principal of the Lower Post Residential school, recently, that he is not receiving any grant from the Government for Elizabeth Johnston of Teslin. I am at a loss to understand the policy of the Government.

Early in the spring of 1951, Mr. William Johnston notified Indian Superintendent Mr. Pheek, contact man for the Lower Post school, that he wanted to transfer his daughter Elizabeth from Carcross to Lower Post because the whole family was following instructions in order to become Catholic.

Mr. Pheek told me himself, that his reply to William Johnston was: "It is up to you."

When Elizabeth came back from Carcross for the holidays of 1951, her father sent her to the Catholic mission, every day, for instruction. After two months, Elizabeth was baptized.
and received in the Church. Then, Official application for transfer and admittance in the Lower Post Residential School was made. Baptism Certificate and written affidavit by the Parents were attached to the application.

As all this was completely in accordance with the new Indian Act, completely in accordance with Indian Superintendent Mr. Week, Contact Henry. As Elizabeth was now a Catholic child and as her Parents did not want her to lose any "school time", they sent her to the Lower Post Residential School when that school opened in the fall of 1951.

In the summer of 1952, after a full course of instructions, Mr. William Johnston, his wife and the rest of the family were officially received in the Church. They made their Profession of Faith and were baptized Confirmationally. Then the whole family is now Catholic - Mr. Week has been notified of this. Last summer, I sent a list of our True Catholic Indians to your Department showing William Johnston and his family as Catholics... And yet, Elizabeth is not officially admitted in the Lower Post Residential School.

I am unable to understand such pressure on the part of the Government.
Would you kindly advise me, Dear Mr. Phelan,
what should be done next in order to have
this matter cleared out. I can send you copies
of the profession of faith of Parents and children,
baptism certificates; copies of affidavits if any
of these things can help.

Mr. Wreck, Indian Superintendent, has been reluctant
to correct the errors in his census about the
religious denominations. Last year, Jack Smarch
of Teslin and Watson Smarch discovered that
they were registered as Church of England, and so
was the family of Jack Smarch. They went to
make an official protest to Mr. Wreck who
corrected the error. I was present at the Protest.
We found out then also that "Tom Peters" who
had his son Frank and who still has his daughter
Theresa in the school at Lower Post, was also
registered as Church of England. We brought to the
attention of Mr. Wreck that "Tom Peters" and his
family never belonged to the "Church of England"
but were always faithful Catholics. Mr. Wreck
replied that he was almost sure that this was
an error but he would not correct the error until
he sees Tom Peters. Tom Peters and his family are
still registered as Church of England today in his
books.

Hoping to have some advice from you, in the
near future, on the matter of Elizabeth Johnston
and wishing you a very happy and most
kind New Year.

I am,

Truly Yours,

Dear Mr. Phelan;

In reference to the case of Jennie Dickson, pupil #065 at the Lower Post Indian School, whose removal you have requested in a recent letter, will you please consider the following facts:

1. The above named child, Jennie Dickson is a Roman Catholic. Her father, John Dickson is also a Roman Catholic. Copies of affidavits certifying these facts are enclosed.

2. Application for admission to the Lower Post Indian School was signed by the father, John Dickson and recommended by Mr. R.J. Meek, Indian Superintendent, in September 1952. The application was held here pending medical examination of the child. Copy has now gone forward to Ottawa.

In your letter you have stated that this girl should leave the Lower Post School, because the Department has not approved her admission. May I respectfully point out that in view of the above facts, it would appear to be in order now for the Department to approve the admission.

In discussing this case with His Excellency, Bishop J.L. Coudeurt, it would appear that, if the child Jennie Dickson were summarily dismissed from the Catholic Indian School at Lower Post, certain regretful and disturbing results would ensue; namely (a) The Indian people of the district would look upon it as a penalty imposed on the parent for becoming a Catholic, since he now would be unable to find schooling for his child, although the Indian Act guarantees such schooling. (b) A very weighty obstacle would be placed before the future activities of the missionaries in the Ross River district, since the people would consider that even if they freely wished to become Catholics, they would have great difficulties in sending their children to a Catholic school.
I have mentioned the results of my discussion with Bishop Coudert in order that the Department may have full knowledge of the import of this case.

As Principal, I have submitted above (paragraphs 1 and 2) the facts which led me to accept the child Jennie Dickson, into the Lower Post Indian School. I see no reason why approval of admission should be withheld. The circumstances of this case are similar to the admissions of other children in the school; namely: the child is a Catholic Indian; the father is a Catholic and wishes the child in the Catholic school.

In view of the above, I trust that you will please review this case and advise me of the results. I will be glad to forward any additional information that you may require.

Very sincerely,

Re: Elizabeth Johnston

This family is from the Stikine Agency in the Province of British Columbia and both parents are living.

In 1948 this girl was placed by her father in the Carcross C.E. Indian Residential School. Although her admission to this school was not approved she remained there until June, 1951.

On checking the December 1951 Quarterly Return for the Lower Post Indian Residential School this girl's name was noted on it. As her admission to the Lower Post R.C. School had not been approved and as she previously attended the Carcross C.E. School Superintendent Meek under whose jurisdiction the Lower Post School is written. He was instructed to advise Father A.H. Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of the Lower Post School that no grant would be allowed for this pupil until her admission to the Lower Post School was approved. Superintendent Meek was requested to obtain full particulars on this girl's admission to the Lower Post School after attending the Carcross School from 1948 to 1951.

On January 10, 1952, Superintendent Meek replied:

"Elizabeth Johnston belongs to the Stikine Agency, being a member of the Atlin-Teslin Band, family # 036. Some two months ago, Father A. Dream of Teslin mentioned to me in casual conversation that William Johnston, father of Elizabeth had been received into the Roman Catholic Church."
As Mr. Meek's letter indicated that the girl is a member of a Band in the Stikine Agency, Superintendent Clark was written and in a letter dated February 15th he stated:

"With regard to the admission of Elizabeth Johnston of the Atlin-Teslin Band, during a visit to Teslin in June the father of this girl, Chief William A. Johnston requested that she be admitted to the Lower Post Residential School. According to our Agency book records, this family was considered to be of the Roman Catholic Faith and still so indicates".

Attached, marked "A" is an application signed by the father requesting the admission of Elizabeth to the Lower Post R.C. Indian Residential School. Superintendent Clark recommends this admission.

Attached, marked "B" is a Certificate of Baptism indicating that Elizabeth was baptized according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

Attached, marked "C" is Certificate of Baptism for Elizabeth Johnston with a note indicating that she was confirmed on July 8, 1952.

Attached, marked "D" is Certificate of Baptism indicating that the mother Daisy Johnston was baptized according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

Attached, marked "E" and "F" are Professions of Faith of Elizabeth Johnston and Daisy Johnston.

Attached, marked "G" is Profession of Faith of William Johnston, the father. On this document is a note signed by Father A. Drean, O.M.I., indicating that William Johnston was baptized in the Eastern Orthodox Church in Juneau in 1900.

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on the application for admission of Elizabeth Johnston to the Lower Post R.C. Indian Residential School.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Elizabeth Johnston

This family is from the Stikine Agency in the Province of British Columbia and both parents are living.

In 1948 this girl was placed by her father in the Carcross C.E. Indian Residential School. Although her admission to this school was not approved she remained there until June, 1951.

On checking the December 1951 Quarterly Return for the Lower Post Indian Residential School, this girl's name was noted on it. As her admission to the Lower Post R.C. School had not been approved and as she previously attended the Carcross C.E. School, Superintendent Meek under whose jurisdiction the Lower Post School is, was written. He was instructed to advise Father A.H. Fleury, O.M.I., Principal of the Lower Post School that no grant would be allowed for this pupil until her admission to the Lower Post School was approved. Superintendent Meek was requested to obtain full particulars on this girl's admission to the Lower Post School after attending the Carcross School from 1948 to 1951.

On January 10, 1952, Superintendent Meek replied:

"Elizabeth Johnston belongs to the Stikine Agency, being a member of the Atlin-Teslin Band, family #036. Some two months ago, Father A. Dream of Teslin mentioned to me in casual conversation that William Johnston, father of Elizabeth had been received into the Roman Catholic Church".
As Mr. Meek's letter indicated that the girl is a member of a Band in the Stikine Agency, Superintendent Clark was written and in a letter dated February 15th he stated:

"With regard to the admission of Elizabeth Johnston of the Atlin-Teslin Band, during a visit to Teslin in June the father of this girl, Chief William A. Johnston requested that she be admitted to the Lower Post Residential School. According to our Agency book records, this family was considered to be of the Roman Catholic Faith and still so indicates".

Attached, (marked "A") is an application signed by the father requesting the admission of Elizabeth to the Lower Post (R.C.) Indian Residential School. Superintendent Clark recommends this admission.

Attached, (marked "B") is a Certificate of Baptism indicating that Elizabeth was baptized according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

Attached, (marked "C") is Certificate of Baptism for Elizabeth Johnston with a note indicating that she was confirmed on July 8, 1952.

Attached, (marked "D") is Certificate of Baptism indicating that the mother, Daisy Johnston was baptized according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

Attached, (marked "E" and "F") are Professions of Faith of Elizabeth Johnston and Daisy Johnston.
Attached, (marked "G") is Profession of Faith of William Johnston, the father. On this document is a note signed by Father A. Drean, O.M.I., indicating that William Johnston was baptized in the Eastern Orthodox Church in Juneau in 1900.

It would be appreciated if a ruling were given on the application for admission of Elizabeth Johnston to the Lower Post R.C. Indian Residential School.

Director.

Re: Transfer of Stanley Blackjack, a Catholic Indian Boy, from the Yukon Indian Agency, to the Lower Post Indian Catholic Boarding School

Dear Sir;

I wish to call your attention to an injustice recently perpetrated by your Agent at Whitehorse, in sending Stanley Blackjack to the Indian Baptist School of Whitehorse.

1.- As the enclosed documents show, Stanley Blackjack:

a.- Stanley Blackjack is a Catholic Indian Boy from Carmacks, Y.T., who was baptized by one of our Oblate Missionaries, at the age of 4, on March 10th 1944, on the Yukon River.

b.- His parents, David and Bessie Blackjack, were received in the Catholic Church, at their own urgent request and after proper instructions, by the same Rev. Father M. Bobillier, on the same day as Stanley (March 10, 1944).

c.- Five other children of the same family, viz. Roddy, Kitty, Sally, Dolly and Clyde, were received in the Church on the same day as their parents and their brother Stanley.

2.- Following their reception into the Church, and after the required applications had been properly approved by the local Agent, two of the children of School Age were sent to the Catholic Indian Boarding School of Grouard, Alberta, viz. Sally and Dolly, around 1946.

3.- Their brother Clyde has been for the past two years at the Indian Catholic Boarding School of Lower Post, B.C.

4.- Both parents are now dead.

5.- Stanley has spent the past two or three years as a patient in Charles Camsell Hospital, and was duly registered there, as well as his sisters Sally and Dolly, and his mother Bessie (who died there last fall) as a Catholic patient.

6.- Upon Stanley's discharge from the Hospital, and notwithstanding our protests, Stanley has been placed by Indian Agent Meek in the Baptist Indian School of Whitehorse, after obtaining from Stanley's brother (Roddy, also a Catholic) a signature to that effect.

With reference to your letter of July 17th regarding the placing of Stanley Blackjack in the Whitehorse School, we are anxious to know the reason for your placing this boy in the Whitehorse School without first having the necessary authority to do so.

If you will refer to our letter of February 7th you will note that the Department instructed you to place Clyde Blackjack, who we are informed is a brother of Stanley Blackjack in the Lower Post Indian Residential School as our information at that time indicated that the parents were dead and that the parents were of the Roman Catholic faith. In view of this information it is felt that Stanley Blackjack should also be placed in the Lower Post Indian Residential School.

It is noted from your telegram that you have an application for admission for this boy. It would be appreciated if you would forward it to this office and make immediate arrangements to have Stanley Blackjack removed from the Whitehorse School and placed in the Lower Post Residential School.

Please advise this office by telegram when this has been done.

Philip Phelan,

Re: Stanley Blackjack's admission to Lower Post Indian Res. School.-(Whitehorse Agency)

Dear Mr. Phelan;

I deeply regretted on my way through Ottawa on July 13 last, to have been unable to see you and discuss thoroughly with you the Stanley Blackjack's case.

At the occasion of a visit I paid to the Acting Director of the Branch, Mr. Jones, I entrusted to his care all the documents concerning the matter to be communicated to you.

I feel that the settlement of this case is very urgent and should be dealt with immediately, for the following reasons:

After a long stay in Camsell Hospital, Stanley Blackjack was sent last Spring to the Whitehorse Baptist School, on the sole authority of Agent Meek, though the boy was a Catholic and had never had any connection with the Baptists; in fact, the whole family had been received by one of our missionaries into the Catholic Church, at their own spontaneous request, some 9 years ago, following which two of his sisters and one of his brothers, being of school age, were sent to our Catholic Boarding Schools of Grouard and Lower Post, with forms of admission duly signed by Agent Meek. After a stay of one month at the Baptist School of Whitehorse last Spring, the boy was allowed to go to Carmacks and spend the summer with his relatives.

The father and mother being now dead, Stanley is an orphan, and in my estimation should not have been allowed to return to Carmacks, where he is running a great risk of being neglected and of relapsing to an active tuberculosis condition.

We all feel very upset about the handling of this case and the prejudice shown against us, since we have not even been consulted by your Agent concerning the disposal of the child, upon his being discharged from the Camsell Hospital.

I am prepared to go to the utmost to have this situation straightened up, and have the boy protected physically, morally and religiously, as he is fully entitled to according to the Indian Act, in his capacity as a Catholic orphan boy deprived of both parents; all the lawyers I talked to concerning this matter, were indignant over the arbitrary way the case has been handled by your Agent.

Our principal, Father Fleury, is willing to accept the boy immediately and I respectfully beg you to take the proper step to have him sent without any further delay to the Lower Post Residential School.

Yours sincerely

[Signature]

Mr. F.A. Clark,

With reference to your letter of May 8th regarding the admission of the five Bob children to the Lower Post Indian Residential School, the Department approves their admission.

It is noted that the Department will be obliged to bear pay transportation charges of $18c. for these children from Telegraph Creek to the Lower Post School.

The Department is prepared to bear this expenditure and it is felt that the children should not be placed in the Lower Post school until September 1st. In that way, it would not be necessary to bring them home for summer vacation.

It is noted from your correspondence that the father of these children is working when work is available and it would be appreciated if you would advise him that the Department will not be able to pay transportation charges for these children when returning home for holidays in future years; consequently he should be advised to keep in mind this fact and save sufficient money to bring the children home for vacations in future.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Brisebois,

Yesterday I saw Colonel Neary in his office. I asked him about having our light bill paid by the Branch. He advised me to write to you requesting this and he was quite sure it could be arranged.

Dear Mr. Birebois,

I wish to request that arrangements be made to have the light bill for the United Church Teachers' Residence paid by the Indian Affairs Branch.

I understand that this expense is customarily met by the Department, but so far this has not been the case in regard to my residence.

Yours very truly,

Viola M. Daly.
Caughnawaga, Que.,
July 9, 1947.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to transmit you herewith the original of a letter received from Miss Viola Daly, teacher at the local U.C., Indian Day School, in which she is applying for the payment of the electricity used at their residence.

I would kindly ask you to take this request into consideration, as electricity is usually paid in such cases.

(Frs. Brisebois)

Please forward immediately a requisition for the coal required at the day schools in the Caughnawagee Agency for the heating season 1949-50. Shipping instructions and the size of coal required should be stated in each case.

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST Chief, Education Division
The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

As requested by your letter of the 31st ultimo I beg to enclose herewith a requisition for the coal required for the coming winter for the Caughnawaga Schools and Teacher's Residences.

You will note that no coal has been ordered for the St. Isidore Road School and Teacher's Residence as I understand it will be closed next year and the children will travel to the Village Schools.

Also no coal ordered for the two Junior classes of the R.C. School, which we are renting, as the children will attend the new School.

The same was done for the Junior class of the U.C. School, as they will transfer to the Eastern School.

(Frs. Brisebois)
